78, 79, 81, 95, 98, 100, 109, 169, 173, 197, 201, 203, 212, 229, 230, 232, 237, 238, 260, 261, 262, 270, 281, 318, 328, 351, 378, 401, 403, 404, 414, 420, 424, 429, 434, 435, 436, 437, 439, 440, 441, 442, 443, 444, 448, 449, 451, 452, 454, 456, 457, 459, 461, 469, 479, 483, 493, 537, 538, 539, 540, 541, 548, 549 Appendix A: Cape Lookout Interim Protected Species Management Plan / Environmental Assessment Modified Preferred Alternative ALTERNATIVE ELEMENTS SUMMARY—SPECIES SURVEY AND MANAGEMENT APPENDIX A: CAPE LOOKOUTINTERIM PROTECTED SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN / ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT MODIFIED PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Bird—Pre-nesting*  Species Survey  PIPL—Survey active nesting areas for piping plover arrival and pre-nesting behavior beginning March 15, at least once a week on North Core Banks (NCB) and South Core Banks (SCB). Beginning April 1, surveying in these areas would increase to three times a week (or every other day). Survey would include potential new habitat and historic nesting areas as determined appropriate by a qualified staff biologist. Monitoring reports will include descriptions of management measures in place and document piping plover behavior sufficient to evaluate the effects of management actions at the site. AMOY—Survey all NCB and SCB beaches for AMOY activity 2 days per week beginning mid-April. Surveys cease when all chicks have fledged or are lost. CWB—Survey active nesting areas for CWB at least 3 days per week when PIPL monitoring occurs. Survey potential new habitat and historic nesting areas as time permits. Surveys cease when all chicks have fledged or are lost.  Every 3 years during the statewide census, map colonies using GPS. WIPL—No survey.  Species Management  PIPL—April 01, establish full recreational closure in active, historic, and potential new habitat as determined by a qualified staff biologist.  Enlarge protected areas where PIPL observed prospecting for territories outside of full recreational closure area (same as alternative A). If birds do not use site, open by July 15. CWB—April 01, establish full recreational closure in active CWB nesting areas. Establish ORV closures in historic least tern and black skimmer nesting areas and any potential new habitat where, from site inspection, a qualified staff biologist determines that nesting may be likely to occur.  Closures would be expanded as necessary when nests or nest scrapes are found in new areas.  Bird—Courtship/ Mating*  Species Survey  PIPL—Survey, 7 days per week NCB and SCB and other areas at least 1 day per week, locations where territorial, courtship, and/or mating behavior observed. Monitoring will include descriptions of the management measures in place and human activity observed in the areas where courting behavior occurred.  AMOY—Survey number (pair/single), behavior, courtship, and evidence of scrapes. CWB— Record territorial/mating behavior if observed during PIPL surveys. WIPL—No monitoring.  Species Management  PIPL—Expand full recreational closures to provide for a 150-foot buffer in areas of territorial, courtship, and/or mating (scrapes) behavior occurring outside existing closures. AMOY—No closures. WIPL—Post WIPL nests or scrapes found outside existing closures on NCB and SCB.  Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Bird—Nesting*  Species Survey  PIPL—Survey nests 7 days per week on NCB and SCB. Survey nests at least one day per week if they occur elsewhere.  Record (1) date & time; (2) nest number; (3) nest location with a GPS unit (1 time). Nest markers should not be placed in the sand; (4) number of eggs (if bird is not flushed, record that the bird was incubating and number of eggs was not observed); (5) habitat; (6) status of nest (laying, incubating, lost, abandoned, hatching, hatched); (7) presence and behavior of the adults [incubating eggs, shading eggs, resting, foraging, disturbed (record source), territorial flight, territorial encounter, distraction display or other defensive behavior toward predator or pedestrian, courtship, other behavior (describe)]; (8) presence of potential predators, humans, pets, or ORVs within 300 feet and locations relative to the nest; (9) evidence (i.e., trails) and number of potential predators, humans, pets, or ORVs within posted areas, including distance to the nest; and (10) suspected cause of nest loss, if apparent. Other specific data will include number of observations of plovers performing territorial defense or courtship displays outside symbolic fencing; and, making nest scrapes outside the symbolic fencing. Data will include a description of the management measures in place where these behaviors are observed. After incubation starts, observe incubating bird with optical equipment from appropriate distance that does not disturb the birds. AMOY—Survey nests every 2 days on NCB and SCB, other areas 1 day per week. Record (1) nest locations with GPS and mile marker locations; (2) number of eggs present and hatch date; (3) presence or evidence of predators, including trails within 30 feet of the nest; and (4) human, or ORV tracks within 90 feet of a nest. CWB—Survey nests at least once every 2 days on NCB and SCB and 1 day per week elsewhere when PIPL monitoring occurs. Record center of colony using GPS. Record same information as PIPL except regular counts of CWB are not performed and productivity information is not recorded. WIPL—Census WIPL during annual PIPL window census (1st week of June).  Species Management  PIPL—Expand full recreational closures to provide for a 150-foot buffer around nests. Place predator exclosures over nest after 4th egg is laid if conditions allow. Areas remain closed until chicks fledge or are lost. Any nest that appears to be at risk, reported to park biologist from field when possible. AMOY—Mark nest in an unobtrusive manner and establish a 10 square foot full recreational closure around the nest if nest in area subject to ORV or pedestrian traffic. Generally, nests found in the dunes are not posted because there is concern that predators might learn to associate posts with nests. Areas remain closed until chicks fledge or are lost, typically August 15.  CWB—Expand full recreational closure to provide for a 150-foot buffer from all nests. WIPL—Post WIPL nests or scrapes found outside existing closures on NCB and SCB.  Appendix A: Cape LookoutInterimProtected Species Management Plan /EnvironmentalAssessment Modified PreferredAlternative Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Bird—Unfledged Chicks*  Species Survey  PIPL—Survey brood 7 days per week on NCB and SCB; at least once per week elsewhere. Record (1) date & time; (2) nest/brood number; (3) location of brood; (4) number of chicks; (5) brood age (this is known from other data on hatch date); (6) brood behavior [foraging, resting/brooding, disturbed (record source), other]; (7) presence and behavior of adults [foraging, brooding, resting, disturbed (record source), territorial flight, territorial encounter, distraction display or other defensive behavior toward predator or pedestrian, courtship, other behavior (describe)]; (8) presence or evidence of potential predators, humans, or ORVs within 300 feet and location relative to the brood including tracks within closures; (9) cause of chick loss, if carcass found and source of mortality apparent. Includes data on the interaction between people and plovers, including instances where vehicles, pedestrians, or pets are observed within the symbolic fencing and the type of response exhibited by the plovers. AMOY—Survey brood at least once every 2 days on NCB and SCB. Surveys cease when all chicks have fledged or are lost. CWB—Survey brood at least once every 2 days when PIPL monitoring occurs. Surveys cease when all chicks have fledged or are lost. WIPL—No survey.  Species Management  PIPL—After nest hatches, when a chick is found using the ocean beach, expand buffer to include a 600-foot ORV closure around each brood. ORV routed to backroad or, if no road, park would consider an escort. An escort program may be used on a case-by-case basis to maintain access to Portsmouth Village or areas with no backroad access if staffing allows. Establish a 2-mile ORV closure at north end of SCB from first nest hatch until last chick has fledged or is lost. Increase enforcement of public compliance with closures. Closures removed when last chick is fledged or is lost. AMOY—Establish ramp-to-ramp ORV closures if chicks present on the beach (route ORV traffic to backroad via designated ramps) unless no backroad is present, then ORV would be allowed at 15 mph, with signs warning operators of flightless chicks in the area. Adjust ORV closures based on chick movement, providing a minimum 300-foot buffer around brood. Closures would move with chicks. Closed areas reopened to ORV after last chick has fledged or is lost. CWB—Establish ORV closure that provides at least a 150-foot buffer around broods when chicks present at Cape Lookout Point Beach. In other areas, route traffic around ORV closures if chicks are in danger of being run over. WIPL—Post areas with WIPL chick found outside existing closures on NCB and SCB.  Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Bird— Non-breeding (migrating / wintering)  Species Survey  PIPL—Survey entire seashore non-breeding population once per month August 1 to March 31. Coordinate with Cape Hatteras Natl. Seashore to conduct simultaneous surveys or receive  survey data from Portsmouth Island during winter, since, based on past banding data, wintering  birds move across Ocracoke Inlet. Send data on winter birds to NCWRC. Record: (1) date; (2)  weather variables [air temperature, wind speed and direction, visibility, % cloud cover (est. by  eye), precipitation; (3) tidal stage (hours after high tide); (5) number of birds; (5) habitat; (6)  behavior of majority of birds in flock [foraging, resting, disturbed (record source), other]; and (7)  check for band combination of any banded birds, using reporting protocols developed by staff  for band color and location. A log will also be kept that records the date, time, and purpose of  each official trip through areas where unfledged chicks are present. Monitors, law enforcement  personnel, and other Cape Lookout National Seashore staff will record all observations of  violations of dog leashing requirements in plover breeding areas, both inside and outside  posted habitat.   AMOY—No survey of non-breeding individuals.  REKN—Survey in spring and fall on NCB and SCB following International shorebird survey  protocols on frequency and timing.  Species Management  Closures not specifically implemented for wintering/ migrating shorebird protection. Permanent ORV closures at Shackleford Banks, Portsmouth Flats, the interior of Cape Lookout Point, beach between mile markers 41A and 41B, and Power Squadron Spit are maintained.  Appendix A: Cape LookoutInterimProtected Species Management Plan /EnvironmentalAssessment Modified PreferredAlternative Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Sea Turtles  Species Survey  May 01–September 15 survey for crawls/nests before 12:00 PM daily on SCB and NCB; Shackleford Banks 2-3 days per week; Middle Core Banks monitored irregularly (difficult access). Monitoring procedures and data collection follow the monitoring and reporting guidelines in the Handbook for Sea Turtle Volunteers in North Carolina (NCWRC 2002) and the USFWS Index Nesting Beach Survey Protocol. Periodic monitoring (e.g. every two or three days) for unknown nesting and emerging hatchlings will continue, especially in areas that are not surveyed regularly or that receive high visitor use, through November 15. Monitoring will also occur for post-hatchling washbacks during periods where there are large quantities of seaweed washed ashore or following severe storm events.  Before May 1, park staff conduct PIPL monitoring and, if possible, note any turtle crawls/nests. Record (1) date & time; (2) species, if known; (3) whether it is a false or nesting crawl; (4) sequential nest number; (5) whether nest was relocated, original and relocation site names, and coordinates of original and relocation sites in Lat/Long; (6) distance from nest to tideline, in meters; (7) date when nest excavation conducted; (8) date(s) of nest overwash; (9) sources of egg or whole nest loss, if apparent; and (9) geographic coordinates of false crawls when first found. Monitor the effects of management actions on nesting, hatching, and stranded sea turtles on beaches within park boundaries. Conduct a nest excavation inventory to determine nest success after hatching.  Species Management  Nest Protection: Each located nest is immediately marked with stakes. 50 days after nest laid, funnel shaped ORV closure established from nest to 15 feet below high tide line. ORV closure is 30 feet wide at nest; 60 feet wide below high tide line, with minimum 10-foot buffer duneward of nest. If 10-foot minimum buffer is not possible, ramp-to-ramp ORV closure is established (vehicles routed around nest via backroad). ORV closure removed after nest hatches. Nest Relocation: Relocate nests laid at or below high tide line or in areas where they are likely to be washed away or are in danger of erosion. According to USFWS recommendations. 3 nest relocation areas (up to 1 mile in length) are designated on SCB and NCB where ORV traffic is prohibited beginning 50 days after first nest relocated to area. Nests are relocated to the nearest designated area. No ORVs are allowed on Shackleford Banks, so nests are relocated to the nearest suitable habitat. Nests are relocated within 12 hrs after eggs laid or 14 days after the nest was laid. Nest Excavations: Nest excavated 5th day after a major hatch (indicated by distinctive hatchling tracks), 10 days after depression forms, or 75 days after nest was laid if no sign of hatching. If nest outside of a designated relocation area, the ORV closure would be removed after excavation. Predator Management: Screens or cages used to protect nests and prevent egg loss to raccoons. Light Management: Camping and campfires prohibited in nest relocation areas to prevent disturbance of hatchlings from artificial lights. Park encourages concessionaires and people staying in park cabins to minimize use of outdoor lights. Park will also ensure park users, concessionaires, and contractors are aware of the sea turtle protection measures implemented within the park boundaries.  Nests in locations deemed vulnerable to light pollution, 2 foot high plywood barriers erected behind and to the sides of the nest 10 days before estimated hatch date. Fireworks are prohibited within the seashore. Seashore will coordinate with FWS to develop and implement measures to further minimize beach lighting threats.   Activity  Alternative D: Increased Species Protection Areas, Education, and Outreach (Preferred Alternative)  Seabeach amaranth  Species Survey  June 1 begin monitoring habitat outside existing bird closures 1-2 days per week for seedlings/juvenile plants. Conduct annual survey in late-July or early-August to record plant numbers and distribution and identify areas for ORV closure. Survey habitat but concentrate on where plants have been found before. Surveys conducted in all areas of suitable habitat and results mapped using GIS. Data collected will include number of plants; general distribution of plants; general proportions of seedlings, medium and large plants at the time of the survey; and overall health (signs of stress, damage, disease or herbivory, etc).   Species Management  Establish ORV closure around all emergent plants. Size of closure based on best professional judgment but with at least a minimum 30-foot buffer around plant. Survey bird/turtle closures prior to reopening to ORV traffic, also no tent camping in ORV closure areas. Open closed area at end of growing season.  Note: AMOY–American oystercatcher; CWB–colonial waterbird; NCB–North Core Banks; PIPL–piping plover; REKN– red knot; SCB–South Core Banks; WIPL–Wilson’s Plover. Appendix B: Comment Response Report APPENDIX B: COMMENT RESPONSE REPORT Concept  Quote  Response  PEDESTRIAN-ONLY AREAS  1.  Do not locate pedestrian-only areas in front of the cabin area. This will create congestion and safety issues, as well as create hardships on visitors who will be made to walk further distances.  “New Pedestrian Only Areas in Option C in front of the Cabin Areas at South and North Core Banks makes absolutely no logistical sense. With a one lane road through the cabin area at North Core and South core, the amount of traffic that will be forced to drive through the camp will go up substantially which puts the patrons of the cabins at more risk. It will only take one instance of a small child being struck by the increased traffic this proposed pedestrian only beach creates for the NPS to completely abandon this approach. I fail to see the logic behind this. Currently, most of the traffic on North and South Core passes in front of the cabins to avoid the tight one lane roads and corners.” (384156) “I feel the camp will become the most dangerous place on the island. The number of vehicles coming through will increase threatening those who walk over from ferry to beach.” (384174)  The NPS considered the suggestions related to the pedestrian-only areas in front of the cabins. Commenters raise valid concerns regarding traffic and safety issues. The NPS revised the preferred alternative in the final ORV management plan/EIS to include an ORV corridor at the dune line to pass through these areas to address concerns about public safety in the camps and to reduce interaction with pedestrians. Specifically, at Great Island a corridor would be established from mid-ramp in the Great Island Camp to the north (ramps 29a to 29b). From mid-ramp south, the beach would be open. At Long Point, ramps 16 – 17a would be closed, and the rest of the area would be open. These pass-through areas would be in place May 1 to September 14.  “CREATION OF ADDITIONAL PEDESTRIAN-ONLY AREAS A seasonal driving closure at Great Island will put too much stress on the narrow, winding back road through the cabin area. Many visitors depend on vehicles for transporting family and equipment from the cabins to beach. Banning ORV's from that area is really pedestrian unfriendly since families with small children and/or the elderly will be burdened with long hikes and loaded arms as well as long walks to the shower and rest rooms depending on which cabin they're staying in. In addition, the back road will be very congested and dangerous for pedestrians wanting to visit the dock, ranger station or fish cleaning tables.” (387468) “say no to closing the beach area in front of the cabins. those visitors with physical impairments can't walk in the sand that far. this could cause grounds for suit under the ADA.....also, the cabin area would lose the peaceful  This change would not allow for parking along these routes, but would provide a pass-through and would remove ORV traffic from going through the camps. These bypass areas were added to the preferred alternative to address concerns about public safety in the camps and reduce interaction between ORVs and pedestrians.  In addition, these bypass areas would have less impacts to the barrier island geology by keeping the route established and eliminating the need to move sand. In regards to increasing and improving the number and location of bath facilities, the NPS would explore this option using the fee monies  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  attraction with all the extra vehicle traffic” (393475) “Prohibiting ORV use in front of the cabin area would cause safety issues and is inconsistent with applicable laws, regulations and guidelines. Under Alternative C, NPS has proposed to prohibit ORVs in front of the cabin area. To prohibit ORV s in front of cabin area would cause safety issues due to travel through the cabin area on mostly narrow one lane roads. ORV use at the Seashore is not limited to recreational fishermen. Many visitors to the Seashore rely on ORVs to travel along the Seashore. Cabin renters use ORVs to carry coolers, chairs, toys, fishing equipment, and other gear to the beach area in front of the cabins. Also, ORV users stop in front of the cabin areas to utilize the bath house facilities. Prohibiting ORV use in front of the cabins and declaring this area as a pedestrian-only area will significantly congest ORV movement in and around the cabins roads and bath area. This will create safety problems for all users. Rather than prohibiting ORVs in front of the cabin areas, NPS should increase the number and locations of the bath facilities.” (399716)  generated from the ORV management program. New amenities could be added as fees allow, and may require additional planning before implementation. The modification to allow bypass routes near the camps would keep the south end of Great Island open, and would maintain access to the bath facility.  2.  Do not close the Great Island Camp areas in the fall, but a summer closure is ok. The lighthouse area is recommended for a summer, but not fall, closure.  “Why close the beach in front of Great Island camp in the fall, the camp is full of ORV users. If they want to close it in the summer fine.” (385957) “Another issue is adding more pedestrian only areas around the light house and in front of the cabins. I would be ok with this for the summer only months but during the spring and fall not as many pedestrian only people come to the island. The last time I was there was in May and the area in front of the light house was almost empty every time I went by their. Some great fishing areas have always been on either side of this area.” (395398)  Under the preferred alternative, the Great Island Camp would be closed only from May 1 until September 14 and it would be open in the fall. No further modification is needed for a summer-only closure. In regards to Lighthouse Beach, this is one of the most popular sites for visitors. Based on ferry operation data provided by the ferry operators, visitors access this area during the summer and into the fall. It is anticipated that with the new pedestrian ferry service, there would be more consistent visitation in the fall months. However, in the final ORV management  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  plan/EIS the preferred alternative was revised to address the proposed expanded pedestrian closure in this area. Under the revised preferred alternative, the area 0.7 mile to the south of the lighthouse would only be closed seasonally, from May 1 to September 14. However, existing pedestrian closures (at the lighthouse and Power Squadron Spit), would remain closed year-round to ORVs. This would maintain pedestrian-only access in key areas, while addressing the fact that visitation changes seasonally in the area south of the lighthouse. Existing year-round pedestrian-only closures would remain, since the lighthouse beach is one of the most popularly visited areas, including in the fall, because pedestrian ferries now run year-round.  3.  If you create pedestrian areas, you should open other areas to ORVs.  “If more beach is taken away for pedestrian only traffic then compensate by opening more beach access below the rock jetties and at the North point.” (389676)  The north end of South Core Banks is typically open to ORVs, except for safety reasons or seasonal species protection closures. The ocean beach is closed to vehicles when piping plover chicks are in the area. The Power Squadron Spit area (including the rock jetty area) is a longstanding closure to ORVs to reduce user conflicts with boaters and others using this beach. The NPS believes this user separation is needed, and it will remain in place under the preferred alternative.   4.  There are enough pedestrian-only areas, additional ones are not needed. Off-Road Vehicle users only have location like Long Point and Great Island on Cape Lookout, a small  The enabling legislation created the Seashore “In order to preserve for public use and enjoyment an area in the State of North Carolina possessing outstanding natural and recreational values…” Following this mandate, the Seashore aims to provide for a variety of  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  Shackleford Banks is  percentage of the East Coast.” (399956)  visitor experiences, including ORV and non- available.  “A few visitors request areas where they will not be exposed to ORVs, these requests are positively responded to by maintaining access to the Shackleford Banks which is closed to ORVs.” (399883) “Lastly, over 20% of this park is ORV free -an ENTIRE ISLAND (Shackleford) this should be championed by NPS CALO. These goals are further reflected in the objectives of the ORV management plan/EIS, which reads:   Manage ORV use to allow for a variety of appropriate visitor use experiences.  Minimize conflicts between ORV use and other users. Retain an experience where  typically a family or individual traveling by ORV can experience the Seashore by finding a remote and otherwise unused stretch of beach.  Retain a non-ORV experience that allows access to a beach that is undisturbed by motorized uses. Although some visitors feel that there are currently adequate pedestrian-only areas, other visitors have expressed the desire for more pedestrian-only areas. The NPS has found that the preferred alternative addresses different visitor use desires and meets the stated objectives of the ORV management plan/EIS.  5. Seasonal and year-round pedestrian-only areas provide an opportunity for visitors who desire these types of areas and experiences while still allowing for ORV use on the majority of the Seashore. The visibility at the intersection of the back road and the path between the dock and the camping area is partly obstructed by dunes which exacerbates the safety situation. The visibility of pedestrians on the open beach is much better. ORV users are accustomed to slowing for pedestrians anywhere on the beach and demonstrate courteous and responsible driving there. However, encountering a pedestrian on the back road away from the populated areas is not normal. There is lower safety risk to pedestrians by having the ORV traffic on the beach. The usage of the Codds Creek area by kayakers and other tent  areas to reopen to ORV use when pedestrian use decreases.  At Codds Creek, non-motorized uses have increased in recent years and the NPS believes this closure (which is only in the summer months under the preferred alternative) is appropriate. In addition, this area is part of the sea turtle relocation area and is closed part of the year for relocation efforts; therefore the closure serves two purposes. In regards to concerns that encouraging pedestrian use would result in a need for more infrastructure, NPS will take appropriate management actions to manage pedestrian areas as use increases, including implementing a new planning process if additional infrastructure is added. Areas proposed for closures are heavily used for fishing, and closing these areas would have impacts to these user groups.  “On both North and South Core Banks some of the best fishing is at the inlets. Closing the inlet areas to ORV users would be detrimental to the fishing community and again favoring the pedestrian over the ORV user. If North Core Banks at Ocracoke Inlet were a closed area would visitors be allowed from Ocracoke on ATVs? There has always been room for all kinds of user groups on the seashore, and never has been a problem until the last few years of over regulation. If there are pedestrian only areas they should be just that&.no dogs&.Dog waste is easy enough to see when not picked up, however dogs are peeing all over the place with children playing in it and visitors walking barefoot through it. If visitors truly want no vehicles there is the proposed wilderness area of Shackleford Banks where motorized vehicles are not allowed.” (387553)  Under the preferred alternative, the inlet areas would be open to ORV use by default, unless closed for resource protection or safety concerns. Typically, the majority of species closures take place before the start of the fall fishing season, thus leaving open the majority of the Seashore for access to fishing, including the inlets. See response #4 for additional information regarding the balance the Seashore seeks to achieve between ORV areas and pedestrian-only areas.  9.  Studies about potential use should be done before pedestrian areas are created.  “There needs to be study put forth to decide how many people would use such an area before it's designated.” (399367)  The Seashore is committed to providing a variety of appropriate visitor uses and provides for these uses by establishing ORV routes and pedestrian areas (see response #4). NPS used the best available information and professional judgment in determining which areas would be established for pedestrian-only and ORV use areas. Usage data included  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  information provided by the ferry operators. This information provides an indication of when and where pedestrians and ORV users are accessing the Seashore. Information sources for visitor use levels and patterns can be found in the reference section of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, including, but not limited to, the following references: NPS 2010i, NPS 2010j, NPS 2011j, NPS 2012l, NPS 2012s, NPS 2013c, NPS 2013f, NPS 2013g, and NPS 2014b, 2015a, 2015j, 2016a.  10.  The lighthouse should be open for visitors to access it in the fall, especially during times of tournaments.  “NPS closes the lighthouse at the height of fishing season in the fall when numerous ORV users are on the island. A fishing tournament is held in mid-October, and there will be over 400 fishermen on the island. During this time, the lighthouse is closed. Many of the ORV people have never been able to climb the lighthouse; this is a slap in the face for all of these ORV islanders who have picked up trash and volunteered with repairs to buildings and boardwalks for the park service. Please consider keeping the lighthouse open on the weekends until at least November 15 or until Thanksgiving.” (387788)  The hours of operation of the lighthouse are outside the scope of this ORV management plan/EIS.  11.  Vehicles should be allowed to pass through pedestrian areas in a specified corridor at low speed. Alternatively, a pedestrian overpass could be established on the beach in front of the cabins.  “Continue to allow ORV's to travel through, but not stop in pedestrian areas. B. Enforce a slow speed zone of 5mph or less in pedestrian areas. C. In regards to pedestrian access in the cabin area, see response #1.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  “A better proposal would be to provide a width of beach above the high tide line, of sufficient width to allow two-way traffic (at slow speed), and construct a pedestrian overpass to allow access to the beach from the cabin area. In that way, the NPS could still provide a pedestrian only area in front of the cabins (which is the only realistic destination for most pedestrians arriving at the vehicle ferry docks) and provide safe passage for ORVs along the beach.” (390878)  12.  The vehicle-free areas in front of Power Squadron Spit should be expanded to provide more nesting habitat.  “Point of Cape Lookout-Power Squadron Spit: NPS should expand the Power Squadron Spit vehicle-free, pedestrian-only area to include the beachfront from ramp 42b to ramp 46, with access available along the back route. This beachfront area is designated piping plover critical habitat and is inappropriate for ORV use. DEIS at 177.” (399255) “The point of Cape Lookout has also been documented as an important nesting site for colonial waterbirds. The ocean intertidal and backshore regions are essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds, breeding oystercatchers, and sea turtles, as well as piping plovers and colonial waterbirds where habitat is suitable. See DEIS at 224.” (399255)  The backshore region that the commenter requested to be closed is currently closed on the soundside and was included in the range of alternatives and analysis in the draft ORV management plan/EIS. In reference to the comment that the closure at the Point of Cape Lookout-Power Squadron Spit should be expanded to include the area of beach front from 42b to 46, there is no historical evidence of species nesting in this area, and it is shown as wintering habitat, not nesting habitat by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS). The NPS monitors all areas of the Seashore and should nesting start be observed in this area, species closures would be implemented per species management policies. Therefore, a proactive closure when there is no known history of nesting is not warranted.   13.  Make the closure at New Drum Inlet year-round, rather than just during the summer.  “New Drum Inlet-Ophelia Inlet: As explained above, the errata pages on the NPS website show that the beach from New Drum Inlet to Ophelia Inlet is a "Seasonal Summer Closure" but "only when Middle Core Banks is connected to North Core Banks." We recommend that this area be designated as pedestrian-only all of the time, and not just in the summer or when Middle Core Banks is connected. The ocean intertidal, backshore region, and inlet spits in this area  In the preferred alternative, Middle Core Banks would be open to ORV use if it is connected to North Core Banks, but nesting closures would continue to be implemented when necessary. This would alleviate concerns about habitat – although the critical habitat referred to by the commenter is not nesting habitat. As in all cases, and especially during nesting and  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  are essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds, breeding oystercatchers, and sea turtles, as well as piping plovers and colonial waterbirds where habitat is suitable.” (399254) “Ophelia Inlet-South Core Banks: NPS should create a vehicle-free, pedestrian-only area from March 1 to December 1 that includes the northern tip of South Core Banks and extends along the beachfront to ramp 24, and it should allow back-route-only ORV use from ramp 24 to ramp 31 and from ramp 33 to ramp 39 (thereby allowing ORV use of the ocean-facing beaches from ramps 31-33 and ramps 39-42b). These proposed vehicle-free areas are piping plover critical habitat and have had at least 10 breeding pairs of piping plovers the last three years and as many as 20 breeding pairs over the last decade. See DEIS at 176177, 180. Ophelia Inlet has also been documented as an important nesting site for colonial waterbirds. The ocean intertidal and backshore regions are essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds, breeding oystercatchers, and sea turtles, as well as piping plovers and colonial waterbirds where habitat is suitable. See DEIS at 224.” (399254)  breeding seasons, the NPS monitors all areas of the Seashore. Areas not connected to North or South Core Banks do have established species protection buffers. Should nesting start in this area once reconnected, these species closures would continue and additional buffers would be implemented as necessary, according to species management policies. Middle Core Banks is a year-round pedestrian area when not connected to North Core Banks.  As stated in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, “In the event that an island is severed from another island (due to storms, flooding, etc.), the island would allow ORV use only if there is a ferry landing location on that island. If the island does not contain a ferry landing, then ORV use would be prohibited. For example, as of January 2013, Middle Core Banks is severed from ferry service and is closed to ORV use; the island and its portion of the back route would become accessible to ORV use if Old Drum Inlet closes and Middle Core Banks becomes accessible to vehicles (i.e., if Middle Core Banks reconnects to an island that has ferry service).”  In regards to the protection of wintering shorebirds, the Seashore currently provides three months of the year that are ORV-free. The entire Seashore is a vehicle-free area during that time. Under the preferred alternative, the existing wintering closure would be further extended two weeks. Certain areas, such as the soundside of North Core Banks and South Core Banks, are vehicle-free year-round and provide additional shorebird habitat. In those areas where ORVs are permitted, wintering shorebirds  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  would be able to take advantage of pre-nesting and nesting closures during times when wintering shorebird activity overlaps with breeding bird activity. In addition, during times when ORVs are allowed, use levels are at relatively low levels, and the proposed permit system would ensure that these low levels continue and would not necessitate the need for additional closures to address wintering shorebirds.  The areas from ramp 24 to 31 and ramp 33 to 39 are not designated as critical habitat.   14.  Expand and make year-round the proposed vehicle-free area at Ocracoke Inlet/Portsmouth Flats and Portsmouth Beach-New Drum Inlet for breeding bird protection.  “Ocracoke Inlet-Portsmouth Flats: The proposed vehicle-free pedestrian-only area at Ocracoke Inlet and Portsmouth Beach in the vicinity of mile-marker 1 should last year-round (to protect both breeding and non-breeding shorebirds) and should be extended southward to Ramp 4a. This expansion would protect important wildlife habitat while having minimal impact on visitor use. Between 2009 and 2011, this area produced 3 7 piping plover chicks, indicating its historic importance and significant potential as nesting habitat. The ocean intertidal and backshore regions are essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds, breeding oystercatchers, and sea turtles, as well as piping plovers and colonial waterbirds where habitat is suitable. See DEIS at 224. Providing these protections should not diminish visitor use. Park visitors are able to reach the north end by private ferry from Ocracoke Island and the south end of this area by ORV along the back route, and can walk to the areas in between or reach them directly by boat. Portsmouth Beach-New Drum Inlet: From Ramp 4a to New Drum Inlet, NPS should allow ORV use only on the back route and not on the ocean-facing beaches from March 1 to December 1. The ocean intertidal zone and backshore should be pedestrian-only in this area because it is piping plover critical habitat and has had at least 10 breeding pairs of piping plovers in the last three years. DEIS  While not a year-round closure, the area noted by the commenter would be monitored and closed if piping plover activities were noted outside of the seasonal closure time.  As noted in table 4 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, full recreational closures are established in active, historic, and potential new habitat for piping plover as determined by a qualified staff biologist. In addition, pre-nesting surveys are conducted to address activities outside closure areas. Additional closures are enacted for courtship, mating, and nesting behavior. When piping plover chicks are found on the ocean beach, the beach is closed to vehicles. All of these species management activities provide the necessary level of protection for piping plovers.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  at 176, 180. New Drum Inlet has also been documented as an important nesting site for colonial waterbirds. The ocean intertidal and backshore regions are essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds, breeding oystercatchers, and sea turtles, as well as piping plovers and colonial waterbirds where habitat is suitable.” (399253)  15.  Allow vehicles to park near the boardwalk at the lighthouse.  “Why are Vehicles no longer allowed to park near the boardwalk at the Lighthouse? Parking there would enable us to walk to the Lighthouse or beach or to use the restroom located there. We feel this discriminates ORV users.” (387892)  Vehicle parking is provided at the boardwalk. Short-term parking is provided in this area to allow for access. Additional short-term parking is also provided adjacent to the long-term parking area, for accessing the lighthouse. With these existing parking areas, additional parking in this area is not necessary.  16.  The pedestrian area from ramp 41a to 41b should not be expanded. If implemented, this closure should only be in the summer. Instead of a closure, lower the speed limit on adjacent beaches and add signs.   “I recommend this section of beach not be closed to ORV use during all seasons. If there is any consideration for closing this beach, it should only be during the summer season. I recommend instead of closing the beach to ORV use, the park service should take the following actions: Impose a summer season 15 mph speed limit on the beaches adjacent to the existing pedestrian-only beach (south from ramp 41b to ramp 42a and also north from ramp 40 to ramp 41a). Add a Yield to Pedestrians sign on the back road at the boardwalk.” (385531)  While a lower speed limit and signage may be a means to mitigate the potential visitor use conflicts, these conflicts are not the only reason for establishing pedestrian-only areas. The Seashore is committed to providing a variety of visitor experiences, including ORV and non-ORV experiences.  ATV/UTV REQUIREMENTS/BANS  17.  ATV restrictions are not warranted based on scientific evidence and will reduce visitation. Some commenters stated  “ATV and Utv grace period will drastically reduce the visitors because of the affordability of the atv/Utv and convenience of them” (384183). “Problem with Alt. C Limits on use of ATV's and UTV's to September 15th through 8 December 15th Recommended  The NPS has further reviewed the research and consulted with experts in the field. Although the research regarding the impacts to species from ATV/UTV use reaches various conclusions, studies do conclude that UTV use and pedestrians create approximately the same  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  that this prohibition was arbitrary and capricious. If ATV/UTVs have head lights and tail lights they should be permitted. Impacts of a ban would include loss of an important visitor experience, more commercial ATV use, negative impact on users with mobility issues, and impacts on summer-only users through a seasonal ban.  Changes No limitation on ATV and UTV use at any time of year on the Seashore, especially seasonal limitation on UTV use. Rationale behind Change ATV's and UTV's are a popular form of transportation for fishermen on the Seashore. Many visitors, including myself, prefer this type transportation on the Seashore. Fuel efficiency, mobility and more freedom in making ferry reservations are a huge plus for me and my other visitors. Many people have purchased A TV's and UTV's for the sole purpose of using for transportation at Cape Lookout to fishing and beach tent camping spots. UTV's in particular are excellent for family visits to the Seashore when you have younger children because they can often be placed on the ferry without reservations made months in advance. This allows families to make trips to the Seashore after weather reports indicate good weather conducive to allowing smaller children to enjoy their camping visit. By eliminating spring and summer use of UTV's, this limits visits families can take using a UTV with school age children. This change would virtually eliminate the chance my son, and many other school age children, would have to visit the Seashore. This is very sad and troubling to me! A TV's and UTV's must abide by the same speed limits and beach closures as other vehicles, therefore no argument can be made that their increased speed is more disturbing to nesting birds than other vehicles. Also, if unmodified, most are no louder than other vehicles on the beach.” (399925) “ATV AND UTV BAN: Here again we have no sufficient data to show just cause for the removal of these vehicles. I would state the operator and not the machine maybe responsible for any wrong produced by these vehicles. If this is the case punish the offender, not the equipment. Many of the visitors to the park own this type of equipment.” (399941) “NPS's proposed prohibitions on ATVs/UTVs are arbitrary and capricious. Under Alternative C, non-sport A TV s/UTV s would be allowed from September 15 through December 15 within the Seashore; all high-performance sport-model and  level of disturbance, a level of disturbance similar to general ORV use. ATV use showed disturbance, but was not shown to lower productivity. Based on this research, the NPS has revised the ORV management plan/EIS to remove an ATV/UTV seasonal ban. However, based on best professional judgment of Seashore staff and their experience regarding a higher likelihood of sport-model ATV/UTV riders entering restricted areas—including dunes— sport-model ATVs/UTVs will still be banned after a one-year grace period. As part of the adaptive management strategy, the Seashore will monitor the impacts of ATVs and UTVs on species productivity, and if impacts greater than those of other uses are found, the NPS could revisit the banning of these vehicles at a later date.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  two-stroke ATVs/UTVs would be prohibited after a five-year grace period. NPS has failed to justify these prohibitions, and the Coalition strongly objects to these provisions. There are presently laws in effect that govern the safe and efficient use of all ORVs at the Seashore. If an operator violates these laws, NPS staff may issue that operator a citation. The solution is not to entirely prohibit use of these ATV s/UTV s at the Seashore. Such a prohibition is overbroad and unnecessary. NPS also claims that high-performance ATVs are generally faster, noisier and less safe than utility models. NPS, however, provides no evidence that these types of A TV s have been involved in more accidents at the Seashore or have resulted in a greater frequency of safety citations. NPS further claims that "continued ATV/UTV use may negatively impact visitors who seek a quiet environment at the Seashore, because these vehicles introduce man-made noise at the Seashore. NPS data, however, indicate that only 13% of ORVs arriving on ferries are ATVs/UTVs. Draft ORV Plan, p. 461. However, "the specific number of high-performance sport-model and two-stroke ATVs being used at the Seashore is not known, therefore, it is not possible to determine the extent of which motorized intrusions on natural landscapes would be reduced relative to existing conditions as a result of [prohibiting these types of ATVs]." Draft ORV Plan, p. 468. Further, studies relied upon by NPS do not differentiate between different types of ATVs or UTVs. Draft ORV Plan, p. 289, 468. Finally, NPS's own noise study does not support this position. "[T]he majority of ORV activity occurs on the beach side of the islands where surf and wind sounds are prominent. . . . Overall, soundscape quality remains high and consistent with the character of the Seashore." Draft ORV Plan, p. 477. "Considering these facts and low level of ORV use under alternatives A, B, C, and D, none of these alternatives would result in significant adverse impacts to natural landscapes." Draft ORV Plan, 477.” (399711) “Finally, not only does NPS fail to justify prohibiting ATVs/UTVs and high-performance ATVs/UTVs, this  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  prohibition has the potential to result in no change in the number of ATVs/UTVs at the Seashore. As acknowledged by NPS, "the prohibition of ATVs at the Seashore could result in increased business for commercial A TV providers, which would not be prohibited." Draft ORV Plan, p. 516. The Coalition strongly objects to the proposed prohibitions of ATVs/UTVs during the spring and summer and high-performance sport-model and two-stroke ATVs/UTVs. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification for these prohibitions, and these provisions are arbitrary and capricious.” (399713) “Banning ATV's and UTV's in the Park until September makes no sense and is very unfair to families and groups that can only visit the Park during the summer months due to school and work vacations. C-14 Banning ATVs & UTV at all is discouraging to visitors. As long as they follow the rules why are you banning them? All should be welcome!” (399645) “I had foot reconstruction in 2010 that fixed 36 broken bones in my right foot and 37 in my left. Although I am now able to get around pretty well on flat land, sand is a nearly impossible feat for my not as flexible ankles and feet. If banning ATVs is to happen, I will no longer be able to enjoy Cape Lookout, the lighthouse, the great fishing and shelling, for it will be impossible to travel the island. Certain types of ATVs/UTVs (and trucks) should be banned such as high performance sport models or those that do not have proper mufflers. DEIS at 47. As the DEIS documents, ATVs and UTVs "impact[] shorebirds to a greater extent than other types of ORVs." DEIS at 289,279. For this reason, A TV IUTV use should be prohibited entirely. However, the ban would continue on sport-model ATVs/UTVs after a one-year grace period. All vehicles, including ATVs/UTVs, must have appropriate mufflers under NPS regulations. If impacts related to soundscapes occur, they will be addressed by future management actions. See response #17 for further details.  20. Phase out high-performance ATVs, but allow other ATVs/UTVs to continue operating. ATV use from the Ocracoke side should not be allowed when the beach is closed to vehicles driving to the north end of the island.  “High performance ATVs can be phased out over the next 5 years, but responsible use of standard ATV/UTVs should continue. Also, ATV use from the Ocracoke side should not be allowed when the beach is closed to vehicles driving to the north end of the island. This appears to be blatant favoritism, and is another way that ORV users are discriminated against & many visitors can only come once a year and enjoy bringing their ATV/UTV. To single them out would be more discrimination.” (387555)  The NPS has re-evaluated the scientific studies related to ATV/UTV use and has revised the ORV management plan/EIS to remove the ATV/UTV ban. However, the ban would continue on sport-model ATVs/UTVs after a one-year grace period. See response #17 for further details. Note that areas closed to ORV use would apply to all private and commercial vehicles.  ORV PERMITS – GENERAL  22.  If permits are required they should be honored at all national parks or users should be able to use the pass that is good at all national parks.  “If permits are required they should be good at all National Parks.” (399937) “I see no rational reason to require me to pay for that privilege. If an access fee becomes necessary, then charge it to all, not just ORV users. CONSIDER USING THE COMMON ACCESS PASS USED BY MANY NATIONAL PARKS ACROSS THE US.” (398233)  The proposed ORV permit fee is a special use fee collected under a special use permit, not a park entrance fee (which is not required at Cape Lookout National Seashore). As a special use permit, cost recovery is different than a general park entrance fee, and is addressed by Director’s Order 53: Special Park Uses. As a special use permit, costs of managing the special use can be recovered and stay in the park where the activity occurs.  23.  The need for ORV permits has not been justified.  “The Coalition strongly objects to permit limits, fees and the duration of the permits, which would significantly limit access the Seashore. NPS has failed to provide any rationale  The overall purpose of the draft ORV management plan/EIS “is to evaluate whether or not to allow ORV use. If ORV use is allowed, this ORV management plan/EIS will address  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  justification to support its proposed permit system.” (399694) “PERMITS We do not need a permit system. If the proposed permit system it is to count the visitors, those numbers are already generated in the form of visitor centers, ferries, etc. The only place you do not count visitors is when they arrive by private boat and this number is a very small percentage of the total visitors. In fact, if you decide you need those numbers, just study those who arrive by private boat, decide what percentage of the total visitors these represent and add to the registered visitors.” (398815)  how to manage that use in compliance with the Seashore’s enabling legislation, executive orders, NPS management policies, and other laws and regulations to ensure protection of the natural, cultural, and recreational values of the Seashore’s dynamic coastal barrier island environment for present and future generations.” Implementation of a special use permit system meets this purpose. The permit system would allow the Seashore to sustainably manage ORVs and recover costs associated with ORV management. The special use permit system will meet all stated laws and policies, while ensuring protection of the Seashore resources. Permits also provide a mechanism for enforcement - another objective of this plan, as habitual violators can have their permits revoked.  24.  ATVs coming from Ocracoke should be required to have vehicle permits.  “The ATV's that come from Ocracoke should also be required to have vehicle permits.” (398891) “The visitors that come from Ocracoke to ride rental ATV's should also be required to obtain driver certificates. The ATV's that come from Ocracoke need to be required to have vehicle permits at a reasonable fee. ” (387910)  People holding a commercial use authorization (CUA) issued by the superintendent would not be required to obtain a separate ORV permit for the operation of a vehicle. ATVs from Ocracoke operate under this commercial use authorization authority. However, commercial operators will be required to obtain the educational permit and comply with ORV regulations, including route designations, closures, and vehicle requirements.  25.  Tie permits to individuals and not vehicles or allow them to be transferrable.  “The permit should be tied to an individual and not a vehicle since some have two vehicles they alternate in using and also in the event of vehicle replacement due to breakdown.” (398770)  The Seashore agrees with commenters that there should be a process in place for a limited number of vehicle transfers per permit holder. The details for this process will be further developed as the permitting program is  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  Establish a process  “I think the yearly permit should be transferable to all  developed.   for transferring the  vehicles registered to the buyer. Vehicles break down and  permit if you buy a  accidents happen. Some folks are lucky enough to have 2  In regards to permitting the person, rather than  new vehicle.  fishing buggies.” (398720) “Also some provision should be made for one-time transfer of the annual vehicle permit when the owner replaces the vehicle without requiring the full fee to be paid again. A reasonable fee for transfer would be appreciated.” (397688)  the vehicle, the NPS believes that permitting the vehicle is more time efficient and less costly for both the NPS and the user. For the user, if a family or a group were visiting and all visitors were driving the ORV, each member would need to be permitted. Having only the vehicle permitted allows for one permit for that group or family, and would require less money and time to obtain (although each driver would still need an educational certificate). For the Seashore, having a vehicle permit sticker on the vehicle would assist with enforcement, and would not require Seashore staff to ask individual visitors for their permit. In chapter 2, the section “Action Alternatives” states that the goal of the permit systems is to “ensure the permit system is simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage.” The NPS believes that permitting the vehicle rather than the user best meets these goals.  26.  What happens to permits that users are not able to use for various reasons?  “What happens if a permit holder becomes ill and can't go to the island? What happens if you buy a permit but can't get reservations for the time you are able to visit or vice-verse?” (398770)  In general, permits would be non-refundable once purchased.  The NPS does understand and appreciate the logistics that can go into planning a visit to the Seashore. As the permit system is developed, the NPS will develop guidance on the issuance of refunds. As stated in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the goal of this program is to ensure the permit system is simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage, and taking into  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  consideration the logistics of trip planning will be part of that process.   27.  Are ATVs and UTVs subject to a permit fee?  “It is not clear in the proposal whether ATVs and UTVs would be subject to the vehicle permit fees.” (387570)  All ORVs, including non-sport ATVs and UTVs, will be subject to a special use permit fee.  ORV PERMITS – PERMIT LENGTH  28.  If users do not use all of the allotted permit days, those days will be wasted.  “Additionally 3-4 days of the primitive living is all some desire, if a 10 day permit is issued I consider the remaining 6-7 days wasted. Lets not forget the potential for additional revenue from permitting and visitor fees (480,000 visitors@ five dollars equates to two million four hundred thousand dollars, 4,157 ORV permits, even at a one- time permit would generate forty one thousand dollars plus), even more if the percentage of visitors purchased annual permits).” (400089)  Permits will be issued for consecutive days. Any days not used will not be transferrable to another time. Administering the permit program in this fashion will allow the NPS to keep the costs to the users down by simplifying permit administration. It also will meet the Seashore’s goal of making the permit system simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage.  29.  The permit system should be modified to include different permit lengths, allowing for nonconsecutive days, to better reflect visitation patterns, and to line up with camping restrictions. Permits should include a one-day grace period.   “There should be a 3 day, 7 day, 14 day and yearly permits.” (399835) “Pg xi. Vehicle Permits& Under the proposed system, there is no inducement for an infrequent visitor (ORV operator or not), ie, or one week in the Spring and one week in the fall, (for example) to purchase short term permits under the proposed fee structure. The total end cost would exceed the cost of a long term permit. $80.00 $80.00 = $160.00 versus $150.00 for a long term permit.” (399899) “Pg ix. Vehicle Permits& The should term vehicle permit should be valid for 14 days. This would bring it into line with the 14 day limit on overnight camping.” (399898)  The 10-day permit proposed in the draft ORV management plan/EIS was for the purpose of capturing those visitors who come for a week and stay over the weekend before and after. Many suggestions were made by commenters suggesting alternate permit lengths. After consideration of these comments, the Seashore has modified the permit lengths to allow for a 3day permit, a 14-day permit, and a seasonal permit. Per commenters’ suggestions, the 3-day permit provides for shorter time for the one-time weekend visitor. The 14-day permit corresponds to the 14-day limitation for camping on the Seashore.   The short-term permit does not provide the  “My normal trip involves catching a returning ferry boat at 8 AM or 10 AM. This is typical of most cabin dwellers, due to  The NPS agrees with commenters that this revised structure will provide additional flexibility  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  user any inducement to purchase it.  the 11 AM cabin check out time. So the last day of my visit I only drive one short trip from my cabin to the ferry boat dock, but it appears that we would need a vehicle permit for that day. I recommend the permits allow a one-day grace period to travel to the ferry boat dock with a vehicle permit that expired the previous day.” (398503) “A year pass for those that come multiple times a year. A week only consecutive permit and a multiple trip 10 day permit that allows use for multiple trips that equal 10 days” (395399) “I have more concerns about the proposed 10-day permit for $80. I assume the 10-days means 10 consecutive days and that "day" means the calendar day from midnight to midnight. I know a lot of people, but I don't know anybody the goes to the island for 10 consecutive days. It seems like such an abstract and meaningless number. The ORV plan on page 505 states "the upper bound estimate for the average trip length is seven days". I know some people that go for as few as 3 nights. I know a lot of people that go for 4, 5 or 6 nights.” (398501)  for Seashore visitors. While the NPS has chosen not to include a grace period with the permits, the revised permit lengths should provide the added flexibility requested by the commenter. These permits are based on cost recovery, and the Seashore has initially estimated that permits will cost $25 for the 3-day permit, $80 for the 14-day permit, and $120 for the annual permit. The permit fee and structure will adapt based on lessons learned as the program is implemented.  30.  Permits should be valid for longer than a year. A suggestion included 3 years.  “My North Carolina driver's license is valid for a six-year period of time. Why should the driving permit be issued for one year only? This will be time consuming for the NPS and will increase their administrative costs while yielding no economic benefit.” (399861) “Permits should be good for 3 years before renewal.” (398873)  Permits would be issued annually to allow the greatest opportunity to the most people for accessing the park. A multiple year permit, such as a 3-year permit, could allow one group access for three years, while limiting others.  31.  Require an annual permit for long-term vehicle storage.  “Annual permits for long term storage of vehicle required” (392164)  To store a vehicle on the island does require a parking permit. Parking permits would be issued on a monthly basis. Limited spots would be available for vehicles left for no more than 24 hours.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  ORV PERMITS – FEES  32.  Pedestrians should also have to pay a fee. Charge all users a fee instead of an ORV fee. Require boaters to pay a fee. Ferry services should have to pay a fee.  “Pedestrians should pay something, as the majority of infrastructure and maintenance costs are for their benefit.” (399990) “Problem with Alt. C Recommended Changes The cost associated with Alternative C is placed solely on ORV users. The $454,500 increased cost for Alternative C (projected by the National Park Service) is placed on ORV users only. Many of the actions proposed in Alternative C are for the benefit of non-ORV visitors, thus they should share in the cost of the implementation of the Alternative as well. Rationale behind Change Shelters, trash collection, resource protection, interpretation and education, pedestrian facilities and maintenance, and predator control are costs that are not able to be attributed to ORV use alone. Other Seashore visitors should share in the increased cost of implementing Alternative C.” (399916) “My questions about park fees bring up the issue of day trippers and boats from Ocrocake. Will they also be required to buy some sort of permit or do they get free access because they don't have to ride ferry. On many a summer day in particular 4th of July go around north point toward Ocrocake and see 20 boats anchored. Do they have to pay a fee and if so where and who will monitor fees paid. Yes day trippers have to pay a guide fee (will guide also have to pay) but campers pay a ferry fee.” (398710) “Why not have a $5.00 a day fee for ALL VISITORS to the seashore (which would certainly bring in a lot more $$ for park service necessities (enforcement, bird and turtle monitoring, etc.) $5.00 X 500,000 yearly visitors (which seems very inflated) is a whole lot more in your coffers than the proposed user fee for a permit would bring in.” (387547)  Pursuant to NPS policy, regulations, and executive orders, ORVs are only allowed upon promulgation of a special regulation allowing their use, if impacts can be minimized, among other criteria. The ORV management plan/EIS evaluates whether to allow ORVs, and if allowed, how to manage them. In order for the Seashore to certify that ORVs can be managed in a way that meets legal requirements, particularly in a way that impacts can be minimized, a permit system has been established to manage this special use. Evaluating educational certificates for other user groups is outside the scope of this planning effort.  There is no similar regulation, policy, or executive order specifically requiring a special regulation designating routes and minimizing impacts for pedestrians or boaters, in part because the impacts are not presumed to require mitigation prior to allowing the use.  While the NPS acknowledges that other uses may in fact create impacts, the scope of this plan is limited and directed to evaluating ORV use, as required by existing NPS regulations, policy, and executive orders. Commercial ferry services are required to either purchase permits or operate under a concession contract, which includes a franchise fee that supports park operations.  “All parties should pay their share if they want to enjoy the  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  island. b. Do the ferry services pay a fee to operate on the island? They are for profit businesses that should pay to have exclusive ferry access to the island.” (398941)  33.  Certain user groups (seniors, veterans, disabled people, people with mobility impairments) should get a discount on the permit fee or a free permit or a discount for purchasing multiple permits.  “Veterans and Seniors should get a discount, and historically putting limits on number of permits is unnecessary." (399990) “What about lifetime permit for Vets and grandfather in longtime visitors who probably know more about driving on beach than people writing these rules? … Your ideas dont incl. a group or family rate, child, senior, handicap,” (399638) “It would be nice if senior citizens would be discounted or no fee at all for permits but I could do what is voted on.” (398946) “Lifetime vehicle permits should be issued to individuals over 65 similar to lifetime fishing licenses issued by the state of NC” (398158) “There should be reduced fees for handicapped, senior and veteran visitors.” (393494) “Fees - Truck camper plus 2 more for family - discount on multiple vehicles?” (391256)  NPS does not have the ability to set different rates for different groups of people under its special use authority. Additionally, were NPS to charge some users less, it would necessitate charging other users more in order to achieve cost recovery for the program.   34. But $80 is not prominent, it sticks out like a sore thumb. Ten days is also not as prominent as 7 days. An alternate pricing strategy using prominent numbers would be $50 for 7 days. This would be more acceptable to the users because 7 days is more within their range of actual visit than 10 days and $50 is emotionally less of a hurdle than $80. This price schedule would likely generate as much revenue for the park service because it will be accepted by more users. This sets up a logical three-step price strategy: 7 days for $50, two 7-days trips for $100 and annual for $150… I recommend a very simple fee structure: a) Long-term $150 per 12 months, rolling b) Short-term $8 per day, with a minimum of 2 days” (389502) “My suggestion that would be reasonable and fair to both parties, due to the ferry fees and NPS wanting to create more revenue, would be to charge an entrance fee to the park per person of $4 or $5 just like other NPS parks (Wright Brothers Memorial is an example). If this reasonable fee is not an option, I would expect NPS to charge a lower permit fee for a 7 day and annual permit. Personally, I think a fee of $25.00 for a 7 day permit and an annual fee of $80.00 would be more feasible and realistic.” (387993) “$20 short term and $50 long term would be more agreeable. Furthermore why should ORV users alone be subject to this penalty? Shouldn't pedestrian be subject to a user fee as well? This is viewed by many to be a discriminatory act.” (387742) “One way would be to offer a third fee, based on each visit, of something like $25. I would truly prefer a free vehicle permit, but that does not seem to be a possibility. At least with this additional option, you would be able to choose the method that best fits your island visitation.” (387570)  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  35.  Proposed fees should be increased to adequately cover the costs of implementation.   “Additionally, the ORV fees listed in Alternative C are too low. Given the increased ranger presence that should be in place whenever ORVs are present - to ensure all rules are followed and ORV users do not harass non-ORV users - the fees should be significantly higher to allow for full-time enforcement rangers with the ability to arrest violators. The minimal fees currently planed do not provide sufficient funds for this to occur.” (387414)  The permit fee system would be based on cost recovery, as detailed in responses #34. The NPS believes that the fees set for each permit length achieve this and do not need to be increased. Should costs increase, the NPS will revisit the permit cost structure, per NPS Director’s Order 53.  36.  Some money from permit fees should be used to subsidize ferry operators if their business is impacted by this plan. ORV fee money should be used to improve the back route. Permit fees should be used to maintain the back route and for species protection, not for enforcement. Develop a list of what the ORV permit fees can be used for. Use permit fees to dredge the ferry channel. Permit fees should not go into the general  “If the chosen alternative results in lower numbers of ORV's on CALO, the vehicle ferry operators stand to lose not only their livelihood, but also the value of businesses that have passed from generation to generation. While the ferry operators may be able to recoup some revenue by raising prices, this can only go so far before it too would cause decreased visitation. To mitigate this, the NPS should use some of the permit fee to subsidize the ferry operations if the number of ORV's fall below a certain threshold (not associated with weather events or closures beyond the control of local NPS representatives). If the NPS truly believes this plan will not adversely impact the number of ORV's on CALO in the coming years, they should not have any problem writing such economic support for the vehicle ferries into the plan. Without the vehicle ferries, an ORV plan is meaningless.” (399912) “Use ORV fees to improve backroad pullover areas- much needed” (399379) “I would like to see more money from permits go to maintaining the back roads and species protection on the island ,than to enforcement.” (398721) “Any permit fee promulgated by the CALO ORV PLAN must be dedicated to improve access and the visitor experience such as trail and ramp maintenance or parking lots. The best method would be to develop a specific list of projects for  See response #34 for information regarding how permit fees will be used. Note that special use permit fees are kept by the park, and do not go into the General Treasury, which helps ensure that collected fees are in fact spent for ORV management.  NPS is unable to subsidize ferry operations through its special use permit authority. The ferries are private businesses that operate under a commercial use authorization (CUA) and ferry operators determine their prices. Ferry operators are also regulated by the North Carolina Utilities Commission.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  fund. NPS needs to institute transparency in the use of these special use funds” (399284) “I recommend the park service (CALO specifically) reevaluate the strict division of labor between the Resource Management personnel and the Enforcement personnel. I have seen great success in business by cross-training so that previously specialized personnel can perform additional tasks. This approach provides additional training and skills to the employees, raising their value and job satisfaction. It gives management flexibility to make adjustments to seasonal changes and to fill short-term absences, etc. In some cases, the same work can be completed by fewer employees or more work is done by the same employees because they are fully utilized. There may be some resistance to moving away from the traditional silo job descriptions typically found in government. But, I know it would be very beneficial in a small park unit like CALO. Existing employees would be grandfathered in their job  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  current positions, or they could volunteer for the new cross-training. New employees would be cross-trained to serve as either resource management or enforcement as their primary duty, but fully capable of performing their secondary duty. While performing their primary duty in the field, they could also perform their cross-trained duties when they observe a circumstance requiring it. Thus a resource biologist could be monitoring bird or turtle nests in the field and issue a warning or citation on a park users if they see a problem. Some cross-trained personnel may be expected to split their duties 50/50. This approach would give park management the flexibility to combine the proposed $180k and $75.2k additional expenses into one $255 pool to hire new employees. I expect the educational requirements may make it easier to cross-train a biologist to be an enforcement officer than the opposite, but I am sure there are exceptions.” (397693)  37.  In terms of providing the park funds, the role of saltwater licensing was questioned.  “Furthermore where is all the revenue for the saltwater licenses going?” (398855)  The saltwater licensing program is administered and controlled by the State of North Carolina, not the NPS. Therefore the NPS does not have knowledge of how these funds are spent nor does the NPS receive any of this funding for administering the ORV program.  38.  Instead of a flat fee, charge per mile of use to reflect the impact to the resource.  “Charge per mile. When you get off the ferry, get a permit and your odometer is recorded. Charge per mile up to a certain amount. Reflects actual use impact to the resource.” (392184)  NPS believes that this alternate idea would result in much higher administrative costs for the NPS and would result in a higher permit fee; therefore the NPS has chosen not to implement this idea. The flat permit fee better meets the goals of the permit system to be simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage, which in turn will help ensure that the permit system remains viable, thus generally meeting plan objectives regarding ORV management.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  ORV PERMITS – LOGISTICS (WHERE AND HOW AVAILABLE, WHERE A PERMIT IS VALID, ETC.)  39.  One permit should be valid on both North Core and South Core Banks.   “ORV Permits should not be cost prohibitive to visitors, and there should only be 1 permit for both North and South Core Banks (CLNS).” (399990) “One vehicle permit should cover both islands. Many visitors go on multiple trips per year to both North and South Core Banks. Only one permit should be required for both islands. It's all the same National Seashore so there is no reason to require a separate permit for each island. If a permit for each island were required it would be a financial burden on visitors.” (399919)  After consideration of commenters’ requests for a single permit, the NPS has determined that a single permit for the entire Seashore would provide for additional flexibility for the visitor and provide a wider range of recreational opportunities for the visitor, without causing additional impacts to Seashore resources. A single permit would also simplify the administration of the permit program and would not add to, but would likely decrease, the cost of administering permits. It would also help ensure that the permit program would be simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage. The preferred alternative was modified so that one permit is valid over the entire park, where ORV use is permitted. In making this change, the NPS does recognize that while it is theoretically possible that all permit holders could go to the same island at the same time, visitor use patterns documented over the last 10 years show this has not happened in the past, and would be highly unlikely in the future.   40. There are no details given on how this would be  As stated in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, the goal of the permit program is to be simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage. Although details for the permit program will be further developed, permits will be available in multiple locations, including locations other than Harkers Island.
