A lottery should not be held until a year after the limit is reached and those would already have a permit should get priority.  “How will it be dealt with first come first served, a lottery, or special back room deals? Why if the park wants to make money would it limit visitors? This is a bad idea and I hope the park managers come to their senses and do not implement it.” (399937) “A lottery should not be needed until the year following when the limit is reached. "Partial lottery" should mean vehicles from previous year have priority to get next year's permit if they apply by a set date, then any remaining permits are by lottery.” (398156)  Permit allocation methods will be further determined as the permit program is developed. As stated in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, “It is the Seashore’s goal to make the vehicle permit convenient to obtain. NPS may adjust the permit system over time, such as to implement a lottery or partial lottery system. The goal is to ensure the permit system is simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage.” Suggestions that give preference to current permit holders could not be incorporated, because the Seashore cannot provide preferential treatment under its special use permit authority.   42.  Permits should be based on the calendar year and should be valid for 12 months (not seasonal). Alternate suggestions include 12 months and per fiscal year..  “Permits should be for a period of 12 months not January 1st thru December. Under the later, a person purchasing a permit in June only has a 6 month permit which is totally unfair to your visitors who may wish to return in the spring.” (399878) “The ORV permit should be on a fiscal year and not a calendar year.” (398737) “I would also like to see yearly permits be 12 months, not seasonal.” (398717)  Permits will be valid by season, when the Seashore islands open on March 16 and close on December 31 (the last day of permitted ORV use). The permit will be valid for the periods the Seashore is open during that calendar year. This provides for simplification of the administration of the permit, so that there is a single sticker. This also meets the goal of making the system straightforward and cost efficient to manage, as stated in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  43.  There should be one permit for both Cape Lookout National Seashore and Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  “I go to Cape Hatteras 3 times per yr and Cape Lookout 6 t per year. Look at a combo Sticker for those that want to enjoy both parks. $130 for Hatteras and $150 for Lookout = $280/yr. I suggest $190 for both and have it available to purchase via internet.” (399378)  The special use authority under NPS Director’s Order 53 allows the permit and permit fee to include cost recovery. The NPS will explore the potential for a joint permit between Cape Lookout and Cape Hatteras National Seashores. However the permit must recover the cost of administering the program at both parks.  44.  Visitors should be able to get their ORV permits when they make other park reservations.  “MOST OF THE FISHERMAN MAKE THEIR RESERVATIONS IN MARCH WHEN THE LINES OPEN, FOR AS FAR AWAY AS OCTOBER FOR THE DIFF TOURNAMENT. IF A LICENSE IS NEEDED FOR EACH VEHICLE THE OPTION SHOUULD BE GIVEN TO GET THE LICENSE AT THAT TIME. IT WOULD MEAN MUCH LESS PAPER WORK AND CERTAINLY MORE USER FRIENDLY. FOR THOSE THAT DON'T FISH, CAMPERS AND KYAKERS THE SAME FEES SHOULD APPLY. LICENSE TO BE FOR ONE VEHICLE FOR THE PERIOD OF MARCH THRU DECEMBER. FOR THOSE THAT DO NOT USE VEHICLES ON THE ISLAND, THEY SHOULD PAY AN ACESS FEE JUST LIKE ANY RECREATION PARK.” (399383)  The NPS does understand and appreciate the logistics that can go into planning a visit to the Seashore. As the permit system is developed, the NPS will consider the complicated logistics of planning a trip to the Seashore. As stated in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the goal of this program is to ensure the permit system is simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage. Taking into consideration the logistics of trip planning will be part of that process.   45.  How far in advance can permits be purchased?  “Will the permits limit how many days you can stay and how far in advance can you purchase permits.” (398711)  The deadlines for permits will be established as the program is further developed. Since permits are based on the season, they would be available the prior to the opening of the Seashore to ORVs in March. likely in the October or November of the previous year to allow visitors to plan trips.  ORV PERMITS – LIMITS ON PERMITS AND VEHICLE NUMBERS  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  46.  There is no reason to limit ORV numbers because use is already self-limited due to the capacity of concessioners and the availability of cabins. If a limit is needed, limit the number of ferry operators, which will regulate the level of use.  “If ORV levels are considered to be too high during certain key times of the year NPS can control access levels via the concessioners who bring people to the island, and availability of the cabins in which a large portion of the people on the island are staying.” (384967) “The NPS feels they need 2500 permits. Where does this data come from, how is it fair to the businesses? This is totally un-necessary, the amount of vehicle and visitors are simply controlled already by the ferry operations schedules….No limits” (400080) “In the alternate it mentioned limiting the number of vehicles by a vehicle permit system. The ferries already limit the number of vehicles that can get on and off the island. Placing a quota on the number of vehicles poses lots of issues as I would see it as causing people not to invest in vehicles to use on CALO.” (399926)  While commenters correctly note that the current ferry operations do, in part, limit the number of ORVs that can access the Seashore, this plan manages ORV use into the future. The number and size of ferries operating in the area could change in the future, which would increase the capacity and number of ORVs on the Seashore if not otherwise regulated. Because of this, the ferry operations are not considered to be a limitation to ORV use at the Seashore. Suggestions that cabin capacity equates to a limitation on ORV use are not correct. ORV use is not limited by the number of cabins because there is no requirement to rent a cabin in order to use an ORV at the Seashore.  “Vehicle permits numbers should not be limited. Put a moratorium on Ferry services to allow only the two current services, that will be self-limiting.” (399834)  47.  The number of permits available should not be open ended and subject to adjustment; this number can be impacted by storm events that would skew the numbers. Using the 3-year average is not a good estimate and would result in use below  “I am strongly opposed to limiting the number of permits, for the simple fact that the draft proposals that provide limits to the number of permits are also advocating an "adjustment" after years 1 - 3. I do not endorse any plan that is open ended in areas regarding access to the park, because, in conjunction with permits, a rolling average will only reduce the number of permits available moving forward. For example, in 2011 and 2012, due to Hurricane Irene and SuperStorm Sandy, the Core Banks experienced closures. If those two years were included in a 3-year rolling average to determine permits for year four, the resulting permits available would be significantly reduced. Following the proposed (C&D) system, the pre-storm numbers could never be re-attained.” (399226)  Commenters raised valid concerns regarding the potential for extended closures to influence the 3-year average. In recognition of this, the preferred alternative has been changed to use a 5-year average, and exclude years with extended closures. The preferred alternative has been modified to read, “If there is a year with a closure in excess of 14 days, that year will not be considered and an additional year would be used.” The term “historic” is no longer used. The preferred alternative now reads, “The limit on the number of vehicle permits issued would be  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  historic demand.  “In the NPS's preferred Alternative C, the ORV permits would be limited to the average number of ORV's delivered  6,200 permits annually park-wide, which is based on the number of ORVs delivered to each  How will “historic”  to the island from 2005 to 2012. Then in year 4, a limit would  island from 2005 through 2015.”  numbers be  be placed on the number of vehicle permits based on the  determined?  average number of permits issued during years 1 - 3 of the plan. As you are aware, Cape Lookout is subject to severe weather events, some of which can close the island for extended periods of time. In addition, other events such as last year's Federal budget stalemate in Congress, may cause the park to close. Depending upon the time of year, this can severely impact the number of vehicles delivered to CALO. Over the seven year period chosen (2005 to 2012) a single weather event (Hurricane Irene) caused the park to close, but the effect on the overall average may not be of great concern. However, given a three year period as mandated by the plan, a single weather event or other closure could have a significant impact on the average. The plan should be modified to allow adjustment for such events, rather than a simple mathematical formula to be blindly followed.” (399909) “How does the NPS plan to determine what constitutes historical levels? The AMA would like to ensure that the historic level of OHV use is not determined or unfairly skewed by the level of activity that occurred during the recent recession, when visitation levels were depressed.” (384940) “Use of three-year average assures the limit will be less than historic peak demand. The limit threshold should have more margins before triggering action. The 3-year average can be unusually low if there is a hurricane closure, gasoline shortage and/or high unemployment, government shutdown, etc. that temporarily keeps people from taking ORVs to the island for a an extended period of time. A better statistical approach should be used to establish the baseline, plus a reasonable margin before triggering unnecessary limit actions” (398156)  The NPS has adjusted the permit level to 6,200 to reflect the most current data. A review of the current data shows that this level still allows for resource protection and accommodates existing ORV use.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  48.  Sell permits when cabin reservations are made and allow two permits per cabin reservation.   “*I recommend that you have the option to reserve 2 permits per cabin when renting your cabin online at Recreation.gov.” (398770) “Sell permits at the time cabin reservations are made online eliminating the uncertainty that a permit would be available if quotas are established” (398157)  The NPS does understand and appreciate the logistics that can go into planning a visit to the Seashore. As the permit system is developed, the NPS will consider the complicated logistics of planning a trip to the Seashore. As stated in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the goal of this program is to ensure the permit system is simple, straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage.  An ORV permit is not required to use the cabins at the Seashore. Cabin users may only have one ORV or no ORV at all. By setting aside two permits per cabin, permits that may not be used by those in the cabins would be set aside and not available for other visitors. For this reason, the NPS did not incorporate the idea of setting aside permits for cabin users.  49.  Make the permit system “weighted” so weekend and weekday permits do not count the same.  “IF limits are a must, please consider a weighted system. A weekend permit shouldn't carry the same weight as a year permit. I am thinking 1/4 for a weekend, 1/2 for a week and 1 for a year. That allows more people to get permits. You know a weekend permit is only going to be on the island for 3 days. That doesn't justify counting as 1 whole permit.” (398723)  The management costs of ORV management are the same for weekend or weekday visitors. Because the permits are based on cost recovery, this would result in no difference between a weekend or weekday permit. The NPS also believes that having a consistently weighted permit meets the goals of the program by making the system straightforward, fair, accessible, and cost efficient to manage.  50.  Will permits be allocated to the various ferry operators?  “There are 3000 permits recommend for South Core Banks. There are two ferry operations (different Companies) transporting vehicles and visitors to South Core Banks. Is this to mean each company receives 1500 permits each? Then you have one ferry operator transporting vehicles and  The NPS will allocate permits to members of the public under the special use authority. Permits will not be allocated to the ferry operators.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  visitors to North Core Banks.” (400080)  51.  If the numbers need to be limited, why was a second ferry operator added?  “If numbers of ORV s need to be limited, why was a second ferry operator permitted for South Core Banks?” (399871)  The National Park Service has found that the ferries are not an appropriate mechanism for limiting park access. At the time the permit for the ferry was requested, in 2010, a preferred alternative had not yet been selected.  52.  The number of permits proposed does not correlate with the number of ORVs at the Seashore at any time.  “NPS mistakenly claims that allowing 2,500 ORV permits for North Core Banks and 3,000 permits for South Core Banks would not impact ORV use because these numbers represent the average ORV use based on 2005-2012 user data. Limiting the number ORVs through permit limits does not correlate with the number of ORVs in use at the Seashore at any given time. "Obtaining exact counts of the number of ORVs actively being used on ORV routes at the-Seashore at any given time is difficult because, once these vehicles reach the Seashore, they may stay for a day, a week, or the entire season, and because many of the vehicles are stationary within the parking lot." Draft ORV Plan, p. 11. Vehicle permit limits are not necessary (the number of ORVs and visitors are controlled already by the ferry operation schedules) and would significantly limit access to and use of the Seashore and require additional NPS expenditures with no corresponding benefits.” (399689)  The permit system does not correlate to the number of vehicles on the Seashore at one time and the draft ORV management plan/EIS does not state that this is the goal of permit limits. The purpose of permit limits is to keep use close to past use levels. The annual permit limit would approximate current use, which has been shown to agree with visitor use expectations for their desired experience, and adequately protect resources. A permit that tracks daily or weekly use at the Seashore is unnecessary both because of the overall low numbers of ORV use and because this would increase administrative costs. Daily limits could impact visitor use and experience due to uncertainty of available space on the Seashore.  53.  Establish a limit after the first five years based on the average of all visitation, then split the permits between the two islands.  “I would suggest to not have a limit on permits for the first 5 seasons of the ORV plan and then implement a average based on all Cape Lookout National Seashore vehicle use and split the permits between the two parks (North Core and South Core Banks). To say, that folks who visit PI during fall fishing will not be able to drive their vehicles due to the allocated permits being distributed is unfair. The thought of not being able to go fall fishing with 10 of my dearest friends, who love PI, saddens me deeply.” (387997)  The preferred alternative has been changed to have one permit covering both North and South Core Banks. The preferred alternative has also been modified to be based on a 5-year average. See response #47 for further details on this revision.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  54.  If all the permits are sold by a certain date, will permits be available after that?  “My question is for the park visitors during the late fall season. If PI is allocated 2500 annual vehicle usage permits and all 2500 have been purchased, let's say by October 1, does that mean that park visitors who visit every year for fall fishing will not be allowed to operate a vehicle? If so, what are the reasons why?” (387996) “Alternative "C" states that "Permits would be issued on a first-come, first-served basis." So what happens if all 3,000 permits for South Core Banks are used by July? The park is open until December 31. Will no ORV's be allowed for the remaining 5 months? Many visitors of the park visit in the fall months to take advantage of the excellent fishing opportunities. Under this plan when the permits are used they are gone. So for those of us who are only able to visit only during the fall - our ability to use an ORV on Cape Lookout will be subject to prior sales? We have to make cabin reservations in January for the peak fall season - how will we know at that time if a vehicle permit will be available? Many of us have to drive long distances to reach the Seashore - will there be a mechanism to estimate remaining permits before setting out on such a journey? Will the NPS cancel, and fully refund, cabin reservations if ORV permits are not available?” (399698)  Yes, permits are limited and once they are all sold out, no other permits will be issued until the next permitting year.   55.  Limits may result in certain groups buying all the permits.  “Putting a limit on the numbers will allow surf fishing clubs to buy up all the available permits and the occasional fisherman like myself would be excluded.” (387330)  The purchase of an ORV permit must be tied to a vehicle. While a certain group obtaining a large number of permits is not implausible, due to this requirement it is unlikely.   56.  The Seashore should set targets for permits, not limits, and make changes if the 3-year rolling average falls below 5,000 permits,  “I recommend that the park service not set an annual limit on ORV permits. Instead, set Target Goals based on the historic data. The Target Goal should be nominal 5500 permits per year with a /- 10% range. The Target Maximum would be 6000 permits per year and the Target Minimum would be 5000 permits per year. The park service would calculate a 3-year rolling average of the actual permits  The method of setting permit limits under the preferred alternative will help maintain current use levels which will maintain the visitor experience and protect park resources. The preferred alternative in the final ORV management plan/EIS, has been revised and no longer uses the 5-year average. The limit on  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  or above 6,000.  issued. As long as the 3-year rolling average remains within the target range of 5000 to 6000 permits, no action would be required.” (387770) “If the 3-year rolling average falls below 5000, the park service would initiate promotions to encourage more permits. Suggested promotions could include: bundling credits for lighthouse climb tickets with each annual ORV permit, a 10% discount on the annual and short-term permit fees to senior citizens and/or military veterans, a 10% discount on the second year when buying an optional 2-year annual permit, perks involving locally controlled CALO activities and events, encouraging the Crystal Coast Tourism Authority to advertise CALO ORV use, coordinate with CAHA to cross-promote ORV use at both parks on their web sites, etc. If the 3-year rolling average falls above 6000, the park service would take incremental actions to discourage permits. Suggested actions could include: eliminating previous promotional actions, raising permit fees, or establishing firm limits on the number of permits issued annually.” (387771)  ORV permits is now set at 6,200. Establishing the permit limit at 6,200 could increase use and could impact visitor experience and resources. After five years, and through a civic engagement process, the limit on ORV permits would be reevaluated.  57.  Under alternative D, reduce the number of permits lower than 8 percent (15 to 20 percent is suggested).  “We strongly favor the permit system, as it has proved successful at Assateague. Please strengthen Alternative D by cutting down on permit numbers more than the 8-percent reduction proposed. A 15 or 20 percent reduction would be more helpful to pedestrian use and wildlife habitat.” (395995)  The 8 percent reduction in ORV permit numbers under alternative D was based on the 8 percent reduction of area available for ORV use. This reduction would help ensure that ORV density remains consistent with traditional levels. Further reductions in permit limits are not justified given the success of species protection measures and the relatively low level of current ORV use that would continue under the permit limits set in alternative D.  58.  The number of permits under alternative D should be phased in over 2 to  “The permit system will certainly result in the most consternation from the ORV 'crowd'. A balance needs to be reached between limiting usage to protect the habitat and making access attainable. Consider phasing in the proposed  Except for alternative E, each action alternative that bans ORV use seeks to balance usage and habitat protection. Because 8 percent is relatively low, based on realistic access to pedestrian areas (see response #57 for more  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  3 years.  8% ct in permits over 2 or 3 years.” (395962)  information about the 8 percent reduction), and because the overall number of ORVs is also relatively low, phasing in this reduction would create additional administrative costs with relatively little benefit. Therefore, under alternative D, the addition of pedestrian-only areas would immediately result in an 8 percent reduction of areas open to ORV use, and would not be phased in, and the number of permits would need to be reduced when pedestrian areas are added. Note, however, that alternative D is not the NPS preferred alternative and is not being proposed for implementation.  EDUCATION AND OUTREACH – INCLUDING THE OPERATOR EDUCATION CERTIFICATE  59.  Provide educational materials, rather than requiring a certificate.   “Requiring licenses to drive vehicles is an example of the type of road blocks which concern me. If education is your objective, then handing out flyers at each of the ferry services would accomplish that objective.” (384161) “A suggestion is that each ORV crossing over to the island be given a handout outlining the rules and expectations of the National Park Service along with a cell phone number of the Park Ranger on duty. By reminding everyone that we need to work with the National Park Service to protect our island, we could produce more protection than a team of 5 rangers each in an ORV. This would eliminate the $180,000 enforcement cost to the taxpayers. An expensive permit to have a vehicle on the island could be eliminated, which would further reduce cost to the National Park Service in administering the program. The handouts should be drafted for the season, such as when birds are mating and fledging.” (398933)  As described in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, all action alternatives would involve a wide range of education and outreach activities including interpretive programs and the distribution of educational materials at the ferries. However, even with this education and outreach, the Seashore believes that the educational certificate provides additional benefits beyond general education. Requiring the certificate ensures that users understand the rules and regulations. Users may or may not read a handout. The purpose of the program is to go beyond just providing the information and to ensure understanding of the information by Seashore users.  60. The education certificate should be valid for more than one year.  “Certifications should be available for multiply year periods similar to State Drivers license.” (399963) “Also annual education is not necessary. Training at Cape Lookout National Seashore should be valid at Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  “Also the off road training should qualify you for the other areas of Cape Lookout and Cape Hatteras National park without having to sit through the same training again that year.” (389857)  The regulations, issues, and concerns associated with Cape Lookout National Seashore are different from Cape Hatteras National Seashore. As many commenters noted, each park is unique and a separate approach to ORV management, including the educational certificate, is warranted.  63.  Grandfather in existing long-term users and do not require them to watch the educational video.   “The second suggestion I would like to make is to provide a grandfather cause for the users who do not need to review a 7-minute video on driving a vehicle for off road use. There are numerous park visitors who have been driving on Cape Lookout and other National Park beaches for years.” (387994)  The NPS appreciates that many users of the Seashore have been coming and using ORVs for many years. As these users are aware, driving conditions at the Seashore can change and species management measures can be adjusted due to the dynamic coastal environment. The Seashore believes that all users need to remain have current information about Seashore policy, conditions at the Seashore, and regulations on ORV use, therefore grandfathering in certain users would not be appropriate.   LONG-TERM PARKING (LOCATIONS, FEES, ETC.)  64.  Do not limit the number of parking permits. Specifically, more cars should be allowed in the North Core Lot (50 was suggested).  “20 cars in long term parking at N Core is not enough...should be 50 year round.” (385098) “I do not think you should limit the number of permits. Same reasons as not limiting driving permits. Last year I got my permit in October and was #242. I should have easily been in the 300s maybe closer to 400. I think the numbers are down, way down from the 2010 numbers you are looking at (table p90). NO LIMIT ON PARKING PERMITS.” (398726)  The permit number that an ORV user receives does not correlate with the number of vehicles in the lot. The limit on parking permits was derived by considering traditional use patterns of the parking lots, based on the number of permits issued, including for the North Core Banks lot. The proposed numbers provide adequate longterm parking based on the traditional use patterns. The Seashore does not feel that these  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  use levels should be expanded because of the physical on-the-ground changes that would be required.   65.  Parking lot fees should be maintained at current levels or reduced ($10/week). Parking permits should continue to be offered on a weekly basis.   “PARKING PERMITS ARE TOO HIGH! The fees to park should not be over $10 per week. Unlike other park location you have to enter Cape Lookout National Seashore by ferry. This requires the visitor to pay a ferry fee for the vehicle, a fee per person, along with all the other expenses.” (399962) “The Coalition objects to raising the parking fees, which would limit access to and use of the Seashore. The current parking fee at the Seashore is $15 per week. NPS has indicated that a parking permit would be approximately $60 to $80 per month and would be valid on a monthly basis. Parking fees should not exceed the current rate of $15 per week and should be offered on a weekly basis. The Coalition strongly objects to increasing parking fees, which would limit access to and use of the Seashore. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification to support increasing parking fees.” (399697)  The current fee of $15 is necessary to allow for cost recovery of administering the parking lots. By having a monthly, rather than weekly, parking permit, the Seashore would incur lower administrative costs, which would allow the Seashore to maintain a reasonable rate for ORV users.  66.  Consider an annual parking permit.  “Consider an annual parking permit - Cost should be $150.00” (392170)  Users are able to purchase multiple monthly parking passes that would allow for parking throughout the entire ORV use season. A discount will not be available for the purchase of multiple parking permits because of the need to maintain cost recovery for the program.   67. Commenters did provide suggestions of alternative locations for parking areas. While the NPS is not currently considering new lot locations, due to the dynamic nature of the Seashore, the NPS does recognize that the current locations of the parking lots may need to change over time. As storms and other events change the landscape of the Seashore, the NPS will explore other areas for the parking lots. Even if new lots are established in other areas, the overall parking capacity detailed in the draft ORV management plan/EIS would remain the same.  “I do not agree with moving the lot to Carly's dock. There are not enough parking spaces available to accommodate the number of ORVs permits allocated; therefore the parking fee could not be automatically added to the ORV permit fee because all of those vehicles may not be able to use the lots.   70. Limit the time and locations of sea turtle closures based on hatching periods.  “Sea turtles have a definite hatching period after the nest is laid. At Bald Head Island, they can tell you within 3 days, when a nest will hatch. They regularly move nests which are too close to the surf. I would suggest that any restriction on access around a sea turtle nest should be no more that a week, or a small area (1/4 mile would be a gracious plenty) should be established for relocation of turtle nests. A road around that specific area would protect the hatching turtles from being caught in tire tracks yet provide for more access to the beach by vehicles.” (384165)  As stated chapter 2, “Table 4: Alternative Element Summary – Species,” closures are established 50 days after nests are laid, which takes into account their expected hatch window, as suggested by the commenter. Establishing the closure 50 days after the nest is laid is also consistent with the recommendations of the USFWS, as well as the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission (NCWRC). The proposed closure is the minimum number of days necessary under this guidance.   72.  How and when nests get moved should be addressed. Specific suggestions include: Park employees should be allowed to move nests to protect them from storms and predators.  Move turtle nests to a single location and use volunteers around hatch time to assist in the process. Turtle nests should be moved to a central location, such as an incubation facility. This has proven successful at Padre  “RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PARK EMPLOYEES: should be allowed to move nest to protected areas to safeguard eggs from storm and predator hazards. These two hazards have a greater effects of the success of bird and turtle survival than any other.” (399955) “Turtle nests located in areas that may be dangerous to their success should be relocated to a centralized area where their success can be better guaranteed. Success rates at Padre Island where a centralized and controlled incubation area is used has a success rate far superior to that enjoyed in any NC seashore. Cape Lookout with the blessing of NCWRC, should take the lead and prove this successful program is applicable in NC.” (399279) “There are, however, other options for the turtles. Nests can be moved to a single location where they can be easily monitored and reduce the areas closed for the turtles. Also, when a nest is close to hatching time, let volunteers, with strict instructions, tent camp near the nest, put up barriers to either side of the nest, smooth out the sand and cover ghost crab holes in front of the nest to the surf. The presence of these people will also help keep seagulls from picking up the  The management of sea turtle nests at the Seashore from a proactive relocation standpoint is consistent with the guidelines set forth in the most recent loggerhead recovery plan (2008) and set forth by the state of North Carolina in the NCWRC turtle handbook to use the least manipulative method to protect nests. The 2008 recovery plan states that “As a general rule, nests should only be relocated if they are low enough on the beach to be washed daily by tides or if they are situated in well documented high risk areas that routinely experience serious erosion and egg loss (e.g., nests laid near river mouths or beneath eroding sea walls).” Seashore guidelines for relocating nests are discussed with NCWRC staff annually to determine the appropriateness of the criteria and their consistency with the NCWRC guidelines, the loggerhead recovery plan, and the goals of sea turtle management. However, because the location of “troughs” or flooding pools and other areas that are susceptible to  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  Island.  turtles. I was fortunate to be able to do this years ago. I feel there would be a lot of participation for this.” (39112) “Turtle nests located in areas that may be dangerous to their success should be relocated to a centralized area where their success can be better guaranteed. Padre Island, where centralized and controlled incubation are employed, enjoys successes far superior to any NC seashore. Cape Lookout with the blessing of NCWRC, should take the lead and prove this successful program is applicable in NC.” (399880)  erosion or frequent inundation change on a year-to-year basis, the specific guidelines for where nests will be relocated from/to will be evaluated and may change annually.  The use of true hatcheries is discouraged by the USFWS and the NCWRC. At Padre Island National Seashore, all Kemp’s ridley sea turtle eggs are relocated to an incubation hatchery. The decision to use this type of hatchery was a last resort management decision made when the species was on the brink of extinction as a way to help the species recover, a situation that does not exist for the loggerhead, leatherback, or green sea turtle. Prior to 2005, the number of nests located along the entire Texas coast taken to the incubation facility averaged less than 50. Within the last several years, nest numbers are now approaching 200 nests along the entire coast. As a result, the latest Kemp’s ridley recovery plan indicates that future management should consider protecting nests in-situ as nesting abundance reaches levels that outstrip the capacity to translocate all nests to hatcheries (NMFS & USFWS draft 2010).  73.  Expand closures and address the potential for ORVs to erase turtle tracks. Buffers for sea turtles should be at least 350 feet.  “We also urge NPS to study additional methods to address the fact that ORV vehicle tracks may obliterate turtle crawl tracks, resulting in turtle patrols not being able to locate and protect nests. Buffers for turtle nests within hatching window: Fifty days after a turtle nest is laid, the closure around it should be expanded to at least 105 meters wide (52.5 meters to each side of nest), 15 meters landward behind the nest, and all the way to surfline, marked with light-filtering fence in a U-shaped configuration around the nest. " (399259) “Of the proposed alternatives, I support Alternative D with  The proposed regulations on night driving in the ORV management plan/EIS reduce the chances that ORVs would impact turtle tracks. However, based on Seashore resource staff experience, high wind and rain, not ORVs, make turtle tracks hard to find. Nonetheless, Seashore staff is typically present on the islands looking for tracks earlier than most traffic. The only other option would be to work at night, which would be unsafe and might not result in additional finds.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  some modifications. The Park Service should ensure buffers for all wildlife are included in the proposed plan and include nesting sea turtles buffers to ensure successful nesting and hatching of their eggs. The Park Service should designate appropriate buffers for sea turtles (at least 350 feet) and extend the night driving restriction to October 31.” (395962)  As the commenter suggests, the Seashore uses light-blocking features for nests when light is a concern.  74.  Document turtles nests when found, during hatching time make a “V” closure to reduce areas closed off to recreation.   “Hey, here is a novel idea. When a turtle nest is found, document it (they do you know),block it off with stakes and tape, then within its hatching time run said stakes and tape in a v to the ocean...thus letting beach traffic and fishermen use their beach while not disturbing the nest...but that would be too simple and too much common sense used up. Instead the NPS just closes an entire section of beach off each time a turtle nests is found and leaves it closed the entire season.” (387277)  As suggested by the commenter, current species management practices at the Seashore that would be continued under the plan mark off nests and allow for vehicles around the back of the nest if room is available. This allows the required buffer size to be maintained and access to be provided where feasible.   75.  Establish semipermanent turtle enclosures that serve to protect turtles and allow for bird nesting.  “I would recommend the following ideas in addition to Alternative A: A semi-permanent turtle enclosure should be created using posts that would accommodate bird netting during nesting season to protect the young turtles from sea gulls as they travel from the nest to water. The netting could be removed at the end of the hatching season.” (384986)  Because most turtle hatching and travel to the water occur at night, seagulls are not considered to be a predator impacting turtle hatchling success. Furthermore, such permanent structures are not practical at the Seashore due to the changing environmental conditions, and once installed, would need to be maintained and replaced often.   76.  Does NPS use a groomer to eliminate tracks they make on ATVs?  “Remember ATV's, if driven properly, do not leave ruts like trucks which makes it hard for turtle hatch returning to the ocean. (At least on Ophelia, you cannot get a truck there so this eliminates that problem). NPS can monitor these egg sites and place flags in the sand as is done elsewhere along the banks. When the NPS patrols the banks in their ATV's, do they have a "groomer" to eliminate their tracks if they are so much of a turtle hindrance?” (387410)  The Seashore does not use a groomer to remove ATV tracks. However, NPS staff are trained to avoid creating tracks in front of the nests to reduce the potential for impacts to hatchlings.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  SPECIES CLOSURES AND OTHER SPECIES MANAGEMENT RELATED ISSUES – BIRDS  77.  There is a perception that there are numerous bird violations, but the data shows this is not the case.  “BIRD CLOSURES VIOLATIONS: The NPS wants us to believe there are numerous violations of closure areas, when in fact their data indicates with 480,000 visitors and 4,157 being ORVs a total of 17 closure violations took place. Of these violations 9 were made by vehicle traffic and the other 8 were made by pedestrian. Based on the total of 480,000 possible violations I would consider these number very good. By requiring driver training and certifications these number will improve even more. Some of our visitors come from across the U. S. and other countries and are not aware of our closure requirements.” (399968)  While citations have been low, Seashore law enforcement staff have observed closure violations that have not resulted in citations. In 2012, law enforcement staff issued four written warnings for vehicles in bird closures, four written citations for pedestrians in bird closures, and eight written citations for vehicles in bird areas. In addition, 125 dog off leash written citations, 75 written warnings (for all violations), and 749 verbal warnings (for all violations) were issued in 2012. This information has been updated in the final ORV management plan/EIS. There are also limited numbers of law enforcement staff, consequently limiting where they can be at the Seashore at any given time. Thus, these documented or observed violations do not represent the total number of actual violations at the Seashore at any given time.   78.  Buffers are too large and should be reduced. Suggestions:  200 feet to 100 feet  Use monitoring to have minimum buffer sizes Lower buffer sizes will increase ORV use and decrease predator activity.  “THE 200 FOOT BUFFER ZONES NEED TO BE REDUCED TO 100 FOOT: Data obtained from other park locations using the larger buffers consistently show declines in data numbers. Buffer size need to be smaller allowing ORV traffic in these areas to help reduce predator activity. Data indicates bird and turtle success rate to be higher in smaller area where predators are detruded by ORV activity.” (399952) “NPS should provide intensive monitoring of shore birds. This will allow the minimum protective measures for buffers.” (399842)  The commenter did not specify what locations are being referenced, or citations from other studies. Thus the NPS is unable to evaluate this information.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  79.  Set limits on the size of closures and instead use alternative species management measures used successfully at state parks and municipal beaches.  “Although it may be unprecedented, the park service should seriously consider setting some kind of limit on the maximum amount of beach that can be closed for resource protection. Implementing such a limit should not be viewed as a negative for the interests of the birds and turtles. Rather it acknowledges the success of a thriving population of protected species. … Trying to manage each and every animal one by one is a futile effort and should not be the goal. Implementing a beach closure limit will require good professional judgment to make sure that the most productive areas for protected species remain closed to ORV use while other less productive areas remain open for both recreational use and potential nesting by protected species. Alternative methods should be utilized to protect bird nests and turtle nests on the beaches that are open for ORV use, even if they may be considered to be less effective than the full beach closure method. Alternative methods of managing sea turtles are being used successfully at state parks (e.g. Fort Fisher) and municipal beaches (e.g. Oak Island) in North Carolina. I recommend the final ORV rule include a cap on the maximum amount of beach that can be closed for resource protection at any time. My gut feel is the cap should be 50% of the total amount of beach available for ORV use or the historic maximum amount of beach closure prior to 2016.” (399396)  The NPS resource management mandate is considerably stricter than state and municipal parks. That said, a review of state and municipal park restrictions shows that many municipal and state beaches are completely closed to ORVs during nesting seasons. For example, Fort Macon State Park (the closest state park) does not allow ORVs. Local municipal beaches only allow vehicles during certain seasons when birds are not nesting and turtles are not hatching (late fall and winter), and only by permit. NPS has strived to develop a plan where beach driving may still be allowed, but to do so buffers and beach closures are required. NPS policy also encourages protection of individual birds in addition to species. NPS closures are based on peer-reviewed science, including applicable USFWS recovery plans.  “Bird closures are not based on science. They are based on hypothetical educational assumptions. No peer reviewed science here. They are reflective on the pressure put on the NPS and FWS by the Audubon Society and others. Bird closures should move with the birds and not remain massive in size. Termination of the closure should be immediate upon the last chick being fledged. Closures should reflect the distances used successfully in other parks.” (398736)  80.  Buffers should be limited so the back  “CALO is very narrow along most of its length, and the proposed buffers, which extend 360ï¿½ around any given  Due to the typical nesting locations of birds at the Seashore, only on rare occasions would the  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  route is not blocked.  nest site, could effectively close access to both the beach and back road. In effect, a pair of birds nesting just north of the cabins, and another pair nesting just south of the cabins, could prohibit access to the entire island to all ORV use (or possibly trap campers with no way to legally return to the ferry landings). Historical data shows nest sites in these areas, so it is not a matter of if, but when. Increase piping plover buffers. Use the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) protocols that were used at Cape Hatteras National Seashore to develop buffers. These protocols have worked at Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  “Shorebird buffers: We agree with the nesting buffers in Alternative D with some exceptions. Piping plover buffers for courtship and nesting should be expanded to 75 meters. Buffers for piping plover chicks should be expanded to 1,000 meters for ORVs and 300 meters for pedestrians. We also urge NPS to consider increasing setback distances by 100 meters (or 300 feet) early in the nesting cycle (courtship, nest building, territory establishment) due to heightened sensitivity of terns and black skimmers to disturbances during this period, and increasing setback distances an additional 100 meters (300 feet) in areas where dogs are permitted. We also urge NPS to consider provisions to increase buffer distances for shorebirds that are being disturbed or flushed, for instance in 50-meter (150-foot) increments.” (399259) “NPS relied on the USGS report and other studies and reports with similar findings in developing the ORV management plan for Cape Hatteras National Seashore. Because Cape Hatteras is located just north of Cape Lookout, and we are not aware of a similar report written for Cape Lookout, we recommend that the wildlife protections embodied in the Cape Hatteras ORV management plan (which were based on the recommendations of the USGS  The buffer distances detailed in the preferred alternative are based on USFWS recovery plan recommendations, relevant USFWS biological opinions, and the professional experience of park resource staff – who have managed these species consistently for over 20 years, with daily monitoring of chicks and nests and establishment of buffer zones and closures. The Seashore did not rely on the USGS report when establishing buffers because this report and its recommendations were specific to Cape Hatteras National Seashore and its higher levels of ORV use. Cape Lookout National Seashore also has a greater population of nesting shorebirds. In 2014 there were 14 pairs of piping plovers and 27 pairs of American oystercatchers at Cape Hatteras National Seashore, while at Cape Lookout National Seashore, there were 47 pairs of piping plovers and 65 pairs of American oystercatchers. The implementation of a permit system with limits would ensure that ORV use would remain at levels where the proposed buffers are  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  report) should inform NPS's efforts in developing wildlife protections at Cape Lookout.” (399258) “For the past several years, the Park Service has enforced specific science-based measures like no-driving buffers around nesting birds and turtles, their nests, chicks, and hatchlings, and protections for migrating and wintering shorebirds. At nearby Cape Hatteras, these policies have worked and wildlife populations have increased.” (395590)  appropriate.   82.  The American oystercatcher should not have protected status.  “American Oyster catchers are not on the species of concern to entitle them special protection. The NCWRC used this designation as awareness!” (399842)  The NPS has responsibilities under many different regulations, policies, and requirements regarding species management, including the NPS Organic Act, the Migratory Bird Treaty Act (MBTA), Executive Order 13186, and NPS Management Policies 2006. Species protection is not governed solely by the Endangered Species Act.  Section 4.4.1 of the NPS Management Policies 2006 says, “The National Park Service will maintain as parts of the natural ecosystems of parks all plants and animals native to park ecosystems…by preserving and restoring the natural abundances, diversities, dynamics, distributions, habitats, and behavior of native plant and animal populations and the communities and ecosystems in which they occur…and minimizing human impacts on native plants, animals, populations, communities, and ecosystems, and the processes that sustain them.” NPS Management Policies 2006 (sec. 4.1) provide that “Natural resources will be managed to preserve fundamental physical and biological processes, as well as individual species, features, and plant and animal communities...including the natural abundance,  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  diversity, and genetic and ecological integrity of the plant and animal species native to those ecosystems.” Section 4.4.1.1 of the NPS Management Policies 2006 addresses the NPS responsibility to maintain “all native plant and animal species and their habitats inside parks.” Section 4.1 of the NPS Management Policies 2006 also provides that “There may be situations in which an area may be closed to visitor use to protect the natural resources (for example, during an animal breeding season...” Simply put, the NPS has obligations under the Organic Act and other applicable laws and policies to protect wildlife, listed or not, even if it means some restrictions on access. NPS Management Policies 2006 (sec. 4.4.2.3) also state that “The Service will survey for, protect, and strive to recover all species native to national park system units that are listed under the Endangered Species Act. The Service will fully meet its obligations under the NPS Organic Act and the Endangered Species Act to both proactively conserve listed species and prevent detrimental effects on these species.” To meet the above obligations, the management policies direct the NPS to “conduct actions and allocate funding to address endangered, threatened, proposed, and candidate species.” The policies further indicate that “the National Park Service will inventory, monitor, and manage state and locally listed species in a manner similar to its treatment of federally listed species to the greatest extent possible. In addition, the Service will inventory other native species that are of special management concern to the parks (such as rare, declining, sensitive, or unique species and their habitats) and will manage them to maintain  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  their natural distribution and abundance.” In addition to NPS responsibilities under the Organic Act and NPS Management Policies 2006, Executive Order 13186 directs federal agencies to minimize their negative impacts on migratory birds, promote conservation of migratory bird populations, and to perform certain actions to further implement the MBTA. This executive order requires that federal agencies “support the conservation intent of the migratory bird conventions by integrating bird conservation principles, measures, and practices into agency activities and by avoiding or minimizing, to the extent practicable, adverse impacts on migratory bird resources when conducting agency actions” and to “ensure that environmental analyses of Federal actions required by the NEPA or other established environmental review processes evaluate the effects of actions and agency plans on migratory birds, with emphasis on species of concern.” Furthermore, the executive order requires agencies to “identify where unintentional take reasonably attributable to agency actions is having, or is likely to have, a measurable negative effect on migratory bird populations, focusing first on species of concern, priority habitats, and key risk factors” and to “develop and use principles, standards, and practices that will lessen the amount of unintentional take, developing any such conservation efforts in cooperation with the Service.” All of the bird species that are described in the “State-Listed and Special-status Species” sections of the draft ORV management plan/EIS are listed in 50 CFR § 10.13, which indicates species that are subject to the protections of the MBTA. These species  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  are also designated as Birds of Conservation Concern (USFWS 2008b) and/or Migratory Nongame Birds of Management Concern in the United States (USFWS 1995), which qualifies them as species of concern according to Executive Order 13186. Therefore, the NPS is required to protect these species according the provisions of both the executive order and the MBTA. Pursuant to the executive order, in April 2010 NPS and USFWS entered into a memorandum of understanding to establish how the two agencies will jointly promote the conservation of migratory birds by incorporating bird conservation measures into agency actions and planning processes.  83.  Large buffers have not proven successful at Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  “Areas closed for breeding shorebirds: should be limited to the smallest possible area and for the shortest duration as required. Excessive closures have not proven to be beneficial, have reduced visitation numbers greatly. At Hatteras some have declared successes due to these excessive closures immediately following their ORV Plans enactment, the nesting success rates have returned to pre-ORV Plan averages in subsequent years. Closures in anticipation of nesting is a further restriction of access to areas that may or may not be utilized for nesting. It is a peer reviewed fact that nesting shore birds are not dedicated to a given area but rather select areas that often differ from year to year and therefore the Superintendent should designate any required, minimal closures on an annual basis rather than using closures summarily defined by geographic limits.” (399882)  Cape Lookout National Seashore has determined that the proposed buffers are of appropriate size to protect shorebirds, turtles, and other species. These buffers are also removed as soon as possible when no longer needed.  Pre-nesting closures are based on the past 5 years of data. Over 20 years of monitoring data show that birds tend to return to the same location every year, making pre-nesting closures appropriate. These closures are timed to the arrival of birds. Further, pre-nesting closures are consistent with the USFWS recovery plans for protected species. See response #81 for more information on the differences between buffers at Cape Lookout National Seashore and those at Cape Hatteras National Seashore.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  84.  If bird populations increase, the Seashore needs a plan to address this so 100 percent of the Seashore is not closed.  “Under the proposed ORV plan, a combination of bird nests and turtle nests could theoretically result in closure of 100% of the beach to ORV use on South Core Banks and North Core Banks. The park service would be required to follow its rules at that time to protect each and every nest even to the extreme of closing all beaches. Clearly such closures would be in conflict with part of the parks mission of providing for recreational use by human beings. The park service needs to anticipate that such an extreme situation could occur and have a plan to manage it. Finding the right balance between protecting resources and providing for responsible recreational use is one of the most difficult decisions in developing a park management plan. If you do not plan for balance, then imbalance will likely result.” (399395)  The Seashore does not anticipate that the bird populations will increase at an exponential rate during the life of this plan (20–30 years) to create a situation in which 100 percent of the Seashore would be closed.   85.  Do not close historical nesting areas before birds arrive. These closures do not provide proper habitat. Instead create spoil islands for the birds.  “Do NOT enact the clause that closure areas (historically) will be closed before ORV's and birds arrive. This is ludicrous and smells of liberal groups. To close areas when nothing is happening does not make sense.” (399380) “Possibly the worst NPS practice has been the extensive use of Pre-Nesting closures. This has enticed bird life to nest on beaches with poor productivity thus increasing the pressure toward extinction. The sand spits around the inlets at Oregon, Hatteras and Ocracoke are prime examples of this condition. If NPS was serious about bird survival they would be working on the creation of dredge spoil islands and construction of good habitat near the salt ponds to provide better forage. Instead they have encouraged vegetative growth and loss of habitat.” (398193)  More than 20 years of monitoring by Seashore staff show that birds tend to return to the same location every year, making pre-nesting closures appropriate. These closures are timed to the arrival of birds. Further, pre-nesting closures are consistent with the USFWS recovery plans for protected species. The NPS considered creating habitat through various methods. Based on the experience of staff at the NCWRC, habitat-creation projects tend to be short-lived and labor intensive. Based on experience with hand pulling, herbicides, fires, and bulldozing, it was found that most of these techniques are effective for only one season before the vegetation returns. Covering areas with new dredge material has been shown to last longer, with vegetation returning after four to seven years (Cameron pers. comm. 2007). Although the NPS recognizes that creation of habitat may be viable under certain circumstances, it is not an appropriate substitute  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  for providing adequate protection of existing habitat. If this method were employed, it would be outside the scope of the ORV management plan/EIS and therefore was not included in the alternatives.  86.  Provide a bypass around bird closures, specifically in locations important to Seashore visitors (Cape Lookout Point, New Drum Inlet, Old Drum Inlet, and Ocracoke Inlet).  “Any area closed for resource protection must have a means of by-pass. The back roads often provide this but if there is not an accessible back road the superintendent should designate an alternative, combined pedestrian and ORV corridor by-pass.” (399280) “I mostly agree with Plan B or at the most a B/C combo. The changes I would make would be to make sure if there is a closure for bird or turtle nest then there has to be an alternative route around the nest.” (389856) “Access to Cape Lookout Point, New Drum Inlet, Old Drum Inlet and Ocracoke Inlets: While I do realize these locations are important to nesting shore birds they are also important to park visitors alike. Recreational opportunities like shell collecting, fishing, swimming, and wildlife enjoyment are at there best in these locations. An access corridor for ORVs and pedestrian use should be allowed even during peak nesting season. These locations are essential for park recreational opportunity. I believe that access and resource protection can be equally compromised in these locations.” (387746)  Current species management practices, and those proposed in the ORV management plan/EIS, allow for a bypass of species closures when the back route is available in the area. However, where a bypass is not possible the NPS Management Policies 2006 provide that “In cases of uncertainty as to the impacts of activities on park natural resources, the protection of natural resources will predominate.” (sec. 4.1). In these cases, a bypass may not be provided.   87.  Statements in the draft ORV management plan/EIS raise questions about the validity of studies and data at the Seashore.  “Piping Plover. &.more consistent training and supervision of resource staff conduction the surveys. This statement brings into question all prior studies involving wildlife at the Seashore and the results of the studies which may be the basis of the proposal to further regulate, restrict or ban the use of ORVs.” (399901)  Seashore Resource Management Staff currently receive adequate training necessary to monitor and collect data prior to field work, but like any organization, staff strives to continually improve its training and capacity, similar to other organizations. Previous studies and data collection were conducted in a sound, methodical manner.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  88.  The report by Dr. Godfrey states that passing vehicles cause less disturbance than people on foot.  Because of this, if an area is closed to vehicles it should be closed to people and pets.  “When attempting to protect nesting shorebirds the NPS Cape Cod ORV study by Dr. Paul J. Godfrey should be reviewed. Godfrey found: uSigns calling attention to the colonies should be posted at least 100 feet on either side of the colony, and visitors urged not to approach any closer. Vehicles can pass by much closer than that, but people leaving their vehicles will scare the birds and can lead to nesting failures. In short, passing vehicles cause fewer disturbances to nesting birds than people on foot.” (399803) “Extending the buffers will do nothing but close more beach to ORVs. Also, if an area is closed to ORVs it should be closed to pedestrians and dogs. You can easily drive slowly past birds on the beach and they hardly look up. Those that fly away are back within one minute. A person (and person with dog) scares a bird off the beach much more easily than people in a vehicle.” (387551)  As suggested by the commenter, areas closed for nesting are also closed to all uses including pedestrians, pets, and ORVs. Regardless of whether ORVs cause more or less disturbance, there is a risk associated with allowing vehicles to pass because pedestrians and pets may stop and exit the vehicle.  89.
