The location of ORV routes is within critical piping plover habitat and ignores impacts to migrating and wintering birds. More generally, vehicle-free areas have not been established for the purpose of wildlife protection and are in violation of Executive Order 11644 and the Organic Act.  “Similarly, the ORV route on the northern end of South Core Banks extends all the way to Ophelia Inlet. See DEIS at 161. Each of the alternatives that allow ORV access would, likewise, create ORV routes through piping plover critical habitat. See DEIS at 175-178 (showing critical habitat) and DEIS at 113-167 (depicting ORV routes under each alternative). The ocean intertidal and backshore habitat, as well as inlet spits, wet sand flats, soundside intertidal habitat, and overwash fans are not just important during the short breeding season each summer. They are also essential habitat for non-breeding shorebirds during migration and the wintering season (which can begin as early as July and last as late as the next June), yet impacts to wintering and migrating shorebirds are largely ignored by the DEIS in Alternatives AD. Disturbance associated with vehicular traffic during the migration and winter seasons for shorebirds has been identified as a significant threat in shorebird conservation plans and species specific conservation plans. Failure to minimize impacts to shorebirds and shorebird habitat from vehicular traffic does not comply with Executive Order 11644 and the NPS Organic Act. Long-term and adverse impacts to non-breeding shorebirds will result from Alternative D if implemented as presented in the DEIS. The DEIS acknowledges that failing to protect these areas for  In accordance with Executive Orders 11644 and 11989, the ORV management plan/EIS includes numerous measures to minimize impacts to Seashore resources. The draft ORV management plan/EIS acknowledges that impacts can occur, but strict routes and robust species protection measures mitigate and minimize these impacts.  The commenter notes that pedestrian-only areas do not serve as wildlife protection areas, while at the same time asking for the addition of pedestrian-only areas for wildlife protection. The Seashore’s primary goal with pedestrian-only areas is to ensure a variety of visitor experiences. Of course, some pedestrian-only areas are remote—including almost the entire soundside of the Seashore—and do not receive high visitation levels, which does in fact provide some level of species protection. Nonetheless, pedestrian-only areas are an incidental protective measure, and are hardly relied on by the Seashore for species protection.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  pedestrian-only use creates hazards for wildlife. It states that Alternative D could "increase the density of ORVs in areas that remain open to ORVs, potentially resulting in some increased impacts to piping plovers and their habitat in those areas." DEIS at 297. As the DEIS recognizes, the areas that Alternative D does designate as pedestrian-only "are not in key nesting habitat for piping plover, so the benefits to the species may be limited." ld NPS acknowledges similar impacts to other bird species. DEIS at 420. Yet the agency has not considered designating any vehicle-free areas specifically for the purpose of protecting "wildlife and wildlife habitat," as opposed to setting aside areas already heavily used by pedestrians to facilitate pedestrian use. At most, the DEIS considers wildlife protection as an incidental benefit of pedestrian-only areas designated for other purposes. See DEIS at 420 (describing potential overlap between recreation-based, pedestrian-only areas and nesting areas that could be expected to provide wildlife benefits).” (399250) “NPS Must Designate Additional Vehicle-Free, Pedestrian-Only Areas to Protect Wildlife. The designation of pedestrian-only/vehicle-free areas in the DEIS does not comply with Executive Order 11644. That order requires that "areas and trails shall be located to minimize harassment of wildlife or significant disruption of wildlife habitats." Exec. Order 11644, ï¿½ 3(2). With the exception of Shackleford Banks (a nine-mile long island designated as "Proposed Wildlife" under the federal Wilderness Act), NPS appears to have given no consideration to the needs of wildlife or wildlife habitat when designating pedestrian-only areas, much less to demonstrating that the proposed-ORV routes 'minimize" -impacts to wildlife. Each pedestrian only area on North Core Banks and South Core Banks is located in high-traffic pedestrian areas or areas used for non-motorized recreation, such as camping and kayaking. See DEIS at 6465. While we support the designation of these pedestrian-only areas that protect the variety of recreational opportunities at the Seashore, they do not address NPS's  Thus, while pedestrian-only areas may only provide an “incidental benefit,” the plan includes multiple other direct management and mitigation measures directed at species protection. Among these measures is the closure of the Seashore to ORVs from January 1 until March 14 each year, providing 25 percent of the year where wintering birds (including wintering piping plover) have an ORV-free area. During the time when ORV use is allowed, species closures are implemented which typically close from 6 – 25 percent of the Seashore to both pedestrians and ORVs. These closures are often used by migrating or wintering birds. Additional measures include limiting the number of vehicles to historically low levels (a limit at which species productivity has thrived), along with a robust adaptive management strategy monitoring impacts and further mitigating use if necessary. Additionally, even if an area is closed to ORVs such as middle Core Banks (when Old Drum Inlet is open) all shorebird nesting areas are marked with signs and are closed to pedestrians. Taken together, these additional measures squarely address requirements of Executive Orders 11644 and 11989 and the NPS Organic Act.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  obligation to designate ORV routes in a manner that protects wildlife. As the DEIS recognizes, inlets and washover areas are essential habitat for piping plover. For example, the DEIS states that New Drum Inlet "is now considered the most important site in North Carolina for the survival of this species." DEIS at 172. Yet it is uncertain whether NPS intends to protect piping plovers near New Drum Inlet at the southern end of North Core Banks nearest Ophelia Inlet. The DEIS shows this entire end of North Core Banks (also known as Middle Core Banks when New or Old Drum Inlet is open) as an ORV route. See DEIS at 159 (depicting ORV route on southern North Core Banks). The DEIS errata posted on the NPS PEPC website, however, show the three miles of beach on North Core Banks closest to Ophelia Inlet as a "Seasonal Summer Closure," but "only when Middle Core Banks is connected to North Core Banks." (4NPS, Errata Alternative D NCB Map 3 of 3 (20 14), http:/ /parkplanning.nps.gov/ document.cfm parkiD=3 59&projectiD= 15978&documentiD=60022.) Thus, it is unclear whether the highly valuable piping plover habitat at New Drum Inlet will be protected in a reliable and consistent way.” (399249)  91.  Use “no thru traffic” signs to open more beach areas and increase the buffer to 300 yards.  “Buffers for closures should stay the same at 200 yards. The use of No Thru Traffic signs would also open more beach even if the NPS increased the buffer to 300 yards.” (398791)  Placing “no thru traffic” signs would require ORV users to drive up to the sign, turn around, and drive back to other areas of the beach or the ramp, which may not encourage compliance. Establishing a ramp-to-ramp closure provides notice to drivers before they reach the closure and allows them to travel around closures more easily, resulting in better access and safety for ORV users.  92.  Further ORV restrictions will not lead to a greater piping plover fledge rate. Current rates  “All through the ORV/EIS Plan there is no evidence that would lead me, and others, to believe that further restrictions on ORV operations is warranted or will lead to a greater Piping Plover fledge rate. During the most productive year, 2011, the Piping Plover fledge rate of .90 was achieved,  The purpose of the ORV management plan/EIS is to establish designated ORV routes. Part of the process of designation is to ensure that adverse impacts to the Seashore’s resources are minimized. While ORVs are one factor that  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  have not been attributed to ORV use and could be the result of natural factors.  which falls well below the Recovery plan goal of 1.5 chicks per year (Pg. 173). As you stated in the ORV/EIS Plan, the cause of high chick mortality continues to be unknown& (Pg. 182); which easily leads anyone with common sense to realize that this could be attributed to any number of NATURAL factors instead of the presence of an ORV. Hillman states, The main drivers of nest and chick survival at CALO were flooding and mammalian predation in 2010 and 2011. (21) Not human activity including driving an off road vehicle! Borneman states in her report, Nest survival, chick survival, and productivity in study season were comparable or higher than overall levels in North Carolina from 19952012” (68) “Borneman also states, Predations was by far the GREATEST cause of nest failure (41.96% of total nests). Environmental elements, such as wind and storm overwash, were responsible for failure of 10.71% of nests and 7.14% of nests were abandoned. (68) Hillman also states The greatest threats to colonial waterbirds at CALO were predation and flooding &. Predators, primarily raccoons and to a lesser extent feral cats, gull-billed terns,, common terns, ruddy turnstones, ghost crabs and great horned owls, were the main cause of nest failure.. (28) Hillman also states, There was no EVIDENCE that overflights or HUMAN RECREATION contributed to nest failures whether directly or indirectly, particularly as nocturnal predators were the primary driver of nest failure and >90% of all known depredation events occurred at night when the Core MOA was inactive, non-Core MOA overflights were rare, and FEW RECREATIONISTS were observed. Borneman also states, I believe the current LOW levels of pedestrian activity at North Core Banks have MINIMAL reproductive consequences for nesting American Oystercatchers.” (72) (398140)  can impact species such as piping plover, the NPS does acknowledge that many other factors impact species as well.  The citations provided in the draft ORV management plan/EIS referenced by the commenter are correct. Should impacts from natural occurrences, such as predators, impact population numbers, the adaptive management strategy would address those impacts, and the Seashore would not default to restricting ORV use.  93.  The park should increase monitoring of protected species. Budget cuts have impacted the studies  “I think there is a tremendous need for more monitoring of protected species. During the six year period from 2008 through 2013, 28% of the American Oystercatcher nest failures at CALO were due to mammal predators (mostly raccoons), while 47% ere lost due to unknown causes. In  The Seashore agrees that additional research is beneficial and will continue to seek funds for this type of research.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  at the Seashore,  2011 on North Core Banks the number of unknown causes  having a negative  dropped significantly while the number of nests lost due to  impact. Increased  raccoons was way up. The reason for this dramatic change  monitoring could be  has nothing to do with ORV use or the population of  accomplished by  raccoons. NCSU did a research study for the USMC to  implementing new  evaluate the disturbance on shore birds due to airplane  technology.  flyovers. They recorded 45,000 hours of video at AMOY nests. As a byproduct of the research, there was clear video evidence of raccoons destroying AMOY nests. The video was proven to be a big improvement in monitoring AMOY nests for that one year. NCSU has conducted scientific research on the American Oystercatcher birds at Cape Lookout National Seashore from 1984 through 2013. The research is conducted by graduate students and has been funded by various grants. The park service has benefited by getting high quality free monitoring of the nesting and hatching activities as a byproduct of these research projects. The data from the monitoring is used to determine when protected birds fledge and subsequently when the beaches can be reopened to ORV use. Ted did not get any grant money for research at CALO in 2014, so the park service lost his valuable monitoring services for 2014. The park service did not add any staff to make up for this loss, due to tight budget so this is now a new deficiency. I recommend the park service exploit technology to monitor bird and turtle nests using less intrusive methods along with traditional boots-on-the-ground monitoring. Implement remote video recording technology, both with local data storage and with real-time radio transmission back to the park office. Implement motion sensing devices in turtle nests to alert biologists of impending nest hatching boils. Keep abreast of new and changing technology that has the potential to aid monitoring. Many companies are looking for harsh environments to test their new products. CALO should participate in beta site testing of new technology products that can improve the monitoring of protected species.” (397694)  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  94.  Current signs can be confusing or wash away. Add additional signs for clarity.  “The closures methods can be confusing with the exception of the ones that state detour. Others you dont know if you take the high line or the beach side! If someone has tracked across one or the other you are inclined to follow. Sometimes an unusual high tide displaces the stakes as well. Would additional stakes and or directional arrows assist driver in the correct path.” (389544) “I would suggest installing more substantial fencing and signage for the few nesting areas or other wildlife protections that may be required from time to time. I know very few, if any, visitors knowingly pass the roped and signed protected areas on the beaches. If there was better signage and/or more visible and substantial fencing identifying those areas, even fewer times would those areas be crossed.” (387933)  The NPS agrees that signs can be confusing and believes that the implementation of the educational certificate will further the understanding of posted signs. The NPS will also seek to improve and clarify signs at the Seashore.  95.  Nesting signs should not be put at the waterline where birds are not located, so that boaters can use the area.  “And for whoever is in charge of putting up the bird closure signs you should give us some room for high tide to anchor our boats to shore because you know the birds do not lay there eggs near the water line.” (387303)  Signs at the shoreline are established to protect nests as well as chicks and adults that use the intertidal area for foraging. These closures are not related to nesting, but to fledging and foraging and are necessary for species protection.   96.  American oystercatcher and piping plover closures should not be put into place until a chick is found using the beach.  “As provided in existing management (although it is not clear whether NPS staff follow this protocol), the full 300-foot or 600-foot buffers for American oystercatchers and piping plovers, respectively, should not be put in place until an American oystercatcher or piping plover chick is found using the ocean beach (To the extent that a resource closure results in certain areas being closed to fishing or hunting, except in emergency situations, NPS is required to consult with the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission and the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources prior to implementing the closure. 16 U.S.C. ï¿½ 459g-3. By prohibiting ORV use (either during a time of year or closing a certain area), the effect is to essentially close the area to fishing and hunting, and therefore NPS is  In following the mandate of the Seashore, as well as NPS management policies (also see response #82), the NPS must protect nests as well as the chicks. Nest protection includes prenesting and other closures which could result in beach closures where a chick is not yet present. Historical nesting areas where shorebirds are likely to nest are also protected, regardless of whether a chick is present.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  required to consult with these state agencies prior to implementing the closure.). The Coalition strongly objects to the expanded closures under Alternative C. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification to support expanding closures at the Seashore.” (399705)  97.  There is no rationale for the expanded closure under alternative C and these expanded closures are not necessary to protect the species.   “The expanded closure areas under Alternative C are not necessary to protect natural resources, minimize conflicts among users or promote visitor safety and are therefore arbitrary and capricious. Alternative C would create three new seasonal pedestrian-only areas and expand one pedestrian-only area. Approximately 79 percent of the length of the Seashore would be potentially available for ORV use from March 16 through the Thursday preceding Memorial Day and from the day after Labor Day through December 15. Approximately 74 percent of Seashore beach would be available for ORV use from the Friday preceding Memorial Day through Labor Day. Draft ORV Plan, pp. 46, 62. However, these percentages are simply a starting point and do not account for any other safety or resource closures that may be implemented. Draft ORV Plan, p. 45. "Based on data from 2008 to 2013, the total amount of ORV resource and safety closures at the Seashore averages approximately 10 miles during the summer months and approximately 5.4 miles during the fall. These closures protect approximately 22 percent more of the Seashore that would otherwise be open to ORV impacts during the summer months, and approximately 12 percent more of the Seashore during the fall months." Draft ORV Plan, p. 278. NPS provides no justification to expand the pedestrian-only areas. As  The purpose of the ORV management plan/EIS is to establish designated ORV routes. Part of the process of designation is to ensure that adverse impacts to the Seashore’s resources are minimized. While ORVs are one factor that can impact species such as piping plover, the NPS does acknowledge that many other factors impact species as well.  The pedestrian closures under alternative C meet multiple objectives of this ORV management plan/EIS including the following:  Manage ORV use to allow for a variety of appropriate visitor use experiences.  Minimize conflicts between ORV users and other users. Retain an experience where a family or individual traveling by ORV can experience the Seashore by finding a remote and otherwise unused stretch of beach.  Retain a non-ORV experience that allows access to a beach that is undisturbed by motorized uses.  discussed above, NPS has acknowledged that there is generally no conflict among users of the Seashore. Although visitation is relatively high in the summer, ORV use in the summer is relatively low. Further, non-ORV visitor use in the summer months is generally concentrated in the lighthouse area, while ORVs are dispersed throughout the Seashore. Draft ORV Plan, pp. 235, 243, 460-61. If Alternative C is adopted, there would be greater opportunity for conflicts   Ensure that ORV management promotes the safety of all visitors.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  among users. As acknowledged by NPS, "[t]he smaller percent of beach open to ORVs under alternative C compared to alternative A might result in increased crowding, which could result in reduction and greater impacts to those businesses that rely on Seashore visitation." Draft ORV Plan, p. 517.” (399702)  98.  Mile marker 44 to mile marker 45 should not have a seasonal closure.  “I recommend the extended back road and ramp from mile marker 44 to mile marker 45 (aka the bypass) should not have a seasonal closure. It should be open the same as the adjacent back road, except it should be closed whenever storms or excessive rains make it unusable. The ORV permit fees should provide enough funding for periodic maintenance of this ramp.” (389566)  The seasonal closure between mile marker 44 and mile marker 45 has been established due to water saturation in the area that makes the area become unpassable. For this reason, the seasonal closure in this area has been retained.  BACK ROUTE MAINTENANCE, PULL-OUTS, AND RAMPS  99.  Pull-outs should be included in the plan and these would prevent vehicles from driving in the grass, relieve congestion, and provide areas where vehicles can go during high water events.  “I think adding turn offs to the backroad is the best part of the proposal. A couple of those would be the best use of public funds and the most cost effective item on the proposal.” (384179) “The back road needs a number of passing turnouts to prevent vehicles from being forced into the grass. Better maintained back roads with passing turnouts would reduce the number of Off Road Vehicles using the beach.” (399967) “If more parking and camping areas were added along the beach and back roads they would relieve some of the supposed congestion in front of the cabins. These additional areas would also be a safety factor in times of storms and high water.” (399640)  The NPS agrees with commenters that additional pull-outs are necessary along the back route; pull-outs have been included in this plan. Refer to chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary – Vehicles” for further descriptions of these pull-outs.  100. Congestion on the back route could be reduced by the construction of a second bathhouse or by requiring visitors to park in front of the cabins. Providing camping along the back route was also suggested to reduce congestion.   “The new construction of a bath house facility on the South end of South Core Banks light house area would reduce the need for ORVs to travel back and forth to Great Island locations. In Fact adding a second bath house facility at the North end of the Great Island Camps would reduce the possibility of congestion. However, to my knowledge there has never be a congestion problem even during high usage periods such as the yearly Diff Club Fishing Tournament. Requiring park visitors using the cabins to park their vehicles in front of the cabins to put out their chairs, tents, coolers, etc. and not the bath house would also help reduce the appearance of congestion.” (399967) “Can we have some parking camping areas along the back roads? This would relieve some congestion from the area in front of the cabins.” (398882) “Rather than prohibiting ORVs in front of the cabin areas, NPS should increase the number and locations of the bath facilities.” (399717)  Building additional bath facilities is out of the scope of this plan. The NPS will continue to monitor what facilities are essential on the island and if additional facilities are deemed necessary, will undertake a separate planning process at that time. This plan does provide for pull-outs that would be used for emergency camping (refer to chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary – Vehicles”), but camping in these areas on a normal basis would not allow the pull-outs to be used for their intended purpose.   102.  Ramps should be placed every half mile.  “*It was mentioned in C to add five more ramps. It would be good to have ramps every half mile. These do not cost much to install and barely anything to maintain. This gives NPS  The ORV management plan/EIS does propose up to four additional ramps (refer to chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary –  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  more options when needing to create closures and leaves the visitor more open beach.” (399929) “It would be even better to add enough ramps to where there would be a ramp every half mile. These do not cost much to install and barely anything to maintain. The additional ramps would give NPS more options when needing to create closures due to nesting birds' etc. and at the same time leaving the visitor as much open beach as possible.” (399371)  Vehicles”). Additional ramps, such as ramps at ½ mile intervals as suggested by commenters, would create breaks in the dunes and makes the islands more vulnerable to overwash. Because of this, the NPS feels ramps at every mile are adequate, with ramp placement minimizing impacts to dunes. The NPS also believes that one-mile spacing meets the various objectives of the plan to protect Seashore resources while allowing public access.  103.  Back route maintenance will not address concerns related to storm events. For storm events, areas on high ground need to be established for emergency vehicle use (i.e., the Village, the old Gun Club, or near the Coast Guard buildings).  “However, this still doesn't solve the problem when there is a big storm. In case of severe, inclement weather, we need to be able to park in the Village or at the old Gun Club Location on South Core Banks. Both are on higher ground, as well as having wind break that trees and shrubs provide, and would offer better shelter than that of the back road. This is why the original settlers built their homes in these areas. Hundreds of years later, nothing has changed about where flooding occurs and what is safe and what is not on the islands. These areas could be opened when a gale or stronger winds are forecast. Placing a temporary or flip sign that states "Open for Inclement Weather" could be used at these locations for overnight parking or the duration of the storm.” (399863) “Emergency shelter should be determined, however the back road should not be considered. It is prone to flooding during heavy rain or wash over.” (399849) “I see a need for vehicle emergency storm shelters but don't believe the back road is the place for them. In case of severe weather, I recommend parking in the village, at the old Gun Club or on the concrete pads near the Coast Guard buildings. They are on higher ground and afford windbreaks. Designating these would not add any operating  As stated in chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary – Vehicles,” “Designated overnight emergency (storm refuge) parking areas would be established on each island along the back route, authorized on a case-bycase basis, to allow for overnight vehicle parking during times of adverse weather or unusually high tide events. (These emergency refuge parking areas would be established in areas that are not sensitive habitat for birds, turtles, or seabeach amaranth. Locations would also take into account topography, wetlands, and other potential limitations.)” Areas suggested by the commenters will be taken into consideration during these designations.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  cost.” (387638)  104.  The final rule should define the standard of maintenance for the back route and the term “would occur as necessary” in the draft ORV management plan/EIS should be clarified.  “I recommend the final ORV rule include the following definition of the level of back road maintenance: The back roads shall be maintained to a condition so that a typical ORV (e.g. Ford F-150) can be safely driven at the posted speed limit (i.e. 25 mph or 15 mph accordingly) during dry weather conditions.” (399800) “Maintenance of the back road is very important for ORV use. The term "would occur as necessary" does not describe what level of maintenance will be done. There are no published standards for the acceptable conditions of an ORV road in the sand. There are standards for state maintained paved roads and even for state maintained gravel roads, but they are not meaningful at CALO. This is not an easy thing to define. Common sense and judgment have guided the back road maintenance at CALO in the past with mixed results. We need to use our collective experience to develop a back road maintenance standard within the ORV plan.” (399796)  Per the ORV management plan/EIS, the back route would be maintained to allow safe passage of all ORVs in the park. Back route maintenance depends on available funding and conditions on the ground. Under the ORV plan, funding will come in part from ORV fee permits. If a greater level of maintenance is defined in the rule, cost recovery would dictate a higher permit fee.  105.  Ramps should not be added. They can serve as “funnels” during overwash conditions.   “No additional ramps. They can serve as funnels to the back road during over wash conditions.” (399824) “CALO does not need…3. Additional ramps, which would destroy more dunes.” (395370) “CALO does not need additional ramps. When the tide is really high, water follows the ramp to the back road. Adding more ramps disturbs more dune area. The NPS should manage the closures better such as how ramp 29 to 28 was done this year, with opening the beach to the edge of the buffer and not allow thru traffic to the next ramp. More ramps would not mean more access points depending on where the nest site is located, such as when a nest is next to a ramp, this would still close the beach for two ramps.”  The NPS agrees that ramps do allow for overwash. The number of additional ramps proposed meets plan objectives related to both resource protection and visitor use and experience. The current and proposed ramps allow the NPS to respond to the dynamic nature of the island. The additional ramps evaluated in this plan would allow for additional management flexibility that addresses the dynamic nature of the environment.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  (398785)  106.  Connect the cabin area from Ramp 29 to the back route.  “This is not stated in the ORV plan, but the NPS should connect the back road to the cabin area from Ramp 29. Anyone north of Ramp 29 is stuck if there is a high tide and cannot escape for emergencies.” (398784)  The NPS agrees and this was added to the ORV management plan/EIS. See response #1.  107.  Specific suggestions were made for maintenance and monitoring of the back route.  “I recommend that appropriate maintenance actions be selected to resolve the specific problems that may occur in the specific problem areas. The maintenance may include, but not limited to the following activities individually or in combination: a) Drag a sled made of steel chain or mesh to redistribute loose sand into the adjacent tire track paths to create a relatively smooth surface. b) Pull a heavy roller or equivalent machine over loose sand to compact it into a more dense composition. c) Move sand from an appropriate nearby source to the back road and distribute it uniformly to create a relatively smooth surface. d) Relocate the back road to a nearby route having a higher elevation. e) For chronic problem areas, create duplicate parallel paths that can be used for alternating cycles of two to three years each to allow for some natural healing during the years of non-use. This method was suggested by Dr. Stanley Riggs during a meeting that I attended at CALO headquarters. f) Scrap the back road with a hard blade to create a relatively smooth surface. g) Distribute spoil sand on the back road whenever doing maintenance dredging at the turning basins at the Long Point and Great Island ferry landings. h) Import crushed oyster shells or similar nature materials and distribute it uniformly on the back road to create a relatively smooth surface. i) Other methods appropriate for the identified problem and the available equipment and manpower.” (399799) “I recommend the back roads be monitored and evaluated monthly for the following variance conditions: 1) Shallow flooding of either fresh water, brackish water or salt water  The Seashore has committed to monitoring and maintaining the back route and a variety of methods could be used, via ORV permit fee. The use of dredging materials would be considered within the context of the permitting required.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  that does not drain within 24 hours after an event. 2) Holes greater than 4" deep that retain water. 3) Tire track paths greater than 6" deep that require a vehicle ground clearance greater than 6" to clear the sand between the tire tracks. 4) Undulations in the tire track path that cause a vehicle to react with severe oscillating motion in the pitch plane like a bucking bronco. 5) Washboard surface causing severe vibration in a vehicle. 6) A back road with relatively low elevation where the tire track path is 12" or more below the adjacent flat land.” (399780)  MISCELLANEOUS VEHICLE AND OPERATOR REQUIREMENTS – GENERAL  108.  Vehicle equipment should be recommended, not required.  “Vehicle equipment should be recommended, not required. …A. Change alternative b, c & d to read "the following equipment will be recommended (not required): tire gauge, shovel, jack, and jack support board."” (398975) “Vehicle Equipment Requirements: Modification to alternative B/C. 95% o the people I know carry all your required items , plus some. Trying to enforce these requirements would be a waste of man power. The size of the board, really? I would like to see these requirements dropped back to recommendations.” (398710)  It is the experience of the Seashore that the equipment required in chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary – Vehicles” is necessary to operate in a safe manner and to be self-sufficient on the islands. As stated in chapter 2, “Table 3: Alternative Element Summary – Vehicles,” a tire gauge, shovel, jack, jack support, and helmets are the only required equipment; other equipment is recommended.  109.  The length of support board required should be changed to a more common lumber size.  “REFERENCE: Alternative C, page 82 Table 3 Vehicle Equipment Requirements: COMMENT: The ORV plan for Alternatives B, C and D states "All vehicles (except ATVs and UTVs) shall contain a tire gauge (capable of registering 15-20 psi), shovel, jack, and jack support board (if wood, size requirement = 10Ã—12Ã—1.5 inches, if plywood, size requirement = 10Ã—12Ã—0.75 inches). I understand the intent of this statement, but the requirement for a board that measures 10x12x1.5 inches can be difficult to comply with. A popular common lumber size is a nominal 2X10. The cross-sectional size of today's 2X10 is specified as 1.50" by 9.25"  The NPS agrees with comments related to board size. Requirements for board length/size were revised to be a more common lumber size. The board requirement is 2 × 10 inches, 12 inches long, or the equivalent.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  but there is a 1/8 inch tolerance, so it measures 1.375" x 9.125" inches. The next size up is a 2X12 that measures 1.375" x 11.125". Likewise a nominal 3/4" plywood measures .718 and is frequently specified and marked as 23/32". I do not want to see anybody fined for a fractional difference in the size of a jack support board. I recommend the park service change the requirement to "a minimum nominal size of 2X10 at least 12 inches in length, if plywood, size requirement = 10"Ã—12"Ã—0.72" minimum nominal thickness", OR just make a generic statement like "a sturdy board for jack support".” (387476) “Vehicle equipment requirements - most of what is listed is common sense, but how exact do we need to read this document? A support for a jack board is listed as 10x12x1.5 inches, mixing nominal with exact dimensions. I believe you mean a 2x10 (nominal) cut 12 in length, minimum? I should also mention that plywood is not available in ï¿½ thickness - actual thickness is 23/32. Minor details, but the proposed plans give no level of infraction that could trigger loss of permit privileges, so we have to pay attention to details. We will have to live with this plan for 15 to 20 years, and therefore we may not always have the good judgment of current management or enforcement officers.” (390907)  MISCELLANEOUS VEHICLE AND OPERATOR REQUIREMENTS – VEHICLE LENGTH  110. This is especially true when the vehicle is being driven on the back route or  Based on the commenter’s suggestion, the NPS reevaluated the vehicle length restriction. The purpose of the restriction is to ensure that all vehicles on the Seashore can safely navigate the back route. The NPS agrees that there are multiple ways to meet this objective. Based on the comments, the preferred alternative has been revised to remove the vehicle length restriction. There would still be a 30-foot restriction on trailer length to address safety  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  should be when the vehicle is in motion. Due to different manufacturing specifications, tire pressure should not  “TIRE PRESSURE LAWS: Totally disagree, every vehicle and tire manufacturer sets safe operating instructions for the products performance. This number is not a chiseled in stone, by rather a tried and proven method which works for that particular vehicle with its particular equipment. Lighter  Text in the draft ORV management plan/EIS regarding tire pressure is a recommendation, not a requirement. Text in the final ORV management plan/EIS was clarified to reflect  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  be mandated.  ORVs and equipment can run lighter air pressures, while heavier ORVs and equipment will have to run heavier tire pressures. To mandate a specific air pressure for all ORV & equipment would create un-safe operating conditions such as blowouts, and roll overs.” (399965) “Tire pressure requirements should be set according to ORV type, not one-size fits all. NPS provides that when driving on designated routes at the Seashore, tire pressure must be lowered sufficiently (to 15 to 20 psi) to maintain adequate traction. The Coalition disagrees that there should be one tire pressure mandated for all ORVs. Every vehicle and tire manufacturer sets safe operating instructions for the products performance. This number is not the same for all ORVs or tires, but rather is a tried and proven method which works for that particular vehicle with its particular equipment. Lighter ORVs and equipment can run lower air pressures, while heavier ORVs and equipment will have to run higher tire pressures. To mandate a specific air pressure for all ORV and equipment would create unsafe operating conditions such as blowouts and roll overs. The Coalition objects to requiring ORVs to maintain a tire pressure between 15 and 20 psi, which would create unsafe conditions. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification for this provision.” (399719) “Changing tire pressure regulations to 15-20 psi maximum is crazy. There is no way I can run that low a pressure with our truck and camper. Our tires require 50 psi for road travel. I run 22 psi in the front and 26 psi in the rear with a 2500 plus lb. load. Years of experience driving on the sand tells me when I have the pressure right and when its too high. Not only are the Rangers going to be asking to check our fish coolers, tire pressure also! NPS might as well restrict the type of tire we use too.” (398778) “The proposal to limit tire pressure to 15 to 20 PSI is arbitrary and should be changed to allow for higher pressure for large campers. If campers were required to run this low  this.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  pressure it would cause blow outs and create dangerous situations. One way to do this would be to use a percentage of the manufacturers limit right on the tire casing.” (393497)  114. Text in the final ORV management plan/EIS was clarified to reflect this. As such, the NPS will not be checking tire pressure of Seashore visitors.  ORV ROUTES AND AREAS  115.  Add additional ORV areas including the north side of the rock jetty on South Core Banks, the north end of the island, and the soundside.  “Another suggestion - give us back a little of the beach that you have taken away in the past. This would help tremendously with the way the park service is viewed by the ORV community. Specifically, could you open up 200 yards of beach on the north side of the rock jetty on South Core Banks? That area of the beach has become very wide, and there is no wildlife or fauna that would be endangered. Not only is there good fishing in this area, but it would also make a safe camping area for those in vehicles or tents. This would be a great gesture on your part. I hope there is also an area on the North Core Banks that could be reopened showing a sign of good faith on the park services' part.” (398973) “From my readings, the plan seems to hint that ORV users are to blame for concerns not necessarily objectively measured or noted as their fault. I suggest opening up more areas for ALL users that are not closed nesting sites, such as; more of the North end of the island, more access to the sound side, and more areas South, beyond the rock jetty.” (389849)  Pedestrian-only areas, and therefore areas where ORVs would be allowed, were determined in part by considering past and current use patterns. The majority of the closures (all closures except those at the lighthouse and Power Squadron spit) are seasonal and do allow for all users to access these areas during other times of the year, except in the case of species closures. For the areas closed year-round, these closures were primarily based on either high visitation of pedestrians or on reducing potential user conflicts. Additionally, year-round ORV closures would provide a benefit to species using the area. In regards to Lighthouse Beach, this is one of the most popular sites for visitors. Based on pedestrian ferry operation data provided by the ferry operators, visitors access this area during the summer and into the fall. It is anticipated that with the new pedestrian ferry service, there would be more consistent visitation in the fall  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  months. The Power Squadron Spit area (including the rock jetty area) is a longstanding closure to ORVs to reduce user conflicts with boaters and others using this beach. The NPS believes this user separation is needed and it will remain in place under the preferred alternative.  However, in the final ORV management plan/EIS, the preferred alternative was revised to allow for additional ORV access in some areas where it was determined that the pedestrian-only closure should be adjusted. Under the revised preferred alternative, the area 0.7 mile to the south of the lighthouse would only be closed seasonally, May 1 to September 14. However, existing pedestrian closures (at the lighthouse and Power Squadron Spit), would remain closed year-round to ORVs. This would maintain pedestrian-only access in key areas, while addressing the fact that visitation changes seasonally in the area south of the lighthouse.  Changes were also made in the preferred alternative to the pedestrian-only areas in front of the cabins. The NPS revised the preferred alternative in the final ORV management plan/EIS to include an ORV corridor at the dune line to pass through these areas to address concerns about public safety in the camps and reduce interaction with pedestrians. Specifically, at Great Island a corridor would be established from the mid ramp in the Great Island Camp to the north (ramp 29a to 29b). From mid ramp south, the beach would be open to ORVs. At Long Point, ramp 16 –- 17a would be closed, and the rest of the area open, although a corridor would be established on the ocean  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  beach to allow ORVs to pass through, which would keep ORVs from the cabin areas. These pass-through areas would be in place May 1 to September 14. See response #1 for further information. The north end of South Core Banks is typically open to ORVs, except for safety reasons or seasonal species protection closures. The ocean beach is closed to vehicles when piping plover chicks are in the area.   116.  The final plan should include a study of the road design and park facilities, and how these would adapt to changing conditions.  “The scope of this draft ORV plan includes back roads and ramps for ORV vehicles and long-term parking lots. It does not include a comprehensive study of the road design and cabin layout within the Great Island camp. I recommend the final ORV plan include a recommendation for a future comprehensive study of the Great Island camp cabins, other structures and associated road pattern design. The study should identify future alternative routes in anticipation of continued storm overwash and westward migration of the dune line. The park service should anticipate future loss and replacement of cabins, fish cleaning stations, RV dump stations and bath houses at new locations and associated new roads. The study should also include alternative cabin camp locations if the current locations become unusable due to frequent overwash or the creation of an encroaching inlet. The addition of a second bath house and associated parking area should be planned.” (389543)  The Seashore acknowledges that it is a dynamic and changing environment. How facilities would be replaced to adapt to these conditions is outside the scope of this plan and would be addressed in a separate planning process. However, the scope of this plan does address the current design and maintenance of the back route, which takes into consideration the dynamic nature of the Seashore. See response #99, #100, and #102 for more information on back route and ramp design under the preferred alternative.   117.  The COLREGS Lines of Demarcation should not delineate what is considered beach and what is not. This designation should not be used in the plan for  “They seem to have decided that the "COLREGS Lines of Demarcation" as noted on page 65 of the ORV plan has some relevance as to what is a beach and what is not a beach. The COLREGS Lines of Demarcation are a part of "The International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea" which was adopted as a Convention of the International Maritime Organization on October 20, 1972 and  The COLREGS Lines of Demarcation is an established line of what is considered ocean and what is considered sound. Currently, and under the preferred alternative, soundside areas are closed to ORV use. The Seashore will continue to use the COLREGS Lines of Demarcation to determine soundside versus  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  designating ORV  entered into force on July 15, 1977. They were designed to  oceanside beaches.   routes and areas.  update and replace the Collision Regulations of 1960, particularly with regard to Traffic Separation Schemes. Various regional rules preceded it. Rule 1 says "These Rules shall apply to all vessels upon the high seas and in waters connected therewith navigable by seagoing vessels." The purpose of the regulations is solely to avoid collisions of large ships. The COLREGS Lines of Demarcation define the boundary between waters governed by domestic navigation rules and the waters governed by these international navigation rules. Large seagoing vessels do not pass through Ophelia Inlet. The COLREGS Lines of Demarcation has absolutely nothing to do with driving on the beach. There is very little difference between the beach of Ophelia Inlet and the beach of the Atlantic Ocean. Both beaches experience normal tide changes. Both beaches can experience high water from wind driven high tides. Both beaches have changing slopes and contours. The main difference is during calm weather the waves on Ophelia Inlet beach are smaller than in the ocean. The ORV plan says on page 80 that there is no "soundside" driving. I agree with that statement. The soundside is the shoreline of Core Sound. Core Sound is brackish water with much less salinity than the ocean. Because of the lower salinity, it is a vegetated shoreline with cord grass growing both above and below the mean high tide line. The Atlantic Ocean and Ophelia Inlet beaches do not have any vegetation at their mean high tide line. The ORV plan states on page 239 "ORVs can be used only on the oceanside beach...". I recommend that the park service abandon all use of the COLREGS Lines of Demarcation for determining ORV access to beach driving. The wording on page 239 and any other similar references should state "ORVs can be used only on the oceanside and suitable inlet beaches." The park service should relocate the posts to a suitable place near the intersection of Core Sound and Ophelia Inlet.” (389536)  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  118.  Estimated ORV use areas overstate the areas that ORVs can use and are misleading.  “Estimates of the % of CALO currently available for ORV use are very misleading. Estimates presented by NPS are based on the notion that ORVs can cross existing inlets and can currently drive from the low tide line to the sound and any points in between. ORVs can currently drive on a very narrow backroad and from the low tide line to the dunes where signs do not prohibit driving. ORVs cannot cross inlets.” (387458)  The NPS recognizes that the inlets were not factored out of the percentages but these areas are not considered closures. Were the inlet areas to be deducted from the overall total, the change would be minimal. Although commenters were concerned about these areas not being counted, future conditions could result in a greater area being open to ORV use. Because the Seashore landscape can change, should these areas reconnect to a larger area or other areas of the Seashore grow, these areas would be available for ORV use.  Because of the dynamic nature of the Seashore, determining the exact area open to ORV use is difficult and is often changing. Therefore, the NPS feels that these estimates are accurate. In the future, the Seashore landscape will continue to be dynamic and more areas could be added or more inlets could be created.   119.  Some areas of the Seashore should not be closed to ORVs, even for species, because of their importance to visitors. These areas include Cape Lookout Point, New Drum Inlet, Old Drum Inlet, and Ocracoke Inlets.   “Cape Lookout Point and all inlets on both islands need to be accessible at all times even during peak nesting season. These areas are prime locations for recreation like fishing, shelling and swimming. Please don't let the big money lawyers from the deceitful groups like the Audubon ruin this awesome and ever changing island.” (387326) “Access to Cape Lookout Point, New Drum Inlet, Old Drum Inlet and Ocracoke Inlets: While I do realize these locations are important to nesting shore birds they are also important to park visitors alike. Recreational opportunities like shell collecting, fishing, swimming, and wildlife enjoyment are at their best in these locations. An access corridor for ORVs and pedestrian use should be allowed even during peak nesting season. These locations are essential for park recreational opportunity. I believe that access and resource  The Seashore recognizes that certain areas are important to visitors.  The NPS Organic Act gives NPS broad authority and discretion to manage the sometimes conflicting goals of resource conservation and visitor enjoyment and to determine how visitor activities, including recreational activities, may be managed to avoid or minimize impacts to natural and cultural resources. However, the express text of the Organic Act does not mandate that NPS equally balance preservation with public use in making its management decisions. Courts have held that the Organic Act places an overarching concern on preservation of resources in the  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  protection can be equally compromised in these locations.” (38318)  management of national parks. Since the act speaks of but a single purpose, conservation, where the goals of resource preservation and user enjoyment conflict, preserving the resources takes precedence. Thus, the NPS interpretation of the Organic Act as allowing the Seashore to manage appropriate recreational uses in the interest of resource protection is consistent with the act and is a proper exercise of discretion. When not closed for species, designated areas would be open to ORV use. Current species management practices, and those proposed in the ORV management plan/EIS, allow for a bypass of species closures when the back route is available in the area. However, where a bypass is not possible, the NPS Management Policies 2006 require that “In cases of uncertainty as to the impacts of activities on park natural resources, the protection of natural resources will predominate.” (sec. 4.1).   120. If the island does not contain a ferry landing, then ORV use would be prohibited. For example, as of January 2013, Middle Core Banks is severed from ferry service and is closed to ORV use; the island and its portion of the back route would become accessible to ORV use if Old Drum Inlet closes and Middle Core Banks becomes accessible to vehicles (i.e., if Middle Core Banks reconnects  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  new island that could be called "lighthouse island", assuming a vehicle ferry landing could be arranged there? b) What if a new inlet is formed at the Great Island camp, destroying most of the cabins and the dock? If significant changes to the landscape of the Seashore limit access to large areas, this decision could be revisited, and would require a separate planning process.  121.  The range of alternatives analyzed was too narrow. Even under the most restrictive alternative, too much of the Seashore is designated for ORV routes.   “According to these authorities, these routes and areas must be designed to protect wildlife and other natural resources, ensure the safety of all visitors, minimize conflicts between the various vehicular and non-vehicular uses of the Seashore, and conserve the Seashore's natural resources for future generations to enjoy. The DEIS does not, however, fully comply with these requirements. The DEIS analysis improperly and unnecessarily limits the alternatives considered to essentially two alternatives with respect to ORV routes on North Core Banks and South Core Banks- either designating nearly the entire beach front as an ORV route or eliminating ORV use entirely. These choices do not cover a "reasonable range of alternatives," as the National Environmental Policy Act ("NEPA") (42 U.S.C 4321- 4370f) requires.” (399241) “Here, the stated objective of the Cape Lookout ORV Management Plan/EIS Alternatives is "to manage ORV use in compliance with" the federal laws listed above, in order "to ensure protection of the natural, cultural, and recreational values of the Seashore's dynamic coastal barrier island environment for present and future generations."( See NPS, Cape Lookout National Seashore ORV Management Plan/EIS Alternatives Newsletter (2012), http:/ /parkplanning.nps.gov I document.cfm ?parkiD=3 5  The Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) NEPA regulations (40 CFR Part 1500 et. seq.), Department of the Interior NEPA regulations (43 CFR Part 46 et. seq.), and NPS Director’s Order 12 require that a full range of alternatives be analyzed in an EIS. NPS has complied with that mandate in the ORV management plan/EIS, with each alternative providing different management approaches and reasonably different levels of access to ORVs from a mixed range of use to no ORVs at the Seashore (see alternative E). The commenter claims that the amount of access granted ORVs at other national seashores is lower, but the commenter misstates the amount of access available to ORVs under alternative D during the summer nesting and breeding season, and does not address key management and operational differences that in practice place additional limits on ORV use to protect resources. For example: Cape Lookout National Seashore is completely  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  9&projectiD= 1597 8&documentiD=48062.) By failing to evaluate any alternatives that permit some ORV use but prohibit it in sensitive wildlife habitat, or to give any consideration to wildlife habitat when designating pedestrian-only areas, NPS has violated the laws that the plan purports to comply with. As in Defenders of Wildlife v. Salazar, NPS in the present case has not provided any "substantive evidence in the record which demonstrates that the decision to" allow driving in certain areas "was made with the objective of minimizing impacts." 877 F. Supp. 2d 1271, 1304 (M.D. Fla. 2012). Instead, NPS has proffered alternatives "whose 'primary beneficiaries' are the 'park visitors who [drive ORVs] in the parks."' Fund for Animals, 294 F. Supp. 2d at 108. As the DEIS recognizes, giving preference to ORVs over wildlife "violate[s] the NPS primary mandate to preserve the Seashore's natural and cultural resources unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations .... " DEIS at 70. NPS must consider impacts to wildlife when determining initially whether or not to designate ORV routes, not simply in determining what buffers to use once an ORV route has been designated. NPS must consider not only impacts to breeding wildlife, but impacts to the non-breeding shorebirds that rely on the Seashore for wintering and migrating habitat outside the breeding season as well. It has not done so in the DEIS. We recommend that the following areas, at a minimum, be adjusted to include additional vehicle-free areas on the ocean-facing beaches.” (399252) “The expansive ORV routes authorized by Alternative Dare unnecessary and unreasonable when evaluated in the context of ORV management at other national seashores on the East Coast. Cape Hatteras National Seashore, also in North Carolina, recently implemented a regulation limiting its ORV routes and areas to 61 percent of the beach, with 42 percent available for driving year-round and 19 percent available only part of the year. NPS, "Final Cape Hatteras National Seashore Off-Road Vehicle Management Plan/Environmental Impact Statement," at 108 (Nov. 2010).  closed to off-road vehicles three months out of the year. No other national seashore has a complete three-month closure as a restoration measure. Only 63 percent of beaches at the Seashore are available to ORVs during the sensitive reproduction periods (May 1 to September 14), not 73 percent as stated by the commenter (which is the percentage available without closures). This is in line with 61 percent at Cape Hatteras National Seashore, despite the lower number of vehicles at Cape Lookout National Seashore (in fiscal year 2015, Cape Hatteras National Seashore issued approximately 30,000 permits – weekly and annual combined, whereas Cape Lookout National Seashore is proposing 6,200 permits annually). In addition to these baseline closures, species protection measures have typically closed an additional 6– 25 percent of the Seashore during sensitive nesting and breeding periods (essentially late spring through early fall). Thus, at some points, ORV use may only be allowed on 38 percent of the Seashore’s beaches under alternative D. Additionally, these percentages only account for percent of beach access available, not the overall acreage of the Seashore. The majority of the Seashore is in fact inaccessible to ORVs, including the entire soundside, which is off-limits to ORVs due to its geographic nature (bogs, swamps, etc., where ORVs could easily get stuck or sink). Alternative D includes proposed 3,250-foot species buffers for highly mobile piping plover broods, which could decrease the percentage of area available to ORVs during the key summer months of species reproduction beyond the  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  Notably, Cape Hatteras designated 26 of its 67 miles as year-round vehicle-free areas, and excluded them from its ORV routes, including areas that serve as high-quality wildlife habitat on Bodie Island Spit, South Beach, and Hatteras Inlet (on both Hatteras Island and Ocracoke), and remote areas between ramps 27 and 30 and between ramps 32.5 and 34. !d. at 191-197. Other Seashores are even more protective of wildlife habitat. Cape Cod National Seashore allows driving on only 21 percent of its beaches, Fire Island National Seashore on only 27 percent of its beaches, and Assateague Island National Seashore on 50 percent. Canaveral National Seashore, Cumberland Island National Seashore, Gulf lslands National Seashore, and Point Reyes National Seashore do not allow any ORV use at all. In contrast, Alternative D, the most restrictive of the proposed Cape Lookout alternatives that allow any ORV access, allows driving on 73 percent of its beaches and falls well short of the mandate to protect natural resources by limiting ORV use.” (399251)  typical 6–25 percent additional reduction in access due to species buffers, and, if necessary would close the beach to ORV traffic during this sensitive time. Vehicle capacity limits: this plan proposes vehicle capacity limits based on typical use levels. Thus, while the use is already much lower than use at Cape Hatteras National Seashore, this plan ensures that use will not grow. The current use level has proved sustainable for species. Adaptive management: under this plan, staff will continually monitor American oystercatcher as an indicator species, and adjust management measures accordingly. Ultimately, NPS has analyzed a reasonable range of alternatives, including alternative D,  which offers the most resource protection aside from the environmentally preferred alternative of not allowing ORVs on the Seashore at all (alternative E). Although alternative D could allow up to 73 percent of the Seashore beaches open to ORVs, in reality, species protection measures greatly reduce this percentage at key times. These additional closures reduce ORV access, and fully round out the reasonable range of alternatives evaluated by NPS in this plan.   SHADE SHELTERS  122. Establishment of shade shelters further limits ORV use because of use and parking restrictions.  “Why are the Shade Shelters included in this? is it to inflate the cost of implementing the ORV plan? We can't use them because we can't park within 100' of them. We don't need them it's the pedestrians who need them. We have the shelter of our ORVs.” (384995) “Shade Shelters Not necessary Too much $ to maintain 100 ft buffer around them could close off fishing areas” (392178) “Why are Shade Shelters proposed in the ORV plan? Pedestrians need shelters; the owners/operators of ORVs have shelter in their ORV. Additionally, ORV owners are not allowed to park within 100' of shelters, such as the one in front of the Lighthouse.” (387891)  The 100-foot restriction on camping at a shade shelter applies to all users. This restriction is for camping and not fishing or parking; therefore, ORV parking near these structures is permitted. The restriction on camping ensures the shade shelters are available to as many people as possible and cannot be used as a campsite for the length of stay of a single visitor or set of visitors.  VEHICLE DELIVERY (INCLUDING OPENING/CLOSING DATES)  124.  Do not change the current dates the Seashore is open to ORV use.  “Proposed driving dates - Driving needs to be March 15 - December 31st The park needs to remain open to vehicles until December 31. That is a special time of year. It is a time of year that families have time to be together and enjoy the park. There are fewer people, no bugs or nesting birds or turtles. And the fish are there. It is hard enough to not be able to access the beach via ORVs come January 1, but we have accepted that limit. Please do not change it to December 15th.” (398801)  The Seashore has revised the preferred alternative so that the dates for the ORV season are March 15 – December 31. This change has been reflected in the final ORV management plan/EIS.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  125.  If year-round use is considered, it may not be viable if the needed services are not provided.  “It has been brought up about the park being open year-round for vehicle use. I am not sure how cost effective that would be for the vehicle ferry operators unless the NPS was willing to have facilities open such as the cabins and bathhouse.” (391120)  The Seashore is not proposing a year-round ORV closure under the preferred alternative. As stated in chapter 2, “Table 5: Additional Species Management Measures not in the Cape Lookout National Seashore Interim Protected Species Management Plan / Environmental Assessment, Biological Opinion, Amended Biological Opinion, or FONSI,” the wintering closure, “…would provide habitat for wintering species, allows the beach profile to recover from heavy fall fishing use, and would ensure that all vehicles are removed from the Seashore at least once a year so that state vehicle safety inspections could be updated and maintenance completed.” The Seashore feels that the wintering closure is important, but a year-round closure to ORVs is not necessary to achieve the goals and objectives of this plan.  126.  The ORV rule should also include information on longterm ferry concessioner services.   “I recommend the final ORV rule include a schedule for developing long-term ORV ferry service concessionaire services to support the expected 15 to 20 year life of the ORV plan.” (399895)  Concession management is outside the scope of the ORV plan, and would require a separate planning process.   127.  Allow year-round use, and year-round delivery of vehicles – closure for three months is not justified. The additional 15 days of closures under the preferred alternative is not  “PARK OPERATIONAL PERIOD: When I began talks with the National Park Service at Cape Lookout National Seashore about beginning a ferry business I was told I would be able to transport visitors to the seashore park the entire year (12 Months) It took me three years to obtain all the building permits, CAMA permits, and the ferry and bait and tackle shop constructed. When I went to get my permit I was told the park closed December 31st and reopens March 15th or 16th the following year. We were not allowed to transport vehicles to the island January, February, or the first  Although there is a seasonal restriction on ORV use at the Seashore, the Seashore is not closed to all visitors year-round. During the times of seasonal ORV closures, the park is open to pedestrian visitation by passenger ferry or private boat. "[T]he Seashore is a dynamic coastal barrier ecosystem, and visual effects of ORVs on ocean beaches may no longer be visible in a day due to daily tidal action, winds, rain, hurricanes, and other storm events." As stated in chapter 2, “Table 5: Additional Species Management Measures not in the Cape Lookout National Seashore Interim Protected Species Management Plan / Environmental Assessment, Biological Opinion, Amended Biological Opinion, or FONSI,” the wintering closure, “…would provide habitat for wintering species, allows the beach profile to recover from heavy fall fishing use, and would ensure that all vehicles are removed from the Seashore at least once a year so that state vehicle safety inspections could be updated and maintenance completed.” The Seashore has revised the preferred alternative in the final ORV management plan/EIS so that the dates for the ORV season are March 15 – December 31.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  (399707) “NPS has provided no rationale justification to close the Seashore to ORVs from January 1 to March 15 (let alone expand this time period) and such a prohibition is arbitrary and capricious. ORVs are currently prohibited at the Seashore from January 1 to March 15. Under Alternative C, the winter Seashore closure would be extended to include from December 16 through March 15. NPS provided several reasons for closing the Seashore to ORV use in the winter, including: (i) opening the Seashore year-round to ORV use would not meet the objective to minimize impacts on natural physical resources, wildlife, and wildlife habitat and vegetation; (ii) the winter closure allows for the mandatory removal of all vehicles from the Seashore once a year; (iii) the winter closure would allow the Seashore time for natural recovery from the impacts of ORV use; and (iv) the winter closure would reduce the cost and time burden on the Seashore for enforcement when visitation would be at its lowest. None of the justifications has any merit. Winter closure of the Seashore is not necessary to minimize impacts on the Seashore's natural resources and wildlife. Breeding piping plovers generally arrive in mid-March. Further, impacts are already "minimized by the fact that much of the habitat where migrating and wintering piping plovers are found is protected through permanent ORV closures which include Shackleford Banks, Portsmouth Flats, the interior of the point of Cape Lookout, the beach between mile markers 41a and 41b, and the Power Squadron Spit." Draft ORV Plan, p. 276. Red knots are not present at the Seashore in the winter, and sea turtles do not nest at the Seashore in the winter.” (399706)  128. Recommend alternate times for night driving closure, including the following:  10 pm to 5 am  allow movement at dusk and daybreak Unrestricted nighttime driving should be allowed on all the back roads and in the Great Island and Long Point camp areas. Nighttime driving on the beach should the following restrictions from 9 pm to 6 am during the summer season: (a) no driving from ramp to ramp on the beach; (b) the only driving allowed is from a parked location to the nearest ramp.  “No night driving- I think this would really effect the cabin rentals, as would not like having to leave fishing at the best time, maybe no traveling between 10:00pm to 5:00am” “Night time driving restrictions can be shortened to allow movement at dusk and daybreak.” (391229) “The light from the headlights of a vehicle driving on the back road at night is not constantly shinning on the beach or ocean due to the blockage effect provided by the dune line. The gaps in the dune line will allow some intermittent light to shine on the beach and ocean. This occasional intermittent light is not enough to be a problem for sea turtles. A good example of the effect of intermittent light on the beach and ocean is the CALO lighthouse that flashes every 30 seconds 24 hours a day. Figure 16 on page 204 shows the highest number of sea turtle nests at CALO are between mile marker 42 and 44. There is also good nesting success between mile marker 39 and 42. Due to the natural curvature of the shoreline, all of the beaches between mile marker 39 and 44 are within clear view of the flashing light coming from the lighthouse which does not deter the turtles. All protected species have closures on the beach to prevent ORVs from driving in those critical areas during nesting times. Those closures provide the same protection to chicks and hatchlings at night as they do during the daytime. Nighttime driving does not increase risk because the young protected species are within the protection of the closures. I  The Seashore, in consultation with the USFWS, reviewed the various suggestions on changes to times in night driving and has determined the proposed times under the preferred alternative (9 pm to 6 am) would be most appropriate for resource protection. However, the Seashore does recognize the unique nature of the environment and has revised the preferred alternative to allow for ORVs to drive on the back route and in the camps between 9 pm and 10 pm, and between 5 am and 6 am, which will allow extended time for fishing and movement from daybreak to dusk. The Seashore evaluated driving to the nearest ramp from the beach, but this was deemed unenforceable and would ultimately still allow beach driving at night, which would not sufficiently protect species.  Night driving will be allowed at any time inside the cabin areas. The following restrictions would be placed on night driving:  January 1 – March 14: Seashore closed to ORV use.  March 16 – April 30 and September 15 –  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  recommend that unrestricted nighttime driving be allowed on all the back roads and in the Great Island and Long Point camp areas. The Loggerhead Recovery Plan states as a recovery action “Prohibit nighttime driving on beaches during the loggerhead nesting season,” and prohibiting night driving through September 14 will allow the Seashore to continue to comply with the recovery plan and its goal of recovering sea turtle populations.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  The following restrictions would be placed on night driving:  January 1 – March 14: Seashore closed to ORV use  March 15 – April 30 and September 15 – December 30: All designated ORV routes open 24 hours a day  May 1 – September 14: Designated ORV routes on the beach would be open from 6 am to 9 pm. Banning night driving would create safety issues, such as being able to react quickly to changing weather.  “BAND ON NIGHT DRIVING: I feel this could be a safety issue, causing hazards to visitors who may need to relocate their ORVs due to un-planned high tides, storm conditions, medical emergencies, etc.” (399954) “At a minimum, provision needs to be made for nighttime driving in the event of actual emergency, ie, medical or weather related.” (399902)  The Seashore recognizes the importance of visitor safety and the need for actions to be taken in emergency situations.
