Data  Impacts to sea turtles and shorebirds from driving on the beach at night are not necessarily limited to physical injuries or death, and due to few NPS night patrols, most impacts would go unrecorded. Vehicle movement and lights at night can disturb females while attempting to  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  does not support banning night driving. Turtles and birds are not being run over.” (399844) “They are related to personal opinion and not peer reviewed (K.A. Schofield 1995) or to stationary lights rather than passing motor vehicles with lights. None of the citations really determines that driving on a back road comparable to that on South Core Banks poses a significant danger to wildlife.” (387465) “Prohibiting ORV use at nighttime would result in significant impacts to ORV users; however, NPS provides no evidence that ORVs impact shorebirds or sea turtles as a result of nighttime driving and nighttime viewing impacts are minimal. Therefore, the prohibition of nighttime ORV use is arbitrary and capricious. NPS has failed to support its proposed night driving ban with any data. There have been no recorded deaths or injuries of sea turtles at the Seashore as a result of ORVs. Draft ORV Plan, p. 353. Further, NPS acknowledges that more information is needed to determine the effects, if any, of night driving on nesting sea turtles as the Seashore. Draft ORV Plan, p. 52. "False crawls" at the Seashore are nearly identical to false crawls under normal, undisturbed conditions. Draft ORV Pan, p. 353. Based on this data, nighttime driving has had little to no impact on nesting sea turtles at the Seashore. Moreover, as NPS has acknowledged, "many different factors can contribute to false crawls, and no definitive assessment exists of how the level of ORV use, or any other recreational use, may influence sea turtle nesting activity." Draft ORV Plan, p. 353. Similar to sea turtle data, there is no evidence of death or injuries of shorebirds and other protected species at the Seashore as a result of ORVs. NPS also acknowledges that ORV closures around protected species not only protect such species from ORV traffic during the day time, but also at night. Draft ORV Plan, p. 281.” (399700)  nest and cause false crawls. False crawls (aborted turtle crawls that do not result in a nest, also often referred to as nonnesting crawls) can be detrimental to sea turtles and can be caused by, among other things, suboptimal sand conditions; encounters with roots, debris, or rocks while digging a nest; encounters with obstacles while crawling up a beach; disturbance from lights, noise, or other unusual activities; or other reasons that are not known. Too many false crawls for one individual can result in turtles shedding their eggs in the water and, thus, those eggs would be lost (Witherington and Martin 1996). Although the percentage of false crawls compared to all nesting activity at the Seashore on average is consistent with false crawls in undisturbed areas, it has ranged as high as 61.5 percent in any given year at the Seashore (refer to the section “Federally Listed Endangered, Threatened, or Candidate Species” in chapter 4). Since false crawls are rarely witnessed, it is difficult to attribute a specific cause to any one occurrence. While the NPS cannot control many of the factors that can cause a false crawl, it does provide the required protection for sea turtles from factors it can address, such as disturbance from vehicle lights and driving at night.  Although there have been no instances of direct mortality of nesting sea turtles at night from ORVs at Cape Lookout National Seashore, at nearby Cape Hatteras National Seashore there was one instance of an adult nesting turtle being struck and killed by an ORV in 2010 (NPS 2010h). There have been three instances of nesting sea turtles being struck by ORVs in the State of Texas (Shaver 2004 and Shaver 2009).  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  These incidents indicate that the potential does exist for vehicles to strike and kill nesting sea turtles. With regards to hatchlings, as detailed in the section “Federally Listed Endangered, Threatened, or Candidate Species” in chapter 4, the sea-finding mechanisms in emerging hatchlings are complex and involve cues from both brightness and shape. Studies indicate that strong brightness stimuli can override competing cues (Witherington and Martin 1996). Hatchlings tend to orient toward the brightest direction over a broad horizontal direction, which on an undeveloped beach is often toward the open horizon of the ocean. However, light pollution, such as that from ORV headlights, beach fires, or lights from nearby residences or other developments, can cause emerging hatchlings to become disoriented (meander or circle) or misoriented (led in the wrong direction) (Witherington and Martin 1996). Night driving can also adversely impact shorebirds. American oystercatchers and Wilson’s plovers are known to be active at night (Simons and Schulte 2008; Morrier and McNeil 1991) and would be subject to noise and habitat disturbance, as well as the potential for injury or mortality, from the presence of vehicles and pedestrians at night. This disturbance can impact their foraging behavior and has been shown to result in disorientation and even abandonment of oystercatcher chicks (Simons and Schulte 2008). However, there are few NPS night patrols, so while most impacts at night go unrecorded, it does not mean that they do not occur.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  135.  The proposed night driving ban should be extended until October 31.  “Please extend the driving ban to October 31, and restrict night driving to allow hatchlings at least a fair shot at making it to the water without being crushed.” (395920) “Additionally, the Park Service is allowing for night driving on the beach to occur while some sea turtle nests have not fully hatched. This could greatly impact the ability of hatchlings to safely return to the sea. To remedy these flaws in the plan, the Park Service must designate appropriate buffers for sea turtles (at least 350 feet) and extend the night driving restriction to October 31.” (387677)  As stated in response #129, the ORV night driving closure May 1 through September 14 adequately covers the nesting times at the Seashore, therefore it was not extended. A restriction is not needed during the hatching season, because the beach in front of a sea turtle nest is completely closed to vehicles prior to turtles hatching.   136.  Night driving restrictions would have negative impacts on visitors and visitation because popular activities, such as night fishing, could not take place.  “Nighttime Driving Exemption under Option C would limit fishing areas for your patrons which would: A. negatively impact patrons to visit the island and rent the cabins and B. decrease the economy of the local businesses in the area. Most patrons of the South Core (Davis Island) and North Core (Portsmouth Island) can not afford slide-in campers on a 4 wheel drive truck or are not equipped to tent camp. Rather, many more fisherman and patrons rent the rustic cabins. The best fishing is usually at dusk and dawn. Nighttime driving restriction would mean the fisherman would have to drive back to the cabins many miles and at least an hour before dusk to avoid getting a ticket. That alone will eliminate many users and fisherman from visiting the park. … Also, I submit that nighttime driving helps keep predators at bay that may otherwise dig up turtle nests or kill baby birds before they fledge.” (384154) “The Coalition strongly objects to any nighttime prohibition of ORV use because as acknowledged by NPS such a prohibition will result in "noticeable long-term impacts on ORV users." Draft ORV Plan, p. 489. This prohibition will also significantly limit access to and use of the Seashore and will have significant economic impacts. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification to support its proposal to  In response to public comments, the Seashore extended the period of time night-driving is allowed, which would allow fishing from 6 am to 9 pm, and 5 am to 10 pm along the back route. Fishing is not prohibited at night, but studies, USFWS recommendations, the Interim Protected Species Biological Opinion, and the best professional judgment of the Seashore’s resource management staff have concluded that a night-driving restriction during sensitive times for species is necessary. As noted under “Socioeconomics” in the final plan/EIS, if implementation of ORV regulations resulted in a 30 percent reduction in ORV visitation, it would result in an impact of less than 0.20 percent on output and employment in the ROI.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  prohibit nighttime ORV use.” (399701)  137.  Only prohibit night driving in specific areas where nesting is known to occur.  “I am sure in the reams of data the NPS and others have collected on nesting turtles, there are areas where nests are likely or probable on CALO, and other areas where nests are unlikely or never found. It should be relatively simple to place a night time driving ban on selected areas, leaving other areas open for access and avoiding conflicts.” (399914)  Turtle nesting can occur along the length of the Seashore; therefore, a Seashore-wide night driving restriction is required. However, ORV driving will be allowed 24 hours a day from March 16 through April 30 and September 15 – December 31.  138.  Night driving could deter predators, and therefore be beneficial to species.  “Driving at night may actually be beneficial to both turtles and birds when vehicle presence deters the activities of nocturnal predators.” (399880)  NPS was unable to find scientific studies to support this claim.   139.  Allow night driving, but with a reduced speed limit.  “Solution: A. Consider allowing night time driving with reduced speed limit.” (398971) “If you must put a 10 mph speed limit , that would certainly seem to be curtailing enough to prevent any impact to wildlife.” (398173)  When considering management actions to protect nesting turtles, vehicle speed is not a key factor. The main source of impacts is from lights, including ORV headlights. For more information on the impacts of ORVs and light pollution on nesting turtles, refer to the section “Federally Listed Endangered, Threatened, or Candidate Species” in chapter 3. Limiting speed would not address plan needs and objectives related to species protection.  140.  Require vehicle equipment such as different lens types, and allow night driving.  “Review research on latest technology for different color, types of lens, illumination and intensity of lights that could be used for night time driving.” (398971)  Having specific light standards would require Seashore staff to inspect all vehicles on the beach at night to enforce compliance, which would increase administrate and law enforcement costs. These costs in turn would need to be incorporated into the ORV permit costs. To keep the costs of the ORV permits at a reasonable level, and to better ensure compliance, the NPS has determined that night driving restrictions, rather than specific equipment requirements, are the preferred  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  course of action.  141.  Reflectors should be installed in wildlife areas and closures to make them more visible for night driving. Blue reflectors should be added at the entrance to each cabin.” (389564)  Although installing reflectors would increase visibility at night for ORV drivers, this would not eliminate concerns related to light impacts to nesting turtles (refer to the section “Federally Listed Endangered, Threatened, or Candidate Species” in chapter 3 for more on light impacts). However, the Seashore will investigate whether using reflectors on the signs to improve visibility during times when driving is allowed.  142.  Instead of a night driving ban, make restrictions on how long headlights can be on while a car is not moving.  “My suggestion if you do make a decision to limit driving at night, "why not have a rule like you cannot sit with your headlights on for some length of time like 5 minutes, that you must be moving or in motion". This would limit headlights being shined in one spot for to long.” (387739)  Light is a primary concern for nesting turtles (refer to the section “Federally Listed Endangered, Threatened, or Candidate Species” in chapter 3). Allowing use of headlights, even if limited, does not eliminate the impacts of light on nesting turtles and therefore was not considered for the preferred alternative.   ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT  143.  A single indicator species should not be used for the adaptive management strategy and is statistically and scientifically problematic. More than one species should be used.  “AMERICAN OYSTER CATCHER AS INDICATOR SPECIES I have become somewhat familiar with the reasons for the AMOY selection as CALO "Indicator Species". It is an NC species of concern, nests up and down the beach and is sensitive to disturbance. I think, however, it is flawed science to choose a single species. Management of a National Park and a major user group of that Park based on measurements of a single species is statistically and scientifically problematic. In my mind, the Park has the responsibility to manage all wildlife. Would it not be reasonable (and supportable) to create a "basket" of species indicators with goals for each expressed as a single composite number, and manage the Park and ORV use  The adaptive management strategy was developed in consultation with multiple experts in the field and the USFWS. The USFWS concurred that the use of the American oystercatcher as an indicator species was appropriate. This species works as an indicator species for the adaptive management strategy because it is widespread throughout the park and the factors affecting the productivity of this species also affect all other nesting shorebirds at the Seashore. Therefore, the plan will continue to use the American oystercatcher as  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  based on that indicator? A single species indicator is risky since population vagaries are hard to account for in the short run (and the long run).” (387471) “The danger with using a single species indicator is the possibility of all other species maybe thriving while the selected species is lagging behind. So the beach gets shut down regardless. There should be more than just one species selected and all should show a 20% cushion below the target goals before action for closures are put into place.” (399943)  the indicator species for adaptive management.  144.  Management actions taken under the adaptive management strategy do not account for nonhuman causes of impacts to species.  “Furthermore, Step 1 of management remedies does not (as written) take into account non-human causes for negative indicator impacts such as storms or mammalian predation. Therefore, if in a single year, a major impact is triggered for 2 goals - regardless of the cause - Park management is committed to take action detrimental to ORV use” (387471)  The adaptive management process does take into account all factors impacting the species. As stated in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, a variety of actions could be implemented, many of them targeting nonhuman use. Management actions under the adaptive management strategy will first target known impacts to the species and will not automatically default to further ORV restrictions.  145.  There needs to be a cushion established before thresholds are triggered. Suggestions for cushions included:  20 percent  10 percent  “At last, there are some doubts in my mind about the trigger thresholds. They are not consistently formulated in the same way and minor impacts are triggered at levels not recently achieved in the Park in some cases. In others, minor impacts are triggered with only a single reduction in breeding success. These are too tight and need some reasonable cushion from current statistics before an triggering a minor impact.” (387471) “The danger with using a single species indicator is the possibility of all other species maybe thriving while the selected species is lagging behind. So the beach gets shut down regardless. There should be more than just one species selected and all should show a 20% cushion below the target goals before action for closures are put into place.”  The triggers for adaptive management were established based on the available data and the professional judgment of the experts consulted by the NPS to develop the adaptive management program. These triggers were designed to capture other impacts to the species, not just ORV impacts, with a variety of responses that address both the human and natural causes of these impacts. The NPS feels the stated triggers are appropriate to capture the impacts, and two triggers must be met before a management response is initiated. Management responses do not automatically target ORVs, and sufficiently account for variability, thus a 10–20 percent cushion is not  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  (399943)  needed. Furthermore, the commenter did not provide any data or scientific studies to  “All indicators should have a 10 percent "cushion" below the  establish the percentage cushion suggested.  goal before a minor impact is triggered.” (399923)  146.  The strategy, including Step 1, should include the same text as Step 2 regarding impacts from non-ORV sources.  “Also, Step 1 under "Adaptive Management Strategy should include the language that is in Step 2 regarding "hurricanes, or other strong storms, predators, or other natural conditions not tied to impacts from visitor use". Rationale behind Change … Step 1 should also provide the same flexibility that is provided in Step 2 for management decisions that are triggered due to natural conditions and not ORV use.” (399923) “Also there needs to be some language put in the "adaptive management" plan concerning over wash, hurricanes, predators and other natural conditions. This year is a fine example of what an early hurricane can do to nesting birds.” (399373)  The NPS disagrees with the comment that adding text regarding hurricanes will add flexibility. Step 1 represents management actions that could be taken but are not required; Step 1 provides maximum flexibility. Step 2 represents management actions that would be required when certain conditions are met; Step 2 has less flexibility than Step 1.  147.  The adaptive management strategy needs to document the cause of species decline so that ORV users are not penalized for non-ORV impacts.  ““Adaptive Management Strategy" Any decrease of wildlife populations needs to documented as to what exactly the cause is? The ORV users and all visitors should not be penalized for the loss of wildlife or fauna due to Hurricanes and Nor'easters or even Gales, extreme high tides, higher ocean levels, predatory animals, or other natural occurring detriments.” (399858)  The adaptive management process takes into account many factors impacting the species, including natural and human causes. As stated in the section “Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, a variety of actions could be implemented, many of them targeting non-human use. Management actions under the adaptive management strategy will target the impact to the species and will not automatically default to further ORV restrictions. For example, if predation is increasing, the Seashore may implement additional, focused trash management and fish scrap disposal or additional predator control, rather than changes to ORV management.   148. The Seashore needs more accurate data to develop the adaptive management strategy, including to accurately identify the date that bird and turtle eggs are laid, and their location.  “The goal of future CALO monitoring resources should be to accurately identify the date that eggs are deposited at each bird and turtle nest and record its location. This data will provide the ability to predict the expected hatching dates. Closely monitoring each nest until hatching and fledgling will reduce the number of unknown nest losses and provide more accurate data that will be useful for Adaptive Management actions and other purposes. More accurate data will also help the park service know when to close and when to reopen ORV closures which is good for ORV users. I recommend the target and action values for the Indicator "% Nsts Lost to Mammal Predation per Year" be used as proposed in the ORV plan along with parallel improvements in monitoring.” (393423)  The Seashore already monitors on a daily basis for sea turtle and shorebird nesting, and has been monitoring sea turtles and piping plovers since 1990 and American oystercatchers since 1995. The GPS coordinates and the date the nest were first observed are recorded. Because of daily monitoring activities, Cape Lookout National Seashore is able to predict expected hatch dates. Even with daily monitoring, many nests and chicks are lost for unknown reasons.  150. I have not completed the remaining years 2007 through 2003 due to the time required to manually review and analyze the data. I generate a stacked bar chart called "Cause of AMOY Nests Lost". It shows the total number of nests lost each year with subsets broken down by the cause and the island identification. A hard copy of this chart was also given to the park superintendent at the Charlotte public meeting on June 19. It was included in the spreadsheet that I e-mailed to the park superintendent. The "Cause of AMOY Nest Lost" chart shows that the causes of nest failure include natural events, native predators, mammal predators and unknown. Very few nests were lost due to ORVs, only one in the past three years. During this six year period 28% o nest failures were due to mammal predators (mostly raccoons), while 227 nests (47% o 485) were lost due to unknown causes. In 2011 on North Core Banks the number of unknown causes dropped from an average of 15 down to only 6 while the number of nests lost due to raccoons was up from an average of 6 to 26. The reason for this dramatic change has nothing to do with ORV use or the population of raccoons. NCSU did a research study for the USMC to evaluate the disturbance on shore birds due to airplane flyovers. They recorded 45,000 hours of video at AMOY nests. As a byproduct of the research, there was clear video evidence of raccoons destroying AMOY nests. The video was proven to be a big improvement in monitoring AMOY nests for that one year.” (393422)  optimal management that is flexible to adjust to this variability. The flexible management plan will help the Seashore deal with the uncertainty inherent in this natural variability. Management of predators to address predators as causes of nest loss is also important. The NPS emphasizes the importance of continuing monitoring and research to continue to improve our understanding of the relationship of factors that affect breeding success.  “The indicator called "Chicks Fledged per Breeding Pair per  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  Year" shows high variability. I can only hope that beneath the data there is some understanding by the CALO professional staff as to what drives this indicator and why it has experienced such high variability. This is a very desirable goal that the park service should work toward achieving in the long term. However, the trigger levels should be changed to a range of 0.35 to 0.25 for minor impact and changed to < 0.25 for major impact for the purpose of Adaptive Management actions. There is something fishy about this set of data. There may be some inconsistencies with the reliability of the field observations or some other underlying problem. ORV restrictions should not be made more restrictive due to future results of this indicator that has had such high level of unexplained fluctuations in the past.” (393421)  151. An annual public forum should be held each year in January or February to meet the requirements for public engagement under Department of the Interior adaptive management guidelines.  “The Department of Interior publication "Adaptive Management, The US Department of the Interior, Applications Guide" on page 49 states: "Stakeholders bring different perspectives, preferences and values to decision making. Managers can strengthen their decision making by involving stakeholders in framing a decision problem, identifying its objectives and models, and even developing and implementing monitoring protocols. It is important to have at least some stakeholder engagement in all the set-up elements of a project, and to continue that engagement throughout the project." One way to help the park management to make more informed decisions is the establishment of a formal Advisory Committee consisting of stakeholder representatives from all outside interest groups. Such Advisory Committees must meet the requirements of the federal FACA which typically become very structured and costly. A better solution to provide continued stakeholder engagement is the use of an annual public forum. The public forum engages all interested parties to participate in open non-binding discussion with the local park  A focused, stakeholder-involved, collaborative approach will help to refine and set long-term adaptive management objectives to guide future ORV management actions. As part of this process, stakeholders and the public will be engaged to ensure the Seashore fully understands key issues and concerns and to work collaboratively on developing a suite of appropriate metrics to monitor impacts and reduce key uncertainties. Any changes to ORV permit levels beyond the initial 6,200 limit proposed will be made through a civic engagement process.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  service management. It is an opportunity for the park service to share the resulting data from the previous year's indicators along with historic trends and other relevant information. Interested parties could surface questions to get clarifications on the data etc. The park service could describe their plans for changes to improve the indicator results. The park service could list alternative plans and seek comments on the merits of the proposed alternatives. The forum attendees should have an opportunity to propose new and creative solutions for consideration by the park service. The forum should be scheduled in January or February before the park service management has reached any decisions on operational changes to be implemented when the park opens on March 16. The forum should be held in Carteret County or at a central location such as Raleigh, or both. The purpose of the public forum is for the park service to gain additional perspectives from knowledgeable outside interested parties to improve their decision making. However, no decisions would be made by the park service during the forum. I recommend the final ORV plan include a commitment to hold an annual Adaptive Management public forum for at least the first five years use of Adaptive Management.” (389562)  153.  The role of horses on Shackleford Banks should be recognized when looking at the success of species at the Seashore, and should be addressed in the adaptive management strategy.  “The park service should collaborate with the Foundation for Shackleford Horses and other professionals to develop new management techniques that will provide better protection for the species of concern on Shackelford Banks while not jeopardizing the continuation of the controlled herd of horses that live there. I recommend the final ORV plan should be modified as follows: a) The sentence on page 57 "Disturbance to American oystercatcher (an indicator species) would be monitored, primarily related to impacts from ORVs." should be modified to read " Disturbance to American oystercatcher (an indicator species) would be monitored, primarily related to impacts from ORVs and horses." b) The list of potential Adaptive Management actions on page 57 needs to expanded to include "Manage  Horse management is outside the scope of this ORV management plan/EIS. However, species management measures in this plan are applicable to Shackleford Banks, except for ORV specific requirements. Before taking action under the adaptive management strategy, the NPS will review the data to ensure the impacts in non-ORV areas, such as Shackleford Banks, do not result in additional ORV restrictions.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  the horses on Shackleford Banks to ensure that they do not adversely impact the indicator species".” (389533)  PREDATOR MANAGEMENT/PREDATOR REMOVAL  154.  The NPS should not remove one species in favor of another; predators should not be removed.  “Removal of predators - I am totally against the park service removing any animal from the park that is to be euthanized, Native or Non-Native species. If they must be removed there should be a place to relocate them. What give NPS the right to play GOD and decide which animals should go? In the long term plan perhaps it is the birds that dont belong. Seagulls are a predator too, but you cannot remove or kill them. PETA may be interested in your actions.” (387557)  The NPS has exclusive jurisdiction over the wildlife on its land and can set criteria for any wildlife management tool to ensure that it is consistent with NPS and park-specific mandates, as well as other federal policies. This includes the management of predators. NPS Management Policies 2006, section 1.4.3, states that NPS managers must always seek ways to avoid, or to minimize to the greatest extent practicable, adverse impacts on park resources and values. Section 1.4.5 further elaborates, stating that “[t]he impairment that is prohibited by the Organic Act and the General Authorities Act is an impact that, in the professional judgment of the responsible NPS manager, would harm the integrity of park resources or values, including the opportunities that otherwise would be present for the enjoyment of those resources or values.” NPS Management Policies 2006, section 4.4.2.1, allows for the management of native species to prevent them from interfering broadly with natural habitats, natural abundances, and natural distributions of native species and natural processes. NPS Management Policies 2006, section 4.4.2, also states that the NPS will rely on natural processes whenever possible, but may intervene to manage wildlife or plant populations under certain conditions. One such condition is when "a population occurs in an unnaturally high or low concentration as a result  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  of human influences (such as loss of seasonal habitat, the extirpation of predators, the creation of highly productive habitat through agriculture or urban landscapes) and it is not possible to mitigate the effects of the human influences."  These authorities allow for the NPS to manage and remove predators to meet the management objectives for threatened and endangered species. Further authority to manage predators for the protection of endangered species can be found in Section 2 of the Endangered Species Act, which reads, “all Federal departments and agencies shall seek to conserve endangered species and threatened species and shall utilize their authorities in the furtherance of the purposes of this Act.”  155.  Improved predator management should be used, including improved trash management.  “Buffer Zones: -how about a better predator management program? i asked Rikard how many birds, turtles, etc. are killed by ORV's...pretty sure the number was ZERO! how many were killed by raccoons, foxes, other birds, snakes, coyotes? cant remember the number but they have it in their data. What about trash management? instead of having rangers constantly "collecting data" and law enforcement "interacting" with ORV users...HAVE THEM PICK UP TRASH...trash leads to more animals looking for food. PUT SOME TRASH RECEPTACLES(and recycling-which currently DON'T EXIST) AT THE LIGHTHOUSE AND HAVE PARK SERVICE PERSONNEL "MANAGE" IT! It is completely absurd to think that the busiest area of the park has NO trash or recycling bins! It is nice to think that people "should" be responsible(ie pack it in, pack it out) but most ARE NOT! Manage existing problems(trash, predators) instead of creating ones that have a perceived impact.”  As stated in chapter 2, “Table 5: Additional Species Management Measures not in the Cape Lookout National Seashore Interim Protected Species Management Plan / Environmental Assessment, Biological Opinion, Amended Biological Opinion, or FONSI,” the plan does recognize and address limited predator management. The Seashore is currently seeking funding for a more comprehensive predator management plan. In regards to trash management, trash is managed in the Seashore though a pack in/pack out system. The Seashore is a trash-free park, except in the camps, to prevent having large containers of trash that attract predators. Raccoons occur throughout the park  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  (387391)  but a larger number occur around the camps. The Seashore has documented unfledged shorebirds killed by ORVs prior to some of the protective measures that are currently in place. The reason that species are not currently “killed” by ORVs is because of the existing protective measures. The Seashore recognizes the need to broaden awareness of trash management to all visitors to the Seashore. Visitors must recognize there is a link between trash management and protection of sensitive species, and the NPS will seek ways to improve this education.  ALTERNATIVE A  156.  Ways to reduce costs under alternative A should be explored.   “I would also request that you explore ways in which to reduce the cost under alternative A. I don't recall there ever being any effort to solicit input from the public on ways in which the Seashore might be operated more efficiently. That seems like a gross oversight on the part of the NPS.” (384166)  Under current management, NPS budgets have remained relatively unchanged, and the Seashore looks for cost efficiencies in daily operations. The public is welcome to provide comment on cost-saving measures at any time.  In regards to concerns about public outreach on Alternative A, the no-action alternative, it represents the preferred alternative of the Interim Protected Species Management Plan and public comment was solicited during that process through a full civic engagement process under the National Environmental Policy Act. Alternative A also includes elements from the General Management Plan, which also included a full civic engagement process. Further, alternative A was presented to the public as part of the range of alternatives during this planning process and comments on the range of  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  alternatives were solicited at that time.  157.  For the range of alternatives evaluated, commenters provided numerous ideas on different mixes and combinations of alternative elements. For each alternative, a sample of the types of mixes proposed include the following: Alternative A could be modified to include additional elements related to education, changing species buffers, implementation of permits and permit fees, increased predator control, improvement of the back route and addition of pull-outs, emergency shelter areas, etc. Alternative B would be acceptable with some changes including no permit limits, change in vehicle length, changes in the educational permit, changes to the  “A combination of Plan A with some elements of Plan B, makes the most sense to me and is the most cost effective". *Reflects long-standing ORV use at the Seashore and is consistent with park planning documents OVER PREVIOUS DECADES, including the Seashores general management plan (NPS 1982) and general management plan amendment (NPS 2001e), which permit ORV use. Approximately 81ï¿½/o (45 of 56 miles) of the entire length of the seashore would be designated as available for ORV use from March 16th-December 31st. 19ï¿½/o (11 of 56 miles)would be available to pedestrian-only use year-round; all 56 miles of shoreline would be available to pedestrian-only use from Jan 1st-March 15th. Species management measures would be the same as those for Plans B, C, D, E. The back route would be retained in its condition as of 2010, and would receive no regular maintenance. ~I think than Plan A is the best and most cost effective, however there are a couple of additions that should be considered". 1-Pull-offs along the back route to allow vehicles to pass other oncoming vehicles should be established. (As stated in Plan B). 2-Occasional maintenance should be done on back route. (As stated in Plan B). 3-Emergency areas to escape storms should be determined, but on the back road is not a good idea. We tried that in a bad nor-easter, the road ended up flooded and we were forced to retreat to long term parking at the Lighthouse. There, at the Coast Guard Station, and at the old Gun Club; which already exist and have trees for shelter are safer and are already established, saving money on trying to create an new safe haven. Chief Ranger Munyun said that this is a consideration but the concern is possible misuse. If the Ferries can take us to CALO and we can drive on CALO without a problem why  Alternative A is presented in the document as the no-action alternative and is required to be a stand-alone alternative for analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act. The NPS is required to evaluate a range of reasonable alternatives. Key elements of the range include establishing ORV routes, species management, adaptive management, etc. While the NPS agrees that other alternative elements could be created that represent a different mix, NPS has addressed the key criteria for ORV management through the current range of alternatives and feels that the range of alternatives is appropriate. Although some elements are common to all action alternatives, which is common and accepted in NEPA practice, the action alternatives contained numerous different alternative elements. NEPA regulations require agencies to evaluate a range of alternatives, including the no-action alternative. Therefore, the NPS has fulfilled the requirements of Section 1505.1(e) of the CEQ NEPA regulations by evaluating in detail five different alternatives with numerous differing alternative elements as well as the full range of alternatives that includes those considered but dismissed from further analysis. The “agency's preferred alternative” is the alternative that the agency believes would fulfill its statutory mission and responsibilities, giving consideration to economic, environmental, technical, and other factors. Alternative A is working, meets the laws and purpose of the park, is not considered to be an impairment of resources, and therefore should be implemented.  “There is no data which identifies or supports the need for the National Park Service to implement the proposed laws governing the use of the National Seashore Park. In fact, the data I've been able to obtain and study clearly identifies the measures currently in place are working and that Alternative A would meet and satisfy the Law Suits as a working Off-Road Vehicle Plan. It is working and the data the National Park Service, N.C. State University, and others collect clearly show an increase in the numbers of birds and turtles. The best numbers since the park has been recording data on these species.” (399948) “As discussed above, Alternative A is working. There has been a general increase in the number of breeding piping plover pairs at the Seashore since 2004. "Although the fledge rate in 2009 was slightly lower than in 2004, the fledge rate for piping plovers at the Seashore increased 350 percent from 2008 to 2011, but declined in 2012." Draft ORV Plan, p. 182; see also Piping Plover Monitoring at Cape Lookout National Seashore, 2013 Summary Report. The red knot relative abundance at the Seashore has generally  Alternative A provides a useful baseline of impacts from current management during a part of the planning period for the long-term ORV management plan/EIS. As described several places in the FONSI for the Interim Protected Species Management Plan/EIS, management under Alternative A was considered to have no significant impacts during the 3-year period it was to be in effect before the long-term plan was developed and approved for implementation. The related biological opinion issued by the USFWS also evaluated the impacts of the Interim Protected Species Management Plan/EIS based on the understanding that it was a short-term action. The purpose, need, and objectives for the Interim Protected Species Management Plan/EIS are different than those of the longterm ORV management plan/EIS, focusing on species protection, rather than the designation of ORV routes and areas. As a long-term  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  increased from 2006 to 2013. Red Knot Monitoring at Cape Lookout National Seashore, 2013 Summary Report. The number of American oystercatcher nesting pairs and chicks fledged has also increased from 2004 to 2013. American Oystercatcher Monitoring at Cape Lookout National Seashore, 2013 Summary Report. The number of least tern at the Seashore has generally increased from 2006 to 2013. Cape Lookout National Seashore Colonial Waterbird 2013 Summary. The number of sea turtle nests at the Seashore has steadily increased from 2007 to 2013. Cape Lookout National Seashore, 2013 Sea Turtle Monitoring and Management Report .” (399704) “It is important to recognize that NPS no impairment clause, 16 U.S.C. 1, does not prohibit any impacts to the Seashore's resources and values. Rather, NPS has "the discretion to allow impacts to park resources and values when necessary and appropriate to fulfill the purposes of a park, so long as the impact does not constitute impairment of the affected resources and values." NPS Management Policies 2006 ï¿½ 1.4.3. NPS is mandated not only to conserve the natural resources and values of the Seashore, but also to provide public access for recreation. 16 U.S.C. ï¿½ 459g-4(a) ("The Secretary shall administer the Cape Lookout National Seashore for the general purposes of public outdoor recreation, including conservation of natural features contributing to public enjoyment.") As recognized by NPS, many visitors to the Seashore (56 miles of barrier islands with no improved roads) rely on ORVs to access these recreational opportunities. In fact, NPS personnel also rely on ORVs to perform their functions at the Seashore. As provided in NPS Management Policies 2006 ï¿½ 1.5, "[w]hen proposed park uses and the protection of park resources and values come into conflict, the protection of park resources and values predominate." In this case, there is no conflict. NPS has determined that Alternative A protects natural resources, minimizes conflicts among users and promotes visitor safety. Not only does Alternative A meet these objectives, the Coalition agrees that the following  management plan, alternative A would not meet the criteria of the executive orders or the NPS regulations for designation of ORV routes, nor would it meet the purpose or resolve the need for the long-term ORV management plan/EIS.  The “agency's preferred alternative” is the alternative that the agency believes would fulfill its statutory mission and responsibilities, giving consideration to economic, environmental, technical, and other factors. NPS identified the preferred alternative as alternative C because it best meets the objectives of the plan, as detailed in the section “How Alternatives Meet Objectives” in chapter 2.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  additional measures are appropriate to further these objectives: formal designation of ORV routes, additional ORV operator education and certification, improved maintenance and design of the back route, additional shade shelters, and additional education and outreach. NPS should adopt Alternative A along with these additional measures ("Modified Alternative A") as its preferred alternative .” (399672) “ Alternative A, a continuation of existing conditions and management policies, is consistent with the Organic Act, the Cape Lookout Enabling Act, the Executive Orders and NPS Management Policies, and Modified Alternative A should be adopted by NPS as its preferred alternative. In response to a settlement agreement reached in Friends of the Earth v. Department of Interior, 478 F. Supp.2d 11, (D.D.C. 2007), NPS developed and implemented an interim management plan for the Seashore (the "Interim Management Plan"). To comply with NEPA, NPS prepared an Environmental Assessment, which concluded with a Finding of No Significant Impact ("FONSI'). In other words, NPS determined that the Interim Management Plan would have no significant impact on the human environment. In its FONSI, NPS determined that: Implementing the preferred alternative will not violate any federal, state, or local environmental protection law. There will no impairment of Seashore resources or values resulting from implementation of the preferred alternative." Interim Management Plan, FONSI, p. 26. The Interim Management Plan serves in part as the "no-action" alternative (Alternative A) for this ORV management plan and EIS.” (399664)  ALTERNATIVE B  Comments received on this alternative are addressed under other codes.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  ALTERNATIVE C  159.  Alternative C is not needed to meet NPS mandates; the existing plan already does that.  “It is the purpose of Executive Order 11644 & Executive Order 11989 to establish policies and provide for procedures that will ensure that the use of off-road vehicles on public lands will be controlled and directed so as to protect the resources of those lands, to promote the safety of all users of those lands, and to minimize conflicts among the various uses of those lands. Both Executive Orders provide the respective agency head the power to ensure ORVs are controlled and used in a manner that will not damage the wildlife or parks environment. Nothing that I have read states that the agency is accountable to employee un-necessary regulations which will place hardships on the parks visitors. According to all the data which has been presented for turtles and birds shows they are increasing in numbers. There are more law enforcement officers per mile on North and South Core Banks than any other location in Carteret County. We never hear of any major or minor problems taking place in the park. So explain why there is a clear NEED to spend this kind of money. The current plan is working why burden the American People when it is not NECESSARY!” (399811)  Alternative A does not meet the purpose, need, and objectives of this plan in several important respects. The additional ORV restrictions proposed under Alternative C will significantly limit access to and use of the Seashore, which is inconsistent with North Carolina's enforceable Coastal Management Program. The State of North Carolina has a longstanding focus on improving public access to shorelines. See, e.g., N.C. Gen.  The Seashore completed consultation with the North Carolina Division of Coastal Management (DCM) to concur that the preferred alternative was consistent. Alternative D should be modified to include additional year-round pedestrian-only areas that benefit species, limitations on essential vehicles, increasing buffer sizes, and implementing prenesting areas.  “With that in mind, while we do not object to Alternative E, we recommend that NPS select Alternative D, with certain changes to bring the Seashore more fully into compliance with the authorities cited above and with other federal law and that are described in more detail below. These changes include: 1. Designating additional year-round vehicle-free areas where they will benefit breeding, migrating, and wintering birds as well as pedestrians seeking remote natural experiences. 2. Limiting non-essential vehicles to the back route behind the dune line (referred to in the DEIS as the "back route" or "backroad") to the maximum extent possible during bird breeding and migration seasons, and sea turtle nesting and hatching seasons. 3. Increasing the size of the protective buffers for nesting shorebirds and unfledged chicks to match those that have allowed wildlife breeding to rebound so successfully at Cape Hatteras National Seashore. 4. Implementing pre-nesting closures in historic nesting areas, to prevent shorebirds from being deterred from early courtship efforts by human disturbance.” (399242) “ALTERNATIVE D MUST BE MODIFIED TO COMPLY WITH NPS'S OBLIGATIONS TO PROTECT WILDLIFE. We endorse Alternative D if essential changes to improve wildlife protections are made. Although it is the most protective of the alternatives that allow ORV access by a small margin,  The NPS believes that the preferred alternative provides the needed level of resource protection, while still allowing for visitor use of the Seashore. The elements of alternative D provided by the commenter are discussed further below:  1. Designate additional year-round vehicle-free areas to benefit species: Existing closures at the Seashore are adequate and appropriate to protect breeding, migrating, and wintering birds. Pedestrian-only areas are an incidental protective measure, and are hardly relied upon by the Seashore for species protection. Thus, while pedestrian-only areas may only be an “incidental benefit,” the plan includes multiple other direct management and mitigation measures directed at species protection. Among these measures is the closure of the Seashore to ORVs from January 1 until March 15 each year, providing 25 percent of the year where wintering birds have an ORV-free area. As noted in the final plan/EIS, based on  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  Alternative D does not "minimize harassment of wildlife or significant disruption of wildlife habitats," as required by Executive Order 11644. Moreover, the DEIS concedes that even Alternative D will have long-term, adverse impacts to wildlife on the Seashore due to ORV use. See DEIS at 538 (generally), 309 (piping plover), 344 (red knot), 369 (sea turtles), 390 (seabeach amaranth), and 427 (state-listed birds). As a result, it violates NPS's statutory obligation "to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wild life therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations." 16 U.S.C. ï¿½ 1. The changes necessary to bring Alternative D into compliance include reducing the extent of designated ORV routes by designating additional vehicle-free areas on the Seashore's ocean-facing beaches, increasing buffer protections for birds and turtles, and maintaining buffer integrity.” (399248)  data collected by NPS staff from 2008 through 2013, approximately  10 miles along the ocean beach are closed to ORV use periodically for resource protection during the nesting season (summer).” These closure areas are often used by migrating and wintering birds. Additional measures include closing the soundside to ORV use, numerical capacity limit on vehicles based on the highest current levels of ORV use (a limit at which species productivity has thrived), along with a robust adaptive management strategy monitoring impacts and further mitigating use if necessary.  Taken together, these additional measures squarely address requirements of executive orders and the NPS Organic Act.   2. Administrative use should use back route when possible: In its current condition, the back route could not sustain the level of use required for all administrative travel. Modifications would be needed such as making the route wider and adding more pull-outs, which would create large areas of disturbance.  3. Increasing buffer sizes: The NPS did analyze larger buffer sizes under alternative D and determined that the buffer sizes in the preferred alternative, alternative C, were appropriate for resource protection. The buffer distances detailed in the preferred alternative are based on USFWS recovery plan recommendations, with daily monitoring of chicks and nests. The  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  Seashore did not rely on the USGS report when establishing buffers because this report and its recommendations were specific to Cape Hatteras National Seashore and the significantly higher levels of visitor use at that Seashore. It would be inappropriate to apply the management recommendations of that report to Cape Lookout National Seashore, which although geographically proximate, has lower levels of visitor use due to ferry-only access. Cape Lookout National Seashore also has a greater population of nesting shorebirds. In 2014 Cape Hatteras National Seashore documented 12 pairs of piping plovers and 25 pairs of American oystercatchers while Cape Lookout National Seashore documented 43 pairs of piping plovers and 66 pairs of American oystercatchers. The implementation of a permit system with limits would ensure this use would remain at levels where the proposed buffers are appropriate and species continue to thrive.  4. Pre-nesting closures: The pre-nesting closures suggested by the commenter are provided under alternative C. Refer to chapter 2, “Table 5: Additional Species Management Measures not in the Cape Lookout National Seashore Interim Protected Species Management Plan / Environmental Assessment, Biological Opinion, Amended Biological Opinion, or FONSI.”  162.  The Seashore is not currently meeting their goals under the  Moreover, implementation of the terms in the Interim Plan since 2007 has failed to provide the level of wildlife protection required under Executive Orders 11644 and  As stated in the USFWS Biological Opinion for this project, “The goal is at least 0.75 chicks fledged per breeding pair at the Seashore per  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  Interim Species Management Plan Biological Opinion or the Recovery Plan, and implementation of alternative C would not further the meeting of these obligations.  11989. Cape Lookout has fallen short of FWS' s performance measures for piping plover under the Interim Plan and previous management practices. The Seashore has only met Performance Measure 3, 0.75 fledged piping plover chicks per breeding pair, six times in the last 23 years. See DEIS at 181 , NPS, Piping Plover (Charadrius melodus) Monitoring at Cape Lookout National Seashore: 2013 Summary Report at 5 (2013). It has never met FWS's Recovery Plan goal of 1.5 fledged chicks per breeding pair. Id. The practices in place at Cape Lookout, which were formalized in the Interim Plan and would be continued in Alternative C, simply do not meet NPS's obligation to protect piping plover or other wildlife at the Seashore, much less minimize adverse impacts to wildlife and wildlife habitat. (540025)  year. Since 1989, the number of chicks fledged per breeding pair has ranged from 0.09 to 0.92 with an average fledging rate of 0.48 chicks fledged per breeding pair.” While these goals have not been met every year, since 2009, 5 of those 7 years have had a fledge rate of 0.72 or higher, with a high of 1.04 in 2013, which is one of the highest fledge rates on record. The Seashore also notes that ORV use is one of many factors affecting piping plover reproductive success. The adaptive management plan addresses this uncertainty by allowing a range of management responses geared toward resource protection when key indicators are not met.  NEW ALTERNATIVE ELEMENTS  163. Alternative elements that look at modifying this regulation are outside the scope of this ORV management plan/EIS.  164. Additional amenities such as dumpsters, places to buy ice, and additional fish cleaning tables should be added.  "Putting dumpsters somewhere near the South end of CALO would cut down on trash, and selling ice at the Lighthouse gift shop would decrease the driving time of fishermen going all the way back to camp just for ice". (399991) “Currently the only fish cleaning tables are at the cabin camps. I recommend an additional fish cleaning table be added near the lighthouse visitor parking lot, or at the lighthouse long term parking lot or at a another suitable location to be determined.
