The location should be far enough away from the boardwalk to not be objectionable to pedestrian visitors.” (389567)  Additional amenities could be considered as revenue from the fee permit system allows. The idea of additional fish cleaning stations at other areas of the park would be one of the amenities evaluated for these funds. However, the Seashore does not plan on adding dumpsters around the Seashore. The only places where there are currently dumpsters at the Seashore are within the camps where staff are available to manage them. Establishing dumpsters in more remote areas would lead to management concerns as staff would not be available to make sure the containers are closed and trash is collected on a regular basis.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  167.  Cut strategic gaps in the boundary dune line to allow more overwash and remove non-native trees to help sand migration.  “The park service treats these boundary sand dunes like a rigid sea wall that "protects" the island from storms. The park service tries to maximize all the sea oats on these dunes thinking the dunes are fragile and might "fail" during a storm. Coastal experts such as Dr. Stanley Riggs understand the dynamics of the islands and the associated dune line. A simple barrier island like South Core Banks will have periodic overwash events during storms that are a natural part of the westward migration of these islands. The overwash serves to move sand to the interior of the island and raises the elevation of the interior of the island. The back road between ramp 41a and ramp 44 and the surrounding interior area needs overwash to raise the elevation above the water table. Hurricane Irene helped some of this area, but more overwash is needed. A controversial yet effective corrective actions would be to cut some strategic gaps in the boundary dune line to allow more overwash. Removal of the non-native trees might also help sand migration.” (399797)  There are already a number of gaps from the ramps, but the Seashore would never create more for the sole purpose of overwash. Overwash occurs naturally without gaps, and there is a risk that more gaps would create more islands, and ironically, result in less access for ORVs since there would not be a ferry landing.   168.  Alternative transportation should be included in the plan, with the possibility this could be added to alternative E.   “ALTERNATIVE E COULD PROVIDE VISITOR ACCESS WITH ALTERNATIVE TRANSIT. If NPS selects Alternative E, we urge it to facilitate visitation with additional alternative transportation and infrastructure. NPS could consider adding shuttles, trams, or ferries to additional portions of the Seashore, similar to those that currently transport visitors to the southern end of South Core Banks, the lighthouse, Cape Lookout Point, and Power Squadron spit. Funding for such efforts is available through the Paul S. Sarbanes Transit in Parks Program, which is designed to promote alternatives to the use of private automobiles, in order to reduce traffic congestion, noise, air pollution, and other effects associated with traffic that detract from the experience of visitors to national parks such as Cape Lookout and other public lands. We understand, for instance, that the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Virginia Department of Conservation and Recreation recently received a-grant- -to purchase a new  Options for alternative transportation currently exist on South Core Banks. The Island Express Ferry service is authorized to transport visitors anywhere on South Core Banks. For details on this service please visit http://www.islandexpressferryservices.com/. In regards to additional options, the reference to funding and website link provided by the commenter did not work. However, another relevant link (http://www.vbgov.com/government/department s/parks-recreation/design-developmentprojects/Pages/tripp-grant-bbnwr.aspx) states that MAP21 has eliminated federal funding for transportation plans.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  transit vehicle to transport-visitors along-a beachfront area between Back Bay National Wildlife Refuge and a state park in southeastern Virginia (FTA FY2012 Paul S. Sarbanes Transit in Parks Discretionary Program, U.S. Dep't ofTransp.: Fed. Transit Admin., http://www.fta.dot.gov/13094_15068.html.). Millions of dollars are distributed by this program each year for planning and capital expenses for alternate transit systems in national parks. In light of the availability of funding, as well as the program's goal of reducing traffic congestion and its ill effects on national parks, NPS should consider implementing motorized transit (beach shuttles, trams, boats, etc.) and/or non-motorized transit (pedestrian walkways, interdunal trails, etc.). Such systems will facilitate access to the Seashore's remote beaches in the event that ORV access is eliminated by selection of Alternative E, and will do so in a way that is less environmentally damaging than use of individual ORVs. In addition to easing the aesthetic and environmental impacts of beach driving, an alternative transit system could benefit many kinds of visitors, from the very youngest and oldest visitors and those with physical disabilities, to those with fishing gear and other heavy loads. It could also conserve energy and create transit-related jobs for local residents.” (399247) “Please add a provision for public transportation on the North and South Core Banks. Visitors should be encouraged to arrive on the islands without bringing a vehicle, and use some form of public transportation to travel to the beaches or to overnight lodgings. The Federal Highway Administration manages the Federal Lands Transportation Program, which can help NPS develop new approaches to reducing vehicular congestion in the parks. Shuttle services have been successful in several national parks, from Yosemite and Grand Canyon to our nearby Harpers Ferry.” (399957) “my proposal is this: An authorized NPS party could provide an NPS authorized service that would operate similarly to a scheduled city bus/subway system on an NPS authorized  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  route(s) for the purpose of transporting visitors and their gear to and from all designated pedestrian only areas, as well as ORV use areas. Visitors could initially access this service at any of the NPS authorized ferry drop-offs, and also could communicate via cell phone in with the transport service to order supplies, check on availability, etc. Of course an affordable fee or token system would need to be established to support the system financially. There would be multiple benefits to such a service: The transport service could operate flexibly to augment the conservation goals and responsibilities of the NPS, while promoting access and enjoyment by the public thru a convenient and cost effective mechanism. An actual reduction of ORV use might occur as a consumer choice, rather than a restriction. Additional employment opportunities for drivers and other support personnel would be created.” (392092)  169.  Use GPS tracking to determine where ORVs are on the island and if they are violating resource closures.  “A true alternative would be a technological solution, such as GPS tracking. The technology exists, as fleet managers use it to track shipments on a global, if not international scale. Each ORV on the beach could be assigned a GPS tracker unit (with suitable deposit to prevent intentional loss or damage). The GPS tracker could be sealed or locked to the vehicle in some manner, or sufficient penalties given for not having it on the vehicle and operational. Officers on each island could geo-fence (and physically mark) resource closures. Any violations could be immediately identified, giving the nearest officer the chance to catch the actual perpetrator in the act, or to prevent any damage to the resource. I am not sure, but I would suspect a GPS system could be configured so the user could be warned when approaching a geo-fenced area, giving auditory or visual indication of the location of resource closures or buffers - and offering real flexibility in managing these areas. Yes, this proposal does have a certain big brotherness aspect to it, but since NPS law enforcement officers sometime hide in the dunes and watch park visitors with binoculars, we are already there. The system could be set up that the NPS  The use of GPS tracking devices on vehicles is not necessary since Seashore law enforcement staff are on the island to patrol and enforce resource violations. Because a GPS device could be removed, such a device may not be as effective as traditional law enforcement. In addition, the NPS believes there could be unintended consequences to such devices such as visitors feeling that such devices would be an invasion of privacy and that they were being “tracked” by the NPS, which would negatively impact the visitor use and experience at the Seashore. In addition to the technical concerns with GPS tracking units, it would also be cost prohibitive to outfit all ORVs coming to the Seashore with these devices.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  does not constantly track every visitor every second of the day, but only give an alert when a violation is detected. GPS trackers could tag violators of speed limits. The number of trackers could be limited, thereby limiting actual vehicles in use on the island - rather than some indiscriminate and artificially derived limit on permits. In emergencies, GPS trackers could provide real time location information to the authorities. GPS tracking could offer a cost effective means of nearly 100% compliance, without heavy-handed enforcement efforts. Punishment for violations could be directed at individuals, rather than handed down to the ORV user population as a whole. Given the transitory nature of park visitors, the punishments given by the plan would by and large fall on innocent visitors who come afterwards. I am not aware of any other park unit using GPS tracking and geo-fencing for this purpose, but the unique aspects of CALO should make it a feasible alternative that should be given due consideration.” (390927)  170.  Demolish the old Coast Guard pier and construct a new pedestrian pier with a boat dock.  “I recommend the derelict old Coast Guard pier be demolished. A suitable pedestrian pier with both a boat dock and a fishing pier section should be constructed. It should be designed for handicap use. It should also have both steps and a wheel chair ramp to the beach. The ORV parking space should be increased. It should be serviced by the mule train for pedestrians. This would provide additional recreation use and a gateway to the historic village. This addition would open up a new area for multiple use and help to reduce visitor density.” (389568)  Pier construction, demolition, and access improvements suggested by the commenter are outside the scope of this ORV planning effort. These projects could be considered in a future, separate, planning effort.  171.  Electric golf carts should be considered.  “How about electric Golf Carts? These are not addressed either. They are quiet and would not traumatize the nesting birds” (387409)  When considering management actions to reduce impacts to nesting birds, noise is one of many factors (others include the physical presence and visibility of vehicles) that needs to be considered. The use of quieter vehicles would address one, but not all, of the concerns  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  related to species disturbance. Electric golf carts are a subset of UTVs and are not addressed separately. Any restrictions in the ORV management plan/EIS that apply to UTVs would apply to electric golf carts. Although not prohibited at the Seashore, use of an electric golf cart would present challenges to visitors. The main challenge would be the lack of electricity on the islands, which would require a visitor to bring his or her own generator capable of charging the vehicle in case the golf cart runs out of power. Further, electric golf carts are not a proven mode of transportation on beaches.  172.  Instead of restrictions, increase enforcement and penalties, such as a 5-year ban.  “I do believe the penalty for endangering these animals and the ecosystem should be more severe, zero tolerance for driving in restricted areas. Maybe a 5 year ban for a violation, seems harsh but it will make the few people that stray respect the land and help keep it open for future generations. So please don't change the rules or add red tape, just enforce them and increase the penalty for breaking them.” (387417) “Micro managing the ISLANDS has taken a turn for the worse. You need to enforce the rules we already have and increase the penalties for those taking advantage of the system.” (385009)  As indicated in the section “Discussion of Action Alternatives” in chapter 2, the Superintendent may revoke a vehicle permit or an operator education certificate for violation of applicable park regulations or terms and conditions of the permit. Most of the violations observed at the Seashore have been considered petty offenses (Class B Misdemeanors) in the federal court system, which carry a maximum fine of $5,000.00 and/or six months in prison. The monetary amount of fines is governed by the Collateral Forfeiture Schedule (CFS), which must be approved by the Chief Judge of the Eastern District of North Carolina, not the Seashore.   Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  173.  Reduce air pollution by providing more services at the lighthouse area.  “Air Pollution from ORVs on the beach is discussed. Any emissions from vehicles are quickly dissipated by the prevailing winds. If emissions need to be reduced on the island, why not provide gasoline and ice and trash collection at the Lighthouse area? There is already a gift store there which is open most days, and there is electricity that could be used for freezers or icemakers. Another option would be for NPS personnel, who already come to the Lighthouse area everyday, to bring over ice just as they do at the camps. Additionally, tractors at the camps are already rigged with back blades for scraping the roads and lift for the dumpsters. Could these same tractors move a dumpster to and from the lighthouse and scrape the back road along the way?” (3879889)  Many of the services noted by the commenter are already provided by a contractor that delivers ice to the camps. In addition, Long Point and Great Island already provide gas and ice. To create another operation to provide ice and gas elsewhere at the Seashore would be financially infeasible. The NPS will discuss with the concessionaire about providing additional ORV services at certain locations, and whether this would be financially feasible. However, NPS seeks to minimize fuel storage at the Seashore, due to environmental impact concerns. Several fuel storage locations are vulnerable to weather events. Additional locations could increase environmental risk.  GENERAL/OTHER  174.  The various dates for seasonal closures in the document should be made consistent.   “REFERENCE: Alternative C, pages 58 through 64; and pages 79 through 100 Tables 3, 4 and 5: COMMENT: The proposals within Alternative C include numerous seasonal changes in ORV restrictions. There is a hodgepodge of seasonal dates that include May 1, May 15, the Friday before Memorial Day, August 31, Labor Day and September 15. Each of these dates were developed independently with some well-intended basis for each of the change actions, but without considering the big picture. The net effect is unnecessary complexity with the potential for confusion by the users and by park service law enforcement about what changes on what date. The CALO track record on resource management has been good. It should improve by increasing seasonal restrictions during the Standardized Dates noted below in my recommendation. There is no increase in risk by continuing the current restrictions outside of the Standardized Dates. The benefit of Standardized Dates is a more simple set of rules that are easier to explain  The Seashore agrees that consistency of dates will help eliminate unnecessary complexity and reduce confusion, and has consolidated dates where possible. Overall, the Seashore will be open to ORVs and non-sport ATVs/UTVs March 15 – December 31. ORV and ATV/UTV seasonal closures for species management and seasonal pedestrian-only closures will be May 1 – September 14 generally, although the area in front of sea turtle nests is completely closed to vehicles for hatching, which can occur through mid-November.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  in the ORV educational program and therefore they will be understood and remembered which will result in higher acceptance and compliance by ORV users. This also simplifies the job of law enforcement and should result in fewer violations. Any consideration for extending the seasonal dates beyond Standardized Dates in the future should be done under Adaptive Management that uses scientific principles and local CALO data to determine the need for incremental changes. I recommend one set of Standardized Dates to apply to all seasonal changes. The Standardized Dates would be as defined on page 63: "from the Friday preceding (typo correction for 'proceeding') Memorial Day through Labor Day". This is a recognized definition of the summer tourist season that is just good common sense. It captures the two holiday weekends when visitation is up and it also recognizes the time of transition between user interests.” (387475)  175.  The plan should be reviewed every 3 years to start, then every 5 years.  “Review of the ORV Plan should be 3 years initially and then every 5 years.” (399845)  The Seashore has accounted for the need to revisit and adjust the plan through the adaptive management strategy. The adaptive management strategy accounts for the dynamic nature of the Seashore, and allows for reevaluation of the plan and various actions.  AFFECTED ENVIRONMENT – SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN  176.  Species numbers at the Seashore are not driven by ORV use, but by weather events and predation. There is no evidence that ORVs impact sensitive species. The NPS should  “I am not aware of any credible evidence whatsoever that ORV use on a beach has or will cause a reduction of ANY avian species. Please provide me with that evidence if it is in existence, I would very much appreciate it and promise to give it appropriate weight.” (385081) “The Piping Plover population reached an all time low in 2003, just as visitation declined by 21 MILLION, its lowest point since the recession of 1990. This suggests that beach driving and plover populations are not related. Since the  Many factors, both natural and anthropogenic, can affect the population numbers and trends of piping plovers both within the Seashore, as well as across the species’ entire range. However, the number of piping plovers at the Seashore is too low on an annual basis and the magnitude and number of potential and actual natural and human risks to piping plovers are too high to establish statistically clear annual cause-andeffect relationships. Poor breeding performance  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  conduct a study to determine the impact of predation on species.  NPS has been setting aside beach driving for more than 20 years, it would be surprising if they were. Interestingly, plover populations didn't just drop in the Seashore; identical declines were mirrored across North Carolina and reached new lows in 2004. Obviously, beach driving in the Seashore couldn't cause a reduction in plover outside of the Seashore. It is also surprising that while plover populations dropped to record lows in the Seashore and in North Carolina, they rose in Virginia and all along the Eastern Seaboard, reaching new highs. What could reduce plover population in North Carolina and in Cape Hatteras National Seashore, while at the same time reduce tourism in the Seashore by 21 million? It would appear that plovers and tourists have one thing in common: They don't like HURRICANES" (385113) “Responsible ORV use does not disturb the nesting birds as much as predators. Predators do far more damage & ORV use actually helps keep predators away.” (385816) “I don’t understand how the NPS can blame low reproduction rates of certain shore birds on ORV traffic while they permit nocturnal ground predators roam the island. Has the NPS done any surveys on the impact of such predators? I would ask that the NPS determine what affect ground predators are having on nesting shore birds on Portsmouth before blame is put on ORV's.” (398828)  of piping plover at the Seashore can include, but is not be limited to these: the unavailability of habitat due to recreational pressure, failure of piping plover to settle at the Seashore and establish territories, failure of piping plover pairs to build nests, and failure of piping plover to hatch eggs and fledge young. It is very rare to be able to establish conclusively and scientifically what natural or human variable may have been at the root cause of the failure. Rather, it is typically the case that adults, eggs, and young simply disappear without proper indicators to determine losses. Therefore, it remains difficult to assign a particular poor reproductive outcome to a single environmental or anthropogenic issue.  Piping plover numbers have increased and decreased over the last 2.5 decades. The exact cause of these trends is not known, but human activity, including direct and indirect effects of ORVs, is considered to be one of the factors. The adverse effects of ORVs on wildlife, and the additional people brought into remote areas by ORVs are well documented in the peer-reviewed literature cited in the draft ORV management plan/EIS. For example, refer to the following sections in the draft ORV management plan/EIS:  Chapter 3, Piping Plovers, Risk Factors on pages 197-198;  Chapter 4, Piping Plover, Alternative A, Impacts of Alternative A: No Action, ORV and other Recreational Use on pages 277-282.  The draft ORV management plan/EIS correctly acknowledges that other factors such as  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  predation and hurricanes also adversely affect wildlife at the Seashore. For example, refer to the following sections:  Chapter 3, Piping Plovers, Risk Factors on pages 195-196;  Chapter 4, Piping Plover, Alternative A, Impacts of Alternative A: No Action, Resource Management Activities, Predator Management on pages 276-277. None of the applicable laws imposes a burden of proof on NPS to show direct causality of ORV impact on a species. Rather, Executive Orders 11644 and 11989, the NPS Management Policies 2006, and 36 CFR 4.10(b) require that no ORV use be allowed, unless ORV routes can be designated consistent with the executive orders. Executive Orders 11644 and 11989 state that trails shall be located in areas only if the respective agency head determines that ORV use in such locations will not adversely affect their natural, aesthetic, or scenic values (which include park wildlife). Part of the purpose of the ORV management plan/EIS is to manage ORV use and access in the Seashore to protect and preserve natural and cultural resources and natural processes to meet these requirements. The Seashore is able to certify that impacts are minimized through buffers and closures; without these mitigation measures ORV routes could not be lawfully designated. Regarding specific mortality events and/or disappearances of birds, nests, and eggs from territories, NPS publishes information in its annual species reports regarding the potential disturbances to the species (weather, predation,  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  and human disturbance to name a few). Other than the rare case where chicks or adults are found dead in tire tracks or cases where predator signs are found near a failed nest, the majority of cases are necessarily categorized as “unknown” or “indeterminate” regarding the actual cause. Although these specific cases are unknown, what is known and provided in the reports, are the types of disturbances that are occurring. With regards to predators, as noted in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, a predator removal study was conducted at the Seashore from 2007 to 2009, although it focused only on raccoons and not other predators. The study found piping plover nest predation decreased one year after removal of half the raccoon population and piping plover productivity increased one year after the raccoon removal effort, although the increase was not statistically significant. It is important to note that predator populations and the pressure they exert on other species are enhanced to some degree by recreation and other human activities (e.g., attraction by trash left behind). Because of the low numbers of piping plover coupled with the inherent uncertainties surrounding piping plover reproductive performance, the NPS provides the required protection for this species from factors it can address, such as ORV use and human disturbance, as well as some predator impacts through the use of predator exclosures, as opposed to factors outside of NPS control (e.g., weather events). This is consistent with NPS management policy provisions on listed species, which state the NPS will undertake active management programs to inventory, monitor, restore, and maintain listed species' habitats;  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  control detrimental non-native species; control detrimental visitor access; and re-establish extirpated populations as necessary to maintain these species and the habitats on which they depend. In addition to NPS management policies, the NPS has a responsibility under the Endangered Species Act to provide protection to the piping plover. An agency is not required to remedy all factors related to a problem in order to manage one factor. Thus, it is reasonable, and consistent with applicable laws, regulations, executive orders, and NPS Management Policies 2006, for NPS to manage ORV use as provided in the ORV management plan/EIS to help protect the piping plover and other protected species at the Seashore.  177.  Where does the piping plover go when it leaves the Seashore and how does the NPS know it is threatened? The piping plover is not native to the Seashore and preservation efforts should be focused where it is native.  “I asked the question about one of the birds that supposedly is threatened , The Piping Plover, where does it go after it leaves the island? The biologist said she wasn't sure because there wasn't a study done yet to know, how do we know then that the bird is threatened ?” (398794) “I am also concerned about the efforts to protect the Piping Plover. That is not a bird which is native to Core Banks, so you are trying to establish a bird in a locale which is not its natural environment and not naturally selected as its best habitat. I would suggest that if you want to preserve and have that bird thrive, that you should go to where it determined to be its native habitat and control that area as it was originally selected as more favorable that Core Banks.” (384162)  As noted in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the first recorded breeding of the piping plover in North Carolina is from 1901 on Pearl Island, and according to the USFWS, the Outer Banks is at the southern end of the range for the Atlantic Coast population (Maritime Provinces of Canada to the Outer Banks of North Carolina). Although migration patterns of the piping plover are not well studied and documented, individuals have been found wintering on the Atlantic coast from North Carolina south to Florida, along the Gulf coast, and in the Bahamas and West Indies (USFWS 2007 http://www.fws.gov/northeast/pipingplover/pdf/pl over.pdf). Therefore, North Carolina is uniquely positioned in the species range, being the only state where piping plover breeding and wintering ranges overlap and the birds are present year-round (USFWS n.d. http://www.fws.gov/Raleigh/pdfs/20080000_PIP  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  LCH_FactSheet.pdf). The 1996 Piping Plover (Atlantic Coast population) Revised Recovery Plan requires a minimum of 2,000 breeding pairs over a five-year period in order to be delisted. The 2010 Atlantic Coast piping plover population estimate was 1,782 pairs, more than double the 1986 estimate of 790 pairs. North Carolina’s population of breeding pairs accounted for approximately 3 percent of the Atlantic Coast population, with reproduction success 30 percent [0.77 chicks fledged] below the average [1.27 chicks fledged]. Therefore, the bird does not yet qualify for delisting, and is still considered threatened under the Endangered Species Act (USFWS 2011 http://www.fws.gov/northeast/pipingplover/pdf/A bundance&Productivity2010Update.pdf). Because the piping plover occurs at the Seashore and is listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act, the NPS continues to have a responsibility under the Endangered Species Act to provide protection to the species.  178.  Current management of the Seashore is working for species and should be continued.  “From everything I have seen and personally experienced, the last 15-20 years have shown that all the plant and animal species have remained and continue to thrive on South Banks/Great Island/Calo along with ORV use. There is no reason to believe that the next 15-20 years of the same use would result in a different outcome.” (385075) “PIPING PLOVER Your own data state the fledge rate has been increasing. Your own data state the number of breeding pairs has been increasing. Your own data state, "The USFWS provided CALO a biological opinion that included four performance measures for the Interim Protected Species Management Plan. Forty five breeding  The Seashore agrees that current species protection measures are working, and for that reason, the NPS is proposing ORV routes and species protection measures substantially similar to existing measures, with some differences (such as night-driving restrictions) specifically recommended by the USFWS in a long-term ORV management plan. Were these species protection measures not working, NPS would be unable to allow ORV use. Other management measures are intended to keep ORV use based on the highest current level of ORV use, which have worked in concert with  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  pairs were found in CALO in 2013 surpassing the target of 25 or more pairs of performance measure one. Forty five pairs produced 52 nests (1.15 nest per pair) surpassing the target of at least one nest per breeding pair of performance measure two. The 45 nesting pairs produced 47 fledglings for a fledge rate of 1.04, which is above the target of 0.75 of performance measure three." No Action is a decision and can be justified by the data.” (387615)  species management. Vehicle permits and fees will provide the Seashore the ability to implement management measures specific to ORVs.  Regarding piping plovers, both regionally in the Atlantic Coast Southern Region Recovery Unit in North Carolina, and at the Seashore itself, the species has risen above the historic lows recorded. However, the numbers of piping plovers continue to be lower than the number of breeding pairs required under the 1996 Piping Plover (Atlantic Coast population) Revised Recovery Plan for it to be delisted. Perhaps more importantly, they are still performing below the 400 breeding pair target established in the recovery plan for the Atlantic Coast Southern Region Recovery Unit. The Seashore is also an important breeding habitat for the species in North Carolina since it has a majority of nesting pairs in the state. High quality nesting habitat from Old Drum Flats to Plover Inlet contained 65 percent (28 pairs) of the nesting pairs in 2015. Portsmouth Flats, another important area, continued to provide nesting habitat on North Core Banks with 14 nesting pairs (32% of the nesting pairs) in 2015. As noted in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, visitation is expected to continue to slowly grow in the future, with an estimated annual increase of approximately 1.5 percent. With increased visitation it is also assumed that the number of ORVs on the beach at the Seashore would also slowly increase, potentially creating increased conflicts between recreation and birds as well as other protected species. The NPS continues to have a responsibility under the Endangered Species Act to provide  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  protection to the piping plover and other protected species. Because breeding numbers are still below recovery goals and visitation at the Seashore is expected to continue to increase in the future, the NPS believes the levels of protection proposed in the alternatives are necessary for adequate species protection.   179.  The goal of 2,000 breeding pairs is not supported by a reference. Other studies have not shown that ORVs impact piping plovers.  “Despite documented research on Piping Plovers (Page 170) and observation of Piping Plovers activity within the seashore, the accompanying data fails to take into account the full range of factors that present obstacles to the revitalization of the species across its range. The report references USFW data supporting a stated goal of 2,000 pairs being obtainable or sustainable, but the source of the data nor a reference to a particular study are provided. Again, in a study funded by the U.S. Marine Corps and National Park Service, Matthew Hillman stated, CALO is unique in that relatively few measures, historically or presently, have been implemented to control erosion and protect human development. Therefore, human impacts on water bird habitat are less PERVASIVE at CALO than in many other regions of the U.S. Atlantic coastline. (10) In another study done by the same agencies, Tracy Borneman stated, I did not find human activity affected oystercatcher nest attendance.” (387963)  The Seashore report does cite this recovery goal of 2,000 pairs (USFWS 1996a; Hecht pers. comm. 2008). Further, the 1996 Recovery Report (located here: http://www.fws.gov/northeast/pipingplover/pdf/s ummary.pdf) states that: Delisting of the Atlantic Coast piping plover population may be considered when the following criteria have been met: 1. Increase and maintain for five years a total of 2,000 breeding pairs, distributed among four recovery units as follows: Atlantic Canada, 400 pairs; New England, 625 pairs; New York-New Jersey, 575 pairs; Southern (Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina), 400 pairs.  “In addition, recent research conducted by North Carolina State University and Virginia Tech concluded that ORVs on CALO had minimal impact on shore birds. So regardless of the increased restrictions on human activity, predators and constant weather events will continue to determine the success or failure of the protected species (turtles, birds and plants).” (398757)  2. Increase and maintain for five years a total of 2,000 breeding pairs, distributed among four recovery units as follows: Atlantic Canada, 400 pairs; New England, 625 pairs; New York-New Jersey, 575 pairs; Southern (Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina), 400 pairs.  3. Verify the adequacy of a 2,000-pair population of piping plovers to maintain heterozygosity [genetic variation in the  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  population] and allelic diversity over the long term. 4. Achieve five-year average productivity of 1.5 fledged chicks per pair in each of the four recovery units described in criterion 1, based on data from sites that collectively support at least 90 percent of the population in the recovery unit.  5. Institute long-term agreements to assure protection and management sufficient to maintain the population targets and average productivity in each recovery unit.  6. Ensure long-term maintenance of wintering habitat, sufficient in quantity, quality, and distribution to maintain survival rates for a 2,000-pair population. Although human impacts on water bird species may be less pervasive at the Seashore than in many other locations along the U.S. Atlantic coastline, there are still impacts. A study cited in the draft ORV management plan/EIS by Simons and Borneman (2012) found that American oystercatchers were on their nests significantly less during all types of ORV and pedestrian events than before those events. Executive Orders 11644 and 11989, NPS Management Policies 2006, and 36 CFR 4.10(b) require that ORV use not be allowed, unless ORV routes can be designated consistent with the executive orders. Executive Orders 11644 and 11989 state that trails shall be located in areas of the national park system only if the respective agency head determines that ORV use in such locations will not adversely affect their natural, aesthetic, or scenic values (which include park  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  wildlife). Part of the purpose of the ORV management plan/EIS is to manage ORV use/access in the Seashore to protect and preserve natural and cultural resources and natural processes to meet these requirements. Because of the low numbers of water birds coupled with the inherent uncertainties surrounding their reproductive performance, the NPS provides the required protection for this species, as well as other protected species, from factors it can control, such as ORV use, human disturbance, and to some extent predation, and not from factors it cannot control (e.g., weather).  AFFECTED ENVIRONMENT – WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE HABITAT All comments were non-substantive or addressed under special-status species.  AFFECTED ENVIRONMENT – VISITOR USE AND EXPERIENCE  180.  ORV use is an important part of providing visitor access to the disabled and elderly.   “Please keep Cape Lookout open to ORV access with moderate restrictions. I'm one of the many handicap people who need ORVs and the alike to access points of interest on the Core Banks. Denying ORV access would be the equivalent of removing wheelchair ramps, accessible restroom facilities and rails at National exhibits at the nation's capital.” (385137) “Restricting ORV's from CALO restricts accessibility for disabled persons, and therefore may be in violation of NPS Director's Order #4. Plans to limit ORV usage on CALO therefore unfairly discriminate against older citizens of the USA. Many people legally and lawfully own and use ATV's and UTV's. So long as they follow the rules why are they to be singled out? Will the park service also dis-continue the use of their ATV'S, UTV's, etc. complying with their own  The NPS recognizes that visitors to the Seashore have different needs, and therefore provides a variety of uses, including ORV areas and vehicle-free areas. For those visitors who may require a vehicle for access due to a medical condition or disability, or need to have a family member with them at all times, opportunities are provided under the preferred alternative where ORVs are allowed. This complies with the applicable requirements and NPS policies. Under the Federal Rehabilitation Act, 29 USC 791 et seq., which applies to federal agencies in lieu of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the NPS is required to provide reasonable access to programs and services at the Seashore.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  regulations?” (399686) “I have enjoyed surf fishing on the Core Banks many times over the years. Now that I am 70 getting around makes that more difficult without the use of a 4wd vehicle.” (398965)  “Reasonable” does not necessarily mean “total” and must be viewed in the light of the entire program or activity, including its purpose (i.e., providing the visitor with a variety of experiences).  “Vehicles must be allowed to remain for those who require transportation for recreation, health, spiritual regeneration, or financial income.” (398213) “In this entire document, the NPS has made no mention, or planning considerations, for disabled persons. While the term mobility is used in several instances when referring to bird species, the document does not make one reference to mobility as related to homo sapiens. Allowing usage of ORVs on CALO gives disabled persons the means to visit areas that would otherwise be inaccessible. Restricting ORVs from CALO restricts accessibility for disabled persons, and therefore may be in violation of NPS Directors Order #42. I am not disabled, but I, like everyone else, am getting older. At my present age, recreational opportunities on CALO without an ORV would be severely limited, and for those people who are older, or with certain infirmities, I would imagine they would be next to impossible. Plans to limit ORV usage on CALO therefore unfairly discriminate against older citizens of the USA.” (390880)  Likewise, for visitors with disabilities who come to the Seashore by themselves, opportunities are provided throughout the preferred alternative for transportation to areas of the Seashore in an ORV. Additionally, for those with a family member who is disabled or mobility-impaired, use of an ORV to drive that family member to the beach, even if it is not designated as an ORV route, could be accommodated on a case-by-case basis and would be subject to the conditions of a special use permit issued by the Superintendent.  181. Per the Seashore’s visitation data, which is summarized on page 238 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the Seashore acknowledges that the Seashore was closed for 2.5 months due to Hurricane Irene, and that data is unavailable for total vehicle days for that year. The data in the draft ORV management  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  plan/EIS is the most accurate data available. The draft ORV management plan/EIS does not include visitation data for 2013, but this data was updated in the final ORV management plan/EIS. Visitation data at the Seashore can be accessed online at https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/. During the October 2013 government shutdown, 37,212 people visited the Seashore. As a comparison, the total number of visitors to the Seashore in October 2012 was 72,785. This data appears to show a decline in visitation at the Seashore, which could be in part due to the government shutdown, likely combined with other external factors.   182.  Is Ophelia inlet or Middle Banks included in the plan? Is ATV access allowed in these areas?  “To make a long story shorter, as you know, there is another island called Ophelia or some call it the Middle Banks. I could not find this Island in the Plan. Calling the NPS, I was told there is absolutely no ATV access to this island even though the restrictions signs are not right down to water level. Is this true?” (387407)  The commenter is correct, any type of ORV access, including ATV/UTV access, is not currently permitted, and would not be permitted under the plan, on Middle Core Banks, unless it reconnects to the main island. Currently Middle Core Banks is closed because New Drum Inlet is open. Per the ORV management plan/EIS, In the event that an island is severed from another island (due to storms, flooding, etc.), the island would allow ORV use only if there is a ferry landing location on that island. If the island does not contain a ferry landing, then ORV use would be prohibited. For example, as of January 2013, Middle Core Banks is severed from the ferry service and is closed to ORV use. The island and its portion of the back route would become accessible to ORV use if Old Drum Inlet closes and Middle Core Banks becomes accessible to vehicles (i.e., if Middle Core Banks reconnects to an island that has ferry service).  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  AFFECTED ENVIRONMENT – PARK OPERATIONS  183.  How many driving violations are issued in the park?  “I would be very interested in knowing many driving violations are written in the park. Most people I know that take their vehicles to the park respect the park and the rules the NPS has in place (whether we like them or not).” (387295)  Page 197 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS states that “Law enforcement rangers issued eight citations for pedestrians in bird areas and nine citations for vehicles in bird areas in 2012. In addition, 35 dog off leash citations, 12 written warnings, and 118 verbal warnings were issued in 2012.” However, after further examination, the Seashore found that this information is incorrect and should be revised. In 2012, law enforcement rangers issued four citations for pedestrian in bird areas and eight citations for vehicles in bird areas. In addition, 125 dog off leash citations, 75 written warnings, and 749 verbal warnings were issued in 2012. This information has been changed in the final ORV management plan/EIS.   184.  Is the ORV plan needed to generate revenue at the Seashore?  “FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SEQUESTRATION: Could the fact that in 2013 the National Park Service at Cape Lookout suffered a reduction of $123,000.00 from their $ 2.4 million dollar budget have anything to do with their ORV plan? Is the proposed development to sell ORV permits and other costs our Park Managers idea to regain funds and manpower? Superintendent Kenney stated that 84% of the $ 2.4 million dollar budget pays employee salaries and fixed cost such as utilities.” (399928)  ORV permit fees would be based on cost-recovery, meaning that all fees would be used to administer the new program, not to fund existing operations. The plan is not being implemented to generate new funds for existing operations unrelated to ORV management.   185. Natural sounds like wind and waves are louder than ORVs.  “Soundscapes Acoustic Environment." The surf is louder than most ORVs on the island. Boats in the sound are louder than vehicular noise on the island.” (387884)  The elevated natural ambient sound level on the surf side of the islands was incorporated in the soundscapes impact analysis, including the effect of surf noise masking ORV noise. The surf sound level was estimated to be 63 dBA at a distance of 50 feet (draft ORV management plan/EIS, table 53), and approximately 40 dBA near the sound side of the islands. The extent of soundscape impacts from ORVs varies depending on the location of the ORV relative to the surf and the location relative to the receiver. The analysis supports the experience of the commenter that ORV use would not increase the sound levels for receivers closest to the surf (e.g., R1). In terms of the Lmax metric, the largest potential impacts are close to the ORV due to the masking effect of the surf/wind and because the potential impact from operation on the back route (sound side) is higher than the beach side.  CONSULTATION AND COORDINATION  187. The North Carolina State Historic Preservation Officer stated that their concerns were addressed.   “Thank you for your letter of May 14, 2014, concerning the above project. We believe the Management Plan/Environmental Impact Statement adequately addressed our concerns for historic resources. The NPS spent several years and hundreds of thousands of dollars seeking a solution that would be acceptable to all parties at Cape Hatteras National Seashore, only to terminate the process without a consensus agreement. Large species closures would result in certain areas being closed to fishing or hunting, which would require NPS to consult with the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission and the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources prior to implementing the closure.  “As provided in existing management (although it is not clear whether NPS staff follow this protocol), the full 300-foot or 600-foot buffers for American oystercatchers and piping plovers, respectively, should not be put in place until an American oystercatcher or piping plover chick is found using the ocean beach (To the extent that a resource closure results in certain areas being closed to fishing or hunting, except in emergency situations, NPS is required to consult with the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission and the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources prior to implementing the closure. 16 U.S.C. ï¿½ 459g-3. By prohibiting ORV use (either during a time of year or closing a certain area), the effect is to essentially close the area to fishing and hunting, and therefore NPS is required to consult with these state agencies prior to implementing the closure.). The Coalition strongly objects to the expanded closures under Alternative C. NPS has failed to provide any rationale justification to support expanding closures at the Seashore.” (399705)  NPS is not regulating fishing through this plan and rulemaking, and is already consulting with the State of North Carolina.  GENERAL NEPA ISSUES  199. The NPS should take action to designate proposed Wilderness at the Seashore.  “The NPS studied Cape Lookout for wilderness suitability, conducted public hearings but never submitted the proposal to the Secretary of the Interior or transmitted it to the President or to Congress. The last proposal, in August 1985, recommended 2990 acres as wilderness and 2 acres as potential wilderness. That proposal is depicted on map #623-20,050D dated July 1985. The wilderness study excluded thousands of the more than 25,000 acres of federal lands that were otherwise suitable but the NPS expressly wished to keep open to ORV use. At a minimum, and in accord with NPS Management Policies, the NPS must safeguard from ORV use the acres that the NPS found suitable for wilderness. The Draft does that and PEER supports the proposal that would keep the wilderness suitable areas on Shackleford Banks free from ORV use. PEER urges that you take action to forward the wilderness proposal to the Director and the Secretary.” (399264)  Designation of Wilderness on Shackleford Banks is outside the scope of this ORV management plan/EIS.  201.  The plan should include ecological monitoring.   “The general ecology of the island should be monitored to ensure a relative understanding of the natural ecological cycles occurring on the island, and to maintain baseline data for comparing change over time.” (385126)  The NPS must balance the needs of those who use the beach for recreation with the needs of wildlife that use the beach and islands for survival. For this reason, the Seashore’s resource management staff spends most of the spring and summer monitoring and marking the areas needed by nesting shorebirds (piping plover, red knot, American oystercatcher, Wilson’s plover, and colonial waterbirds) and sea turtles, as well as endangered plant species (seabeach amaranth). The Shackleford horses are monitored all year as well. These monitoring activities are summarized in annual reports and are available on the Seashore’s website. These monitoring activities are a part of the ORV plan and will continue into the future.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  APPLICABLE LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND EXECUTIVE ORDERS  202.  The Seashore was founded to provide for recreational use. Restrictions are against the Seashore’s purpose, significance, and enabling legislation.  In addition, Executive Order 11989 does not require NPS to restrict ORV use and regulations that restrict use are not the spirit and intent of this executive order.  “The Mission statement of Cape Lookout National Seashore states that the seashore was established by Public Law 89366 (March 10, 1966) "to preserve for public use and enjoyment an area in the State of North Carolina possessing outstanding natural and recreational values ... " On Page iv, Purpose and Significance of .... To restrict or prohibit Off Road Vehicles (ORVs) would violate the enabling legislation that would diminish or prohibit the use and enjoyment of the park by a significant and historic proportion of the park visitors. The use of ORVs is historic and predates the founding of the seashore, but has become an increasingly targeted and regulated form of recreation and visitation.” (398898) “The very purpose CALO was created for is lost in the NPS preferred alternative. It states "to preserve for public use and enjoyment an area in the state of North Carolina possessing outstanding natural and recreational values". The only alternative the NPS could lawfully adopt is the aforementioned as evidenced by the bias for resource protection in the NPS action alternatives and preferred alternative. CALO is a national seashore, not a wildlife refuge and should be managed according to the aforementioned.” (385126) “Alternative C, NPS's preferred alternative, is inconsistent with the Organic Act, the Cape Lookout Enabling Act, the Executive Orders, and NPS Management Policies. In describing its selection of the preferred alternative, NPS states that "[t]he 'agency's preferred alternative' is the alternative that the agency believes would fulfill its statutory mission and responsibilities, giving consideration to economic, environmental, technical, and other factors." Draft ORV Plan, p. 78. In other words, the preferred alternative is not necessarily the "environmentally preferred alternative"  The authority of NPS to develop the ORV plan/EIS is not limited to Executive Order 11989, but also comes from Executive Order 11644, 36 CFR 4.10, and more broadly, the NPS Organic Act and the Seashore’s enabling legislation.  The Organic Act gives NPS broad authority and discretion to manage the sometimes conflicting goals of resource conservation and visitor enjoyment and to determine how visitor activities, including recreational activities, may be managed to avoid or minimize impacts to natural and cultural resources. The express text of the Organic Act does not mandate that NPS equally balance preservation with public use in making its management decisions. Courts have held that the Organic Act places an overarching concern on preservation of resources in the management of national parks. Since the act speaks of but a single purpose, conservation, where the goals of resource preservation and user enjoyment conflict, preserving the resources takes precedence. Thus, the NPS interpretation of the Organic Act as allowing the Seashore to manage appropriate recreational uses in the interest of resource protection is consistent with the act and is a proper exercise of discretion. Other laws and policies also support the NPS decision to manage recreational use at the Seashore. The General Authorities Act, which amended the Organic Act, requires NPS to manage all units of the park system so as to  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  (i.e., the alternative with the least environmental impacts). Rather, the preferred alternative must comply with NPS's statutory mission and must consider other factors, including economic impacts. Under Alternative C, NPS proposes a number of additional unnecessary and burdensome restrictions on ORV use at the Seashore, which would significantly limit public access to the Seashore and corresponding public recreation opportunities at the Seashore and would result in significant adverse impacts to the local and state economy and. These unnecessary restrictions, which would significantly limit access to and use of the Seashore (with little to no additional benefits of protecting natural resources and potentially increasing conflicts among users), are inconsistent with applicable laws and regulations. The Cape Lookout Enabling Act provides that: "The Secretary shall administer the Cape Lookout National Seashore for the general purposes of public outdoor recreation, including conservation of natural features contributing to public enjoyment." 16 U.S.C. ï¿½ 459g-4(a). NPS has acknowledged that "[t]he enjoyment of park resources and values by people of the United States is part of the fundamental purpose of all parks and that the NPS is committed to providing appropriate, high-quality opportunities for visitors to enjoy the parks." Draft ORV Plan, p. 478 (citing NPS Management Policies 2006 ).” (399673) “Executive Order 11989 only requires NPS to designate trails or ORV routes. The Executive Order is quoted by NPS as requiring restricted use or conveys that the executive implies that NPS must restrict the use. The historical intent of the regulation based on 36 CFR 4.10 was originally meant to provide public access to parks and wildlife and to designate routes. It does not state that the NPS may close a route or public access without properly providing a negative impact statement to the environment. Which is exactly the case with implementing the ORV regulations. The regulation is not based on factual evidence provided by the NPS that these routes and current usage cause a detrimental impact to the environment. NPS should provide founded evidence  effect the primary purpose of the Organic Act, which is to conserve park resources. Unless the general provisions of the Organic Act are in express conflict with any specific provision, they are applicable to all areas within the national park system. Because all units of the park system—including seashores—are to be managed to conserve and avoid impairment of resources, a unit’s designation as a park, monument, or recreation area is irrelevant with regard to the NPS duties under the Organic Act, except where Congress explicitly directs specific treatment for particular park units. The Seashore’s enabling legislation does not specifically mandate or authorize ORV use, nor does it require or authorize NPS to allow unmanaged recreation that damages park resources or values in violation of the Organic Act. Even for legislatively mandated uses (which ORV use is not), the NPS has the authority and must manage and regulate the use to ensure, to the extent possible, that the impacts on park resources from that use are acceptable (NPS Management Policies 2006 sec. 1.4.3.1). The Seashore’s enabling legislation and the Organic Act must be read in tandem when evaluating the appropriateness of NPS management decisions, as the former supplements, but does not supersede, the latter.  Further, while the executive order does not explicitly call for regulation of vehicles, some regulation is necessary for NPS to meet the requirement of the executive orders that routes be located to minimize damage to soil, watershed, vegetation, or other resources of the public lands; that routes be located to minimize harassment of wildlife or significant disruption of wildlife habitats; and that trails shall be located  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  of historical depredation based on ORV use. The EIS studies that are provided do not strictly limit themselves to ORV impact. Historical hurricane data, area predator impact and yearly environmental changes are the primary reasons for environmental change to island habitat. The generalization of merely stating ORV traffic will increase the insatiability of island habitat is overreaching and contradicts the spirit and intent of the Federal Regulation.” (391306)  in areas of the national park system only if the respective agency head determines that off-road vehicle use in such locations will not adversely affect their natural, aesthetic, or scenic values.  PLAN OBJECTIVES  203. "I realize anyone has the right to give an opinion on any National Park. However, in this dialog who's more important to listen to, Special Interest Groups from around the country that have never been/never intend to visit CALO, just sitting behind their computers writing in on subjects that do not affect them; or people like me and others who actually spend time at CALO, understand the make-up of the island, love and respect it; and are not only 'interested in' but are also 'affected by' it? I can only hope that our opinions carry Additional Weight in these matters." "At the meeting in Charlotte you mentioned that much of what you were hearing from those of us who spend time at CALO was info you were hearing for the first time. I hope that you are truly listening to input from those of us who spend the most time there driving on the back road and the beach, keeping the island free of trash, rescuing animals when there are no NPS rangers there, and living through the fierce storms that sometimes occur with little warning. The draft ORV management plan/EIS uses vague phrases to describe impacts, and does not use hard evidence.  “Throughout the draft ORV/EIS plan, vague phrases such as could impact, the potential to, could result, may cause, had the potential, potential impacts, among others, are used as justification for enacting further restrictions, limiting access or banning ORVs from the seashore. As best I can tell, no hard evidence is presented to support the contention that operation of ORVs on the seashore id detrimental to the environment.” (399907)  When preparing environmental assessments and environmental impact statements, it is common practice for federal agencies to use “would” instead of “will” when describing impacts under the proposed alternatives, given that a selected alternative has not yet been determined. Once an alternative is selected for implementation in the Record of Decision, the NPS changes the text in the Record of Decision from “would” to “will,” because the selected alternative has been approved and will occur. “Could, may, might, and possibly” are appropriately used in NEPA impact analyses because there are often varying levels of uncertainty implicit in predicting impacts. Effects that are completely speculative are not included in the impact analysis. Also, please refer to the lengthy list of references in the ORV management plan/EIS for particular scientific studies referenced.   205. Any emissions from vehicles are quickly dissipated by the prevailing winds. There is already a gift store there which is open most days, and there is electricity that could be used for freezers or icemakers. Additionally, tractors at the camps are already rigged with back blades for scraping the roads and lift for the dumpsters. Could these same tractors move a dumpster to and from the lighthouse and scrape the back road along the  Air quality was a topic dismissed from further analysis; refer to page 21 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.
