Cape Hatteras National Seashore should not be used as a comparison to Cape Lookout National Seashore.   “Unlike other barriers island along the North Carolina coast, including Cape Hatteras National Seashore (NPS's reliance on the Cape Hatteras National Seashore Long-Term ORV Management Plan/EIS, see Draft ORV Plan, p. 485, is arbitrary and capricious. Unlike Cape Lookout, Cape Hatteras National Seashore has experienced a relatively steady increase in visitation. Since 1990, at least 2 million visitors have recreated at Cape Hatteras National Seashore every year. NPS estimated that between April 2009 and March 2010, approximately 500,000 vehicles traveled on the beach at Cape Hatteras National Seashore. On the other hand, visitation to Cape Lookout has decreased from a high of 860,602 visitors in 2007 to 480,290 visitors in 2012. Similarly, in 2007, a total of 5,709 vehicles were transported by ferries to North Core Banks and South Core Banks; in 2009, a total of 4,157 vehicles were transported by ferries to North Core Banks and South Core Banks.), public access to the Seashore is only by boat. Other than private boats, three private ferry operators provide the public and ORVs access to the Seashore. Two other ferry operators transport passengers (but not ORVs) to the lighthouse area. These ferry service operators operate under an annual commercial use authorization ("CUA ").” (399662)  NPS agrees that Cape Lookout National Seashore and Cape Hatteras National Seashore are two different and unique areas, with different level of use, and the alternatives considered in the ORV management plan/EIS take these differences into consideration. There are also similarities given that both plans regulate ORVs and propose to designate routes to comply with executive orders and NPS regulations.  Regarding visitation numbers at Cape Lookout National Seashore, these numbers have decreased for Harkers Island only, however, numbers for North and South Core Banks have not decreased and have remained stable. Visitation numbers are provided in the final ORV management plan/EIS, chapter 3, in the section “Visitor Use and Experience.”  207.  Natural forces impact erosion more than ORV use.  “It states that human activity along shoreline can accelerate erosion, compared to the crash of a wave or the southeast wind blowing sand so strong it quickly undermines an ORV and encapsulates any object in its path. Ive seen Portsmouth Flats look like a washboard with 12-18 inch sand piles after a blow, 2 months later flats again. I understand that the beach was ï¿½ mile or greater in front of the Long Point Cabins many years ago, Mother Nature is a powerful force, she has and will continue to re-configure the islands and impact the inhabitants.” (389550)  The impacts of ORVs on geologic resources, including the beach, are discussed on pages 18–19 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS (“Issues Considered but Dismissed from Further Consideration”). As stated in that section, “Although these potential impacts on the geology of the Seashore are present, the Seashore is part of a dynamic coastal barrier ecosystem, and visual effects of ORVs on ocean beaches may no longer be visible in a day due to daily tidal action, winds, rain,  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  hurricanes, and other storm events.” Therefore, the NPS agrees with the commenters that the dynamic nature of the Seashore changes and influences the islands.  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – CULTURAL RESOURCES  208.  The use of ORVs as a cultural resource was not considered in the ORV management plan/EIS.  “The use of ORVs is HISTORIC, and predates the founding of the seashore. This alone is a cultural resource component that you have not addressed.” (387960)  The use of ORVs is not a historic resource protected under the National Historic Preservation Act. However, the plan does acknowledge that ORV use predates the founding of the Seashore, and describes why ORV access is important to many visitors. Refer to the “Visitor Use and Experience” sections in chapters 3 and 4.   POTENTIAL IMPACTS – THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES  209.  The draft ORV management plan/EIS does not take into account the full range of impacts to piping plover.   “Despite documented research on Piping Plovers (Page 170) and observation of Piping Plovers activity within the seashore, the accompanying data fails to take into account the full range of factors that is all present, perhaps insurmountable obstacles, to the revitalization of the species across its range.” (398138)  The draft ORV management plan/EIS acknowledges that a number of other factors besides human activities impact piping plovers at the Seashore, notably weather (e.g., hurricanes) and predators. However, the Seashore is focusing on minimizing factors it has control over (e.g., human disturbance and predation) as opposed to factors it has no control over (i.e., weather events) in order to maximize the productivity of the piping plover and other protected species at the Seashore.  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – GENERAL WILDLIFE  210.  Statements regarding the contribution of ORVs to sand  “During low tide, ORV use in the intertidal zone by users seeking firm sand may result in mortality of individual invertebrate species or loss of food and habitat resulting  In discussing the potential impacts on invertebrates from vehicles driving on the firm sand of the intertidal zone on page 433, the  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  compaction and ORVs  from compaction under vehicle tires" An absolutely ridiculous  draft ORV management plan/EIS is referring to  impacts to  statement. Those same invertebrate species would suffer  the compaction (i.e., crushing) of invertebrates  invertebrates at low  the same mortality by a human foot. What is next, no walking  under vehicle tires, not the compaction of sand  tide are not accurate.  on the beach?” (384982) “Other Wildlife Habitat. During low tide, ORV use in the intertidal zone by users seeking firm sand may result in mortality of individual invertebrate species or loss of food and habitat resulting from compaction under vehicle Tires." Vehicles do not compact sand. Wind and water are the only things that do this. Look at the difference on the beach one year after Hurricane Sandy. It went from flat and hard to built up and soft. Tides, storms and winds move more sand every hour than all the vehicles do in an entire year. This statement is from the Cape Lookout National Seashore website: "Did You Know? Barrier islands, such as those of Cape Lookout National Seashore, are piles of sand. As storms come up from the ocean the beaches are constantly rearranged. "” (399856) “The statement about ORVs and migration of sand toward the beach is contingent on the contours of the beach, the steeper the grade the increase in displacement. Compared to the forces of nature that constantly take millions of dollars of beach replenishment back out to sea, sand migration because of ORVs is insignificant. Compaction by ORVs is insignificant as well; one of the reasons for lowered tire pressure is to allow ORVs to float on the loose sand. Besides, there would be no need for 4 wheel drive ORVs if a compacted base were present.” (389556) “We are not Hatteras National Seashore; we don't have a state highway that allows random access for driving on the beach. We are not crowded like Hatteras. The NPS has been closing the beach for birds and turtles for 30 years. Their own numbers show that populations are doing fine with more nest and hatchings every year. There are many questionable negative comments stated in the need for an ORV plan such as "Heavy Vehicles compact soil." This is not  causing an impact to invertebrates. The analysis on page 433 states “Driving on the sands of the intertidal zone would likely have adverse impacts on invertebrates due to mortality of individual species caused by compaction under vehicle tires” (Wolcott and Wolcott 1984). As noted on page 278, and elsewhere, the draft ORV management plan/EIS acknowledges that ORVs only sink about one tenth of an inch into the firm wet sand of the intertidal zone (Wolcott and Wolcott 1984) and that studies by Wolcott and Wolcott (1984) and van der Merwe and van der Merwe (1991) show that a number of species, especially those species that burrow into the sand in the intertidal zone when the tide is out, are either immune or highly tolerant of ORV traffic. However, studies, such as those by Schlacher et al. (2008), Leatherman and Godfrey (1979), and Wolcott and Wolcott (1984) have also shown that some species are highly susceptible to impacts from ORVs driving in the intertidal zone. Leatherman and Godfrey (1979) found that as few as 50 vehicle passes per day over a 20 day period decimated clam worm and soft-shell clam populations and Schlacher et al. (2008) found that ORV impacted beaches had significantly fewer species of invertebrates at reduced densities than non-ORV beaches. Additionally, as discussed on page 433 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, access to the intertidal zone often requires vehicles to cross over the wrack line, an area of high concentrations of invertebrates due to the large deposits of kelp and other debris available. Driving over the wrack line can crush and  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  true - you cannot compact sand; ask the Egyptians. Look at the difference on the beach one year after Hurricane Sandy. It went from flat and hard to built up and soft. Tides, storms and winds move more sand every hour than all the vehicles do in an entire year.-“ (387792)  scatter seaweed, shells, and macro-invertebrates, causing damage and dispersal of an important source of food and habitat for many beach invertebrates (Kluft and Ginsberg 2009; Stephenson 1999). A three-year study on Cape Cod and Fire Island, New York (Kluft and Ginsberg 2009), found that the shrimp-like crustaceans called amphipods are particularly vulnerable to drying out in immature stages, and use the wrack line as cover. Several species of flies use the site to lay their eggs, and wolf spiders (family Lycosidae) migrate back and forth from the beach grass to the wrack line to feed on these amphipods. The study observed that higher ORV traffic resulted in dispersal and desiccation of the wrack line, thereby reducing the populations of invertebrates in these areas. As one commenter notes, and as recognized in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, the Seashore is part of a dynamic coastal barrier ecosystem, and the daily tidal action, winds, rain, hurricanes, and other storm events disturb the geology of Cape Lookout National Seashore (page 19). However, as cited in the draft ORV management plan/EIS on page 278, studies have also found that vehicle traffic on beaches do compact sand and can displace large amounts of sand (Anders and Leatherman 1987; Schlacher and Thompson 2008), which can contribute to erosion, especially during high tides or on narrow beaches where driving is concentrated higher on the beach and this can also impact invertebrate species. In the Schlacher and Thompson (2008) study, they found that over a 3-day period coinciding with a peak holiday period, that a total of 398 vehicle ruts documented at 10 sites (five sites each along two beaches) disrupted (i.e., displaced  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  and compacted) 33,018 cubic meters and 12,573 cubic meters of sand in one day respectively for each beach. This equated to disrupting 5.8 percent and 9.4 percent, respectively for each beach, of the sand habitat occupied by invertebrates (i.e., top 30 cm) between the wrack line and the base of the foredunes in a single day. Although Anders and Leatherman (1987) conducted their study at Fire Island National Seashore, which at the time had much more vehicle use than Cape Lookout National Seashore; they conducted controlled experiments with a set number of vehicle passes ranging from as little as 5 vehicle passes to as many as 75 vehicle passes. They found that the initial vehicle passes were the most significant in displacing sand downslope and that that amount of sand displaced with each subsequent vehicle pass decreased. Furthermore, Anders and Leatherman (1987) found that traffic compacts the sand at depth while loosening the sand at the surface, making it more susceptible to erosion. They found this to generally occur higher up on the beach, which may lead to steeper dune profiles, while the high moisture content and already compact nature of the foreshore made it the least susceptible to physical disturbance by ORVs. The changes in beach profile and substrate characteristics may reduce the suitability of the habitat for wildlife (Cohen et al. 2010). These studies and findings show that while some invertebrate species are immune from or highly tolerable of ORVs using the intertidal zone, others are not and are impacted through being compacted (i.e., crushed) under vehicle tires. While impacts to sand itself could occur, as stated in chapter 1 of the plan/EIS, these  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  impacts would be minimal due to the dynamic nature of the Seashore.  211.  Are impacts to wildlife based on studies and are those studies available?  “Wildlife/Envir. Impacts based upon data from studies? Who performed, Where are these publications (if avail)?” (392152) “Lastly, where is the scientific documentation on the effects of ORVs on habitats of the native animals. (what measurements are being made to protect these habitats from hurricanes?)” (387341)  The draft ORV management plan/EIS adequately cites studies throughout the impact analysis in chapter 4 describing the impacts that ORVs and other human activities have on wildlife and the beach environment. The full references for the in-text citations can be found in the “References” section of the draft ORV management plan/EIS beginning on page 547. The cited material was obtained from libraries such as the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, online from various agency and journal websites, through public comment, and other means. All references cited in the document will be included in the administrative record for the project.  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – SOUNDSCAPES  212.  Noise from ORVs at the Seashore is overshadowed by wind and wave noise. Overhead aircraft are the only noticeable noise over the wave sounds.  “The use of ORVs at the Seashore could create noise emissions that could impact visitors, wildlife, and wildlife habitats by altering the natural quiet and soundscapes of the Seashore" The sounds of the waves muffle noises. The loudest noise I have ever heard is the waves or the military aircraft that fly over the island on a regular basis. Unless you are very close, it is hard to hear a person talking or vehicles running. People walking or talking on the beach may be offensive or arguable disturbing the ecosystem. People birdwatching could arguably be adversely disturbing various protected avian species. In reality, species will adapt to humans or vehicles in close proximity. The various protected and endangered species are the result of development of their habitats and pollutants to their environment- not from fishermen and their ORV's. Restricting fisherman from  The elevated natural ambient sound level on the surf side of the islands was incorporated in the soundscapes impact analysis, including the effect of surf noise masking ORV noise. The surf sound level was estimated to be 63 dBA at a distance of 50 feet (draft ORV management plan/EIS, table 53), and approximately 40 dBA near the sound side of the islands. The extent of soundscape impacts from ORVs varies depending on the location of the ORV relative to the surf and the location relative to the receiver. The analysis supports the experience of the commenter that ORV use would not increase the sound levels for receivers closest to the surf (e.g., R1). In terms of the Lmax metric, the largest  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  enjoying their passion or restricting bird-watchers access to  potential impacts are close to ORVs due to the  observe various species will not solve any issues.” (384981)  masking effect of the surf/wind and because the potential impact from operation on the back route (sound side) is higher than the beach side. Military overflights were considered in the soundscapes cumulative impact analysis. Although not quantitatively modeled, pedestrian-related noise (people talking on the beach) was considered and found not to be a major source of disturbance to natural soundscapes. Evidence for the low level of pedestrian-related noise is the number of human activity types recorded at American oystercatcher nests in 2010 and 2011. There were less than 200 observations of pedestrians (through video and audio recording), compared to over 2,000 observations of passenger vehicles. With regards to habituation and impacts on protected species, the draft ORV management plan/EIS recognizes that one of the greatest concerns related to the protection of species, especially piping plovers, is habitat loss and degradation from development and beach stabilization (page 170, 195, 310). However, as cited throughout the draft ORV management plan/EIS, there are numerous studies indicating that recreation and ORV use also adversely impact protected species. Related to impacts from military overflights, in a study first cited on page 279 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, Simmons and Borneman (2012) concluded “…that it appears American Oystercatchers either do not view aircraft as a threat or have habituated to the presence of aircraft in their nesting environment.” While at the same time concluding that “In contrast, oystercatchers do appear to respond to all types  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  of ORV and pedestrian activity. Although ORV and pedestrian activity has been occurring in the nesting environment of the oystercatchers for many years, and some habituation may have occurred, ORVs and pedestrians presumably represent a greater threat to incubating birds than aircraft.” specifically noting that “…it is also likely that the smaller, lighter, faster, and louder ATVs are perceived by birds as more of a threat than other types of vehicles.” Thus, while sometimes species do habituate to disturbances; that is not always the case. Because of the protected status of some bird species at the Seashore coupled with the inherent uncertainties surrounding their reproductive performance, the NPS provides the required protection for these species from factors it can address, such as ORV use and human disturbance as opposed to factors it has no control over (e.g., weather events). This is consistent with NPS management policies provisions on listed species, which state the NPS will undertake active management programs to inventory, monitor, restore, and maintain listed species' habitats; control detrimental non-native species; control detrimental visitor access; and re-establish extirpated populations as necessary to maintain these species and the habitats on which they depend (NPS Management Policies 2006, Section 4.4.2.3).  213. The comment states that only one location was considered. As shown in the draft ORV management plan/EIS, figure 28, 18 locations representing a typical cross section of the Seashore were assessed for impacts. NPS was unable to locate a reference to the term “average soil” conditions in the affected environment or environmental consequences sections for soundscapes. Noise attenuation due to ground cover effects was accounted for using a soft cover attenuation rate of 4.5 dBA per doubling of distance. A soil scientist was not required for the soundscapes portion of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.  The 25 mph speed assumption was used because this is the speed limit in the 2013 Superintendent’s Compendium. It is important to note that a 25 mph “cruise” speed was used in the soundscapes modeling and the additional noise that results from vehicles accelerating was not directly modeled. Therefore, the use of an upper limit cruise speed may be high relative to typical operating speeds, but also serves to account for the potential for acceleration noise. This is supported by Figures 15 and 16 of the Federal Highway Administration traffic noise model technical manual, which show a motorcycle cruise noise level at 25 mph is approximately equivalent to a full throttle (accelerating) motorcycle traveling at less than  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  10 mph.3 The variation in natural ambient sound in different areas was accounted for in the modeling by using a different natural ambient background depending on the distance from the surf. The rationale for using motorcycle sound levels as a proxy for ATVs was explained in a footnote on page 457 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS. The exact difference between ATVs and motorcycles depends on the specific models being compared; some ATV models are louder than some motorcycle models, although the general observation that motorcycles are generally louder is correct and was appropriately disclosed as a conservative assumption.  The final ORV management plan/EIS has been clarified to note that impacts from administrative ORV use could occur in the pedestrian areas.  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – VISITOR USE  214. Pedestrians  The NPS must ensure that one visitor use does not preclude other uses, and ensure a mix of visitor uses, including pedestrian uses. Alternative C, the NPS preferred alternative, would limit ORV use through requiring ORV permits, which could slightly increase crowding based on the reduction. However, alternative C is being modified such that new pedestrian-only areas are seasonal only, reducing the potential for increases in crowding of ORVs. Furthermore, the initial number of permits has been modified for the preferred alternative. The number of ORV permits available will be set at 6,200, but will be reevaluated after five years. Any changes to the number of permits would be made through a civic engagement process. Furthermore, because the limit on the number of permits issued would be determined after collecting five years of useable data, it is not expected that visitors would be restricted from using ORVs at the Seashore. That is, the average will be based on five full operating years (meaning five years without major storms or other major events that cause closures greater than 14 days to park operations when ORV use is permitted).  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  embarking from ORVs will therefore be subject to any negative impacts of ORV vehicles, impairing the visitor experience, not enhancing it.” (390877) “In fact, if Alternative C is adopted, there would be greater opportunity for conflicts among users. There is no evidence of visitor conflicts at the Seashore.  “Finally, existing regulations are in place to promote visitor safety, including provisions related to vehicle and pedestrian safety under 36 C.F.R. 4.20 (right-of-way to pedestrians), 36 C.F.R. 4.21 (speed limits set in Superintendent's Compendium) and 36 C.F.R. ï¿½ 4.22 (unsafe operation), provisions in Superintendent's Compendium (ruts, filling holes, speed limit of 15 miles per hour within 100 feet of any person, vehicle, campsite or other structure). NPS has described the Seashore as "a safe visitor destination that is both esthetically and culturally pleasing." Draft ORV Plan, p. 76 .” (399670)  The draft ORV management plan/EIS stated the following objective related to visitor conflicts, “Minimize conflicts between ORV use and other users. Retain an experience where typically a family or individual traveling by ORV can experience the Seashore by finding a remote and otherwise unused stretch of beach.” As stated on page 74 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, “The objective to reduce visitor conflict would be met to some degree under alternatives A, B, and E, but the lack of  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  “Considering these facts and the low level of ORV use under alternatives A, B, C, and D, none of these alternatives would result in significant adverse impacts to natural landscapes." Draft ORV Plan, p. 477. With respect to minimizing conflicts among users, visitation and ORV use at the Seashore has decreased since the time that the Interim Management Plan was adopted. The number of recreational visitors at the Seashore fell from approximately 860,602 in 2007 to approximately 480,290 in 2012, a decline of approximately 44 percent. Similarly, the total number of ORVs that arrived at the Seashore declined from approximately 5,709 ORVs in 2007 to approximately 4,184 ORVs in 2012, a decline of approximately 27 percent. Based on this information, there is less opportunity for user conflict now than when the Interim Management Plan was adopted. Moreover, NPS has acknowledged that there is generally no conflict among users of the Seashore .” (399668)  use limits under alternatives A and B, and the inability of users to access remote areas of the Seashore under alternative E, may impact some visitors more than others and result in perceived conflicts, as described in some public comments. Alternatives C and D would meet this objective to a large degree because additional pedestrian-only areas would be established. Under all alternatives, the objective to ensure that ORV management promotes the safety of all visitors would be fully met.” Therefore, the NPS agrees that all alternatives, to some level, address visitor conflict at the Seashore. Regarding declining visitation levels addressing visitor conflict, while overall visitation to the Seashore has dropped relative to the highest level in 2007, data collected by the NPS shows that ORV use has been increasing. The alternatives in the ORV management plan/EIS address these trends.  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – SOCIOECONOMICS  218. In general, ORV regulations will impact the economy and may result in the ferries needing to close. More analysis should have been conducted on the impact to the ferry operations.  “One the most damaging repercussions would be monies lost to Ferry operators. ATV/UTV ferry fees amount to about 20-25% of their annual income. In the past 3 years, we have had two storms and a government shutdown in our biggest revenue months of those years. Without such a plan, I believe it would take years to resolve the multitude of issues needed to resume transport for ORV's to the islands. Any change in ORV regulations needs to assess the financial impact to the ferry operators as their viability is vital to effect ORV transport to the Park.” (395596)  In the draft ORV management plan/EIS, NPS used qualitative and quantitative information to consider the potential adverse impacts to businesses serving visitors using ORVs, including vehicle ferries. The analysis concluded that proposed restrictions and new requirements could result in some reduction in visitation by ORV users, and thus some loss of business by the vehicle ferry operators; a decline in ferry trips would result in decreased revenue for ferry operators.  In response to public comments, which among other things raised concerns about potential negative economic impacts, NPS has revised the preferred alternative which would reduce the potential adverse impacts to visitors using ORVs and ferry operators. For example, closure dates have been made consistent. Night-driving restrictions have been revised to allow back route driving from 5 am to 10 pm. New pedestrian-only areas are now seasonal only. Non-sport ATV/UTV use would now be permitted. Instead of 10-day and annual permits, there would be 3-day, 14-day (same as the length of time you can camp on the Seashore), and annual permits. NPS has revised the ORV permit structure and has  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  “Page 505 states "The Seashore has not conducted a study of visitor spending. NPS has created spending profiles based on surveys in other national parks..." This statement acknowledges a lack of effort by the park service by failing to do a detailed economic study of visitor spending at CALO that includes the vehicle ferry services. Vehicle ferry services is a very important component of ORV use, but the impact of the ORV plan on the vehicle ferry service business viability is not adequately analyzed in plan. By comparison the ORV Plan devotes 182 pages (page 271 through page 453) to the analysis of impact on protected species.” (399877) “The current ORV plan Socioeconomic Resource verbiage does not adequately analyze the socioeconomic impact that each of the five alternatives will have on the vehicle ferry services. I recommend the park service put more effort into doing analysis of the socioeconomic impact and business risk assessment of the vehicle ferry concessionaires for each of the five alternatives in the final ORV plan. One potential third party is the NCSU Sea Grant program. If the business risks are significant for the preferred Alternative C, the park service should develop a short-term solution that ensures continuation of vehicle ferry services. It may be necessary to consider emergency replacement of a current vehicle ferry concessionaire if the business risk assessment shows financial jeopardy and the business owners agree with the analysis.” (399910)  determined an initial limit of 6,200 vehicle ferry trips per year. This number will be revisited after five years and a civic engagement process will be used for any changes to this number. When looking at the first five years, significant closures would be excluded from overall numbers to avoid skewing the long-term average. Vehicle length restrictions have been removed.ATV trailer length restrictions have been removed from the preferred alternative and now ATV trailers and vehicle trailers have the same limits. Taken together, all of these changes to the plan would reduce the potential economic impacts because with these revisions, the preferred alternative would be more similar to alternative A, the no-action alternative. Thus, the potential adverse socioeconomic impacts would be reduced by these revisions.  220. How many jobs would be lost, how many people would have to move to find new jobs.” (389508)  The socioeconomic assessment provides a range of potential macroeconomic impacts to the region of influence (Carteret County) in Table 67 on p. 509. This table shows that potential job losses that would result from reduced visitation by ORV users ranges from a loss of 10 employees to a loss of 200 employees, depending on the scenario. Overall,  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  the impacts on the economy in the region of influence are expected to be small (at most a reduction of 0.6 percent in employment and county gross domestic product). With such a small percentage change in production and employment within the county economy, NPS did not quantitatively examine the impacts on the state’s economy; however, given the relatively small impacts estimated for the region of influence, NPS concluded that impacts on the state economy would be minimal.  221.  Clarify where an increase in jobs would come from under the alternatives.   “Economic impact. You mention the loss of jobs ( p509 ) as anywhere from 10 to 60 people, based on 10-30% reduction in visitation. You even mention the adverse affect on the ferry operators. You say increase in visitors could have beneficial results in additional jobs. I see these jobs being only through NPS, not in the small towns down east. It saddens me to see a plan put in place that we know will impact these people. I am interested to know where you see the increase coming from.” (398728)  NPS acknowledges the potential for adverse socioeconomic impacts, including employment reductions, concentrated in the businesses serving visitors who use ORVs. NPS also mentions the potential for increased visitation by visitors who do not use ORVs, including day visitors. There may be increased demand for passenger ferry service to serve these visitors, and because such visitors typically do not stay overnight at the Seashore, there may be increased business for hotels and restaurants on the mainland. However, NPS does not expect the increased demand for ORV-free visitation to completely offset the reduction in visitation by ORV users.  222.  The region of influence is not established correctly and diminishes the economic impact of the proposed regulations.   “Alternative C fails to meet NPS's mandate to provide adequate access to recreational opportunities at the Seashore, and NPS failed to adequately consider economic and other relevant factors. 1. NPS's socioeconomic analysis is severely flawed and arbitrary and capricious. As discussed above, in selecting its preferred alternative, NPS must not only consider the environmental impacts and benefits of its proposed action, but must also consider economics. NPS's socioeconomic analysis is severely flawed. There are many  NPS has carefully considered the potential socioeconomic impacts of the ORV management alternatives, using all qualitative and quantitative information available, and employing economic analysis methods that are widely accepted. Although direct adverse economic impacts may be concentrated on a few vehicle ferry businesses located in two towns within the region of influence, total  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  assumptions in NPS's socioeconomic analysis, which could result in significant errors in potential economic losses. First, given the number of major population centers in Carteret County and the overall economy, using the whole county as the Region of Influence ("ROI") disingenuously serves to greatly diminish the impacts of reduced ORV use on the communities serving Cape Lookout. For comparison, in 2010, the vehicle ferries transported approximately 16,000 passengers; in 2011, Fort Macon State Park had over 1 million visitors; between May 2006 and May 2007, Pine Knoll Shores Aquarium had over 600,000 visitors. Not surprisingly, NPS determined that "even a 100 percent reduction in visitation [to the Seashore] should not be significant for the ROI as a whole in the long term." Draft ORV Plan, p. 518.” (399674) “The remainder of the Socioeconomic Resource analysis seems to ignore the importance of the vehicle ferry services and instead focuses on the financial impact on the much larger economy of the entire Carteret County (ROI).” (399876)  impacts would likely be noticed throughout a wider area. The vehicle ferry operators and employees may reside in other areas of the county; they may purchase supplies and other inputs used in their ferry operations from businesses elsewhere in the county (or, in fact, outside the county). In overall magnitude, county-level impacts are estimated to be larger than firm-specific impacts, although in percentage terms the impacts on specific vehicle ferry operations may be larger. NPS has appropriately considered not only the possible impacts on directly affected businesses, but impacts on all Seashore visitors and on the larger region of influence. NPS defined the region of influence for this analysis to be Carteret County. In its general analyses of economic impacts of the spending of national park visitors, the local gateway region for each park unit was defined as all counties contained within or intersecting a 60-mile radius around each park boundary. Using a 60-mile radius here would include Carteret County and parts of several adjacent counties (Jones, Craven, and Pamlico). NPS concluded that using Carteret County as the region of influence for this analysis is consistent with this approach but also hones in on the area where the socioeconomic impacts are most likely to be concentrated.  223.  The socioeconomic analysis relies on the opinions of NPS staff. Visitor surveys should have been conducted to get a better understanding of the  “NPS acknowledges that long-term economic impacts are difficult to predict; however, other than informal discussions with ferry operators (It is not clear which of the three vehicle ferry operators, if any, were interviewed. At least one of the vehicle ferry operators was not interviewed for this study.), no effort was made to determine visitor preferences and how they might react to additional ORV restrictions. As a result,  NPS made use of a wide variety of information, including both qualitative and quantitative data such as visitation data, information on vehicle ferry and passenger ferry trips, interviews with ferry operators and other stakeholders, and information from NPS staff. However, NEPA allows for use of best available information and  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  impact.  the estimated economic impacts are based on the opinion of NPS staff, whose personal interests might conflict with the local community. NPS should have at a bare minimum conducted an informal visitors' survey at entry/exit points. As acknowledged by NPS, the economic impact to local businesses might be severe. Despite this acknowledgment NPS gave little consideration of the local community's opinions and failed to conduct a visitor survey .” (399679) “NPS states that losses from restricted ORV use could be offset by economic impacts from people who might seek ORV-free experiences and might potentially visit in greater numbers. NPS, however, acknowledges that even prohibiting ORV use at the Seashore would not result in a meaningful increase in other visitors to the Seashore. See Draft ORV Plan, pp. 507, 510. Despite these statements, NPS failed to perform any quantified surveys of potential shifts in visitation and an understanding of the spending differences between these two user groups. Although it is not clear how NPS determined its range of projected annual impacts (1 0%,3nd 100% reduction in visitation), NPS determined that even a 30% reduction in visitation (the mid-value) would result in economic losses ranging from $1,464,000 to nearly $3,000,000. Draft ORV Plan, p. 509.” (399682)  does not require creation of new studies where none currently exist. NPS estimated a range of impacts based on a range of potential reductions in visitation by ORV users to reflect the uncertainty about how visitors may change their behavior in response to the alternatives. Interviews with stakeholders including vehicle ferry operators resulted in a range of estimated reductions in visitation by ORV users. The selected percentage reductions used in the analysis (10 percent, 30 percent, and 100 percent) represent lowest expected, mid-range (reflective of estimated by vehicle ferry operators and other stakeholders), and highest potential reductions in visitation by ORV users. Analyzing this range of potential adverse economic impacts allows NPS to ensure that ORV management balances concerns about economic impacts with the need to protect natural, cultural, and recreational values of the Seashore.  “Page 503, paragraph 4: A statement is made that methods and assumptions are guided by past experience and historical data. The accuracy and reliability of using someone's subjective "past experience" to help predict quantitative changes in visitor travel patterns (including trips, expenditures) and business production decisions (including production and distribution of goods and services) needs to be questioned. The discussion should include an assessment of content, construct and criterion validity, and potential biases that could occur whenever subjects are queried in a survey-type setting such as recall bias, information bias, interviewer bias and strategic bias.”  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  (399795)  224.  The use of the campers spending profile (from Stynes) may underestimate activities associated with ORV use.  “Third, the use of the campers' spending profile for all trips may underestimate the spending associated with higher cost activities such as ORV use and maintenance, accessing islands, fishing gear and more.” (399680) “Page 505, last paragraph: Recreation visitor trips for economic impact analysis are typically divided into four categories: day-use, developed site (e.g., visits to Cape Lookout lighthouse); day-use, undeveloped site (e.g., fishing on an undeveloped beach area); overnight, developed (e.g., staying at a Cape Lookout cabin); and overnight, undeveloped (e.g., camping at a primitive beach area). Recreation expenditures vary across these categories as indicated by Table 1, page 3, in Stynes (2011). For example, expenditures on an overnight camping trip to a primitive beach area (overnight, undeveloped category) may be significantly different than an overnight trip to a Cape Lookout cabin (overnight, developed category). For example, cabin renters may spend more on food and beverages as compared to tent campers using primitive beach areas. Thus, more justification should be provided for selecting the camping expenditure profile from Stynes (2011), why expenditure profiles for these four categories were not used.” (399760)  NPS considered a range of possible data to be used in quantifying spending of visitors who use ORVs, and concluded that Stynes (2011) provided the best data available to estimate potential spending of visitors using ORVs. NPS selected the spending profile for “NPS Camp Ground,” believing that this profile was most representative of ORV users. While spending for some visitors to the Seashore could be characterized by local day-trip, non-local day-trip, or back-country camping, NPS chose to use “NPS camp ground” spending as the most representative of visitors who use ORVs. Further, because NPS camp ground spending is greater ($101.39 per day, compared to $40 to $70 per day for the other profiles), this represents a conservative assumption that would tend to overstate potential economic impacts.  225.  Other sources besides Stynes should be used to determine visitor expenditures.   “Also, although not delineated in Stynes (2011), recreation trip expenditures also vary by main activity. For example, expenditures on a recreation trip to Cape Lookout for the main activity or purpose of saltwater fishing (day or overnight) may be significantly different from expenditures to Cape Lookout for non-fishing activities such as bird-watching (day or overnight). For example, salt water anglers may have greater variable trip expenditures (e.g., bait, ice) as compared to bird-watchers. The Socioeconomic Resources section should review recreation trip expenditure and  NPS recognizes that visitor spending will vary depending on many factors, including the main purpose of the visit, as noted by the commenter. Similarly, the characteristics of ORV camping at the Seashore may be somewhat different from the average circumstances described in the article by Stynes. However, NPS feels that the Stynes expenditure profiles resulted from a well-documented, carefully analyzed study and are reasonable estimates to use for the visitors  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  economic impact studies other than Stynes (2011) to determine if the Stynes (2011) camping expenditure profile is an accurate representation of other categories of recreation trips to Cape Lookout with different main activities or purposes (e.g., day and overnight saltwater fishing trips). Considering the Stynes (2011) data may reflect camping trips with lower vehicle use, and considering the costs associated with maintaining and operating ORVs, spending per trip at Cape Lookout may be significantly greater than the generic profiles provided in Stynes (2011). Stynes D.J. (2011). Economic benefits to local communities from national park visitation and payroll, 2010. Natural Resource Socioeconomic Resources section NPS/NRSS/EQD/NRR2011/481. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.” (399761)  using ORVs at the Seashore. Further, some of the costs associated with maintaining ORVs would not necessarily be considered part of trip expenditures, but rather the cost of owning a vehicle wherever it is located.  226.  The socioeconomic impacts did not consider impacts from decreased personal vessel use that could result from the proposed action.  “The proposed ORV restrictions not only have the potential to impact the ferry operators, but also private vessels. It is common for one group to use the ferry service to transport the ORV, while others from the group travel to the Seashore by private vessels. Some of these individuals stay for the day or overnight at the Seashore, while others stay hotels in Beaufort, Morehead City and Harkers Island. The private vessels are used to bring over fuel, ice, food and other supplies. If the proposed ORV restrictions impact the ferry service, these restrictions will impact the money spent as a result of the private vessels. NPS's economic analysis failed to consider these potential economic impacts.” (399681)  While the scenario described by the commenter may sometimes occur, it was not mentioned to NPS in interviews, and does not reflect Seashore staff experiences. Furthermore, even if this were the case, the range of estimated impacts for socioeconomics would account for this change in visitation. In addition, socioeconomic impacts may be overstated given that the number of ORVs allowed through permitting would not be less than current use.  227. The economic study does not take into account the rates ferry operators pay to the North Carolina Utilities Commission, as a result of expired and overdue NPS contracts.  “Economic Impact Study: I don't believe the so-called economic impacts study for the operators of the vehicle ferries has been fairly evaluated. Amplified user fees, permits, plus either the real or perceived annoyance of increased NPS rules and regulations, will result in decreased ORV's spending their hard earned money with ferry operators. For ferry operators to stay in business they will be forced to decrease costs or increase fees. Something that the NPS may not understand, is those ferries operating under the North Carolina Utilities Commission, due to expired and overdue NPS contracts, (Davis Shore Ferry and Cape Lookout Cabins and Camps Ferry) do not have the ability regulate the rates and services of all public utilities in North Carolina. The Commission regulates electric, telephone (including payphone service and shared tenant service), natural gas, water, wastewater, water resale, household goods transportation, buses, brokers, and ferryboats. A number of time I have witness the Superintendent of the park joking state you can reduce your prices/rates and keep your customers. If they are like most  The draft ORV management plan/EIS evaluated potential impacts of the plan including potential impacts to ferry operators. The NPS examined a range of potential reductions in ORV visitation to the Seashore (including a 10 percent reduction, a 30 percent reduction, and a 100 percent reduction). The NPS analysis demonstrated that even a 100 percent reduction in ORV visitation would not have a significant impact on the Cape Lookout ROI. However, the NPS analysis states that impacts may be significant to a few businesses that serve ORV customers, including vehicle ferry operators. Specifically, the discussion of IMPLAN Model results in chapter 4 of the plan/EIS states: Although the impacts on the county as a whole may be small, the effects would be concentrated on a small number of businesses that serve  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  businesses, significant decreases in costs, without impacting safety or reliability, are not easy to find. This will drive one or more of the ferry operators out of business. This maybe the plan.” (399693)  Seashore visitors, particularly the vehicle ferry operators. It is believed that the ORV visitors typically stay on the island and their spending on hotels and restaurants may be limited. Their spending on other supplies, including gas, fishing and camping supplies, may be larger. However, as a percentage of total revenue, changes in the number of ORV visitors will have the greatest impact on the vehicle ferry operators because there are many other visitors who come to Carteret County beyond those that visit the Seashore. For businesses that directly serve ORV visitors, the impacts may be large, and it is possible that some businesses may close under these scenarios.  229.  The ORV management plan/EIS should take into consideration and recognize the economic impacts that ORV regulations have had at Cape Hatteras National Seashore.   “Since a consent decree was implemented in April of 2008, putting into place stringent pedestrian and ORV closures that have only expanded with the finalization of the ORV rule in 2012, the economic health of Ocracoke and Hatteras Island has experienced some alarming changes. The area's small businesses, which are primarily dependent on tourism from visitors who wish to recreate on the area's beaches, have shouldered the economic brunt of the ORV Rule. Small family businesses such as bait and tackle shops, retail shops, car washes and family owned motels have experienced 30-50 percent decreases in yearly income. The overall health of the islands is reflected in the drop in the number of businesses on Hatteras Island from 613 in 2012 to 593 in 2013. It is also reflected in Dare and Hyde counties' 2012 unemployment rates of 19 percent and 13 percent respectively, compared to 2008 rates of 10 percent and 8 percent respectively. We urge the National Park Service to recognize the severe socioeconomic impacts that additional access restrictions at CLNS can have on the area's businesses and residents who are so dependent on recreational access to the seashore, and work to minimize  NPS believes that the commenter is unjustified in attributing the reduction in economic activity during the period from 2008 to 2012 entirely to the NPS ORV rule at Cape Hatteras National Seashore, because the same period coincided with a severe economic recession throughout the economy.  Examining visitation patterns at Cape Hatteras National Seashore from 1990 through 2013, visitation during the periods 1990–1996, 2004– 2008, and 2009–2013 all averaged 2.2 million visitors per year. During the period 1997–2003, Cape Hatteras National Seashore averaged 2.7 million visitors per year.  ORV camping visitation shows a similar pattern: from 2000 to 2004, average ORV camping visitation was 28,005. During the period 2005– 2008, the average was 24,764. For the period 2009–2013, the average was 23,341. Visitation was down in 2008, but rose again in 2009 and  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  these impacts as much as possible.” (399744) “Page 519, second paragraph: This section discusses precedents, but fails to mention how recent decisions at Hatteras have restricted vehicle access and harmed local business. This experience provides helpful insights.”  (399795)  2010 to levels slightly higher than 2006 and 2007. Omitting 2011, which was the lowest year during the entire 15-year period, (probably due to Hurricane Irene), the average for 2009–2013 is 24,064—higher than the average for the period leading up to 2008. Thus, in terms of overall visitation, visitation by ORV users, and levels of economic activity, the Cape Hatteras National Seashore ORV rules do not appear to have had a severe impact, and overall business closures may be due to wider economic issues. However, it is likely that businesses that specialize in serving visitors who use ORVs may have incurred more serious impacts. This pattern corresponds to the expected pattern of economic impacts NPS has projected for the ORV rules at Cape Lookout National Seashore.  230. CLNS is located within the Carteret County, where there are multiple major population centers. Using Cateret County as the Region of Influence greatly diminishes the impacts to the community that reduced ORV would cause. Please see the attached socioeconomic analysis conducted by Southwick and Associates on the Cape Lookout DEIS for more details.” (399745)  NPS reviewed the economic analysis conducted by Southwick and Associates. The response to comments provided in this document addresses concerns raised in that analysis.   231. Clarify the survey methodology used for interviews.  “Page 504, paragraph 1: The methodology for the personal-interview survey conducted of ferry operators and Crystal Coast Tourism Authority members needs to be explained including respondent selection, survey question development and testing, survey implementation including interview selection and training, and response recording procedures including how open-ended question responses were recorded and coded for later quantitative analysis. The reference (RTI 2013) cites the source as personal communications, which implies non-scientific techniques, but the interpretation on page 504 implies otherwise.” (399757)  Interviews were semi-structured, guided by a predefined set of questions, while allowing the interviewer to follow up on ideas, and allowing the interview subjects to introduce topics not included in the interview guide. The purpose of the interviews was to gather focused stakeholder-specific information to enhance NPS understanding of the issues and opinions of the stakeholders. The interviews provide insights into quantitative estimates of impacts expected by individual stakeholders, but they are individual communications and not drawn from a statistical sample. Specifically, as stated on p. 504 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, interviews were conducted with three vehicle ferry operators and the Crystal Coast Tourism Authority. Results were tabulated, but were not “coded,” and there was no statistical analysis performed, because the number of respondents was extremely small and they were not uniform in content—these were interviews, not surveys. The range of responses to specific questions was reported on page 504 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, but due to the desire to keep confidentiality, specific responses are not provided in the draft ORV management plan/EIS.   233.  Clarify the methodology for using professional judgments and opinions in the  “Page 505, paragraph 2: The distinction between "approximate" and "assumed" variables is not clear since both are based on professional judgment. We assume that in both cases, "professional judgment" refers to NPS staff opinions. Because the NPS staff positions and expertise are  NPS used the best available information to analyze the socioeconomic impacts of the ORV management alternatives. However, data were incomplete. To enable NPS to use the limited data on expected impacts, NPS used a range of  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  analysis. If industry-established standards were not used, explain why.   not described, we do not know to what extent these can be considered "expert opinions". The methodology for eliciting professional judgments and opinions should also be described including an assessment of content, construct and criterion validity, and potential biases that could occur whenever subjects are queried in a survey type setting such as recall bias, information bias, interviewer bias and strategic bias (see also comment 2). In addition, if established industry-standard methodologies for eliciting profession judgment and option responses such as the Delphi process were not used, an explanation of why not should be provided.” (399758) “Page 512, first paragraph, last sentence: This sentence is an example of vague and subjective statements throughout the Socioeconomic Resources section crediting crucial assumptions and estimates to "staff observations" or "staff beliefs". First, besides assuming that "staff' refers to NPS staff, we do not know the staff positions and associated levels of expertise. Second, we do not know how the "staff' formulated these observations or beliefs. For example, how do staff members observe ORV drivers at night? Are they literally out on the island all night observing drivers? If so, how do we know the nights the staff member is out observing are typical or representative of other nights when night driving may be more prevalent? We also do not know if these observations or beliefs are more in the nature of "informed guesses" or hunches.” (399774)  possible values that were based on data from publicly available sources or interviews. The resulting values are identified as approximate values. For other variables, no data were available. For these variables, values were assumed, based on NPS professional judgment. Table 65 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS clearly identifies which variables are approximate (number of ORV and ATV/UTV ferry round trips, number of ORV passengers, number of ATV/UTV passengers, and number of ORV passenger ferry round trips) and which were assumed (ATV/UTV ferry round trips). No formal assessment of bias was performed. Information about directly affected businesses was necessarily limited by the relatively small number of vehicle ferry operators and other businesses serving visitors who use ORVs. Statistical methods are not feasible under those conditions, and more formal qualitative approaches may not have led to more complete or reliable information. With respect to night driving, no formal monitoring by NPS staff was undertaken. Observations of night driving behaviors resulted from NPS staff who were performing other duties, but happened to observe night driving activity.  To reflect the uncertainty about magnitude of potential impacts, NPS conducted its analysis using assumptions that would tend to overestimate impacts, and examined a very wide range of possible magnitudes of direct impacts. Using this conservative approach, NPS determined that even the largest direct impact would not have a large impact on the region of influence as a whole.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  234.  Define what is meant by “reliable data” as used on page 505 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.  “Page 505, paragraph 3, line 6: Define "reliable data"? Do you mean reliable in the statistical sense as indicated, for example, by confidence intervals? If not, how was reliability assessed?” (399759)  In the final ORV management plan/EIS, NPS deleted the word “reliable” from Paragraph 2 line 6, and replaced it with the word “established.” Assumptions are made when data are not sufficient to permit estimating approximate values; the word “reliable” should be deleted because it is used imprecisely in this context. NPS has available data on visitation and vehicle ferry trips, and supplemented the regularly collected data with information from interviews with vehicle ferry operators. These data enabled NPS to estimate “approximate” values for many model variables. However, as shown in Table 65 on p. 506 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS, NPS does not have sufficient information to estimate the number of ATV and UTV passenger ferry round trips, and thus assumed a number based on professional judgment of Seashore staff.  235.  A short visitor survey should have been conducted to determine approximate party size.   “Page 505, last paragraph: Why was a short, relatively inexpensive survey of visitors not conducted to determine the approximate average party size since this variable is a key factor determining total recreation expenditures and potential losses from decreased (or increased) recreation visitation? Given the limited entry/exit points for most users, a survey should be relatively simple to conduct.” (399762)  NEPA requires use of best available information, but does not require new studies to be conducted. A formal visitor survey of more than 9 people would require Office of Management and Budget approval, publication of two federal register notices, and additional costs, introducing a longer delay of the planning process. NPS concluded that the data from Stynes, combined with information from interviews with ferry operators and conservative assumptions to generate a range of potential values provides high quality information that is sufficient for the required analyses.  236.  The IMPLAN sector numbers should have  “In addition to the IMPLAN sector name, the specific IMPLAN sector number should be provided so that the  NPS will provide the IMPLAN sector numbers in addition to the sector description in the final  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  been provided in addition to the sector name.  analysis and results can be replicated, and to assess whether or not recreation trip expenditures were correctly allocated to appropriate IMPLAN sectors.” (399672)  ORV management plan/EIS.  237.  Important expenditure categories are missing from the expenditure profile.   “Some important expenditure categories are missing from the expenditure profile including bait and tackle shops, automobile rental (e.g., 4-wheel drive SUVs) and repair, ORV rental and repair, motorized and non-motorized boat rental and repair, commercial island guided tours, NPS cabin rental, and NPS entrance and parking fees. The Stynes (2011) profiles should be modified to reflect local activity and practices. Do the retail sector expenditures in Table 66 (food and beverage stores, gasoline stations, miscellaneous) only include retail margins as recommend in the economic impact literature (for example, see Stynes, 1999). A unique aspect of Cape Lookout is that the island is only accessible by boat. How are visitor expenditures on ferries, charter boats, and boat rentals accounted for in Table 66? They appear to be missing. If they are accounted for, are they assigned to areas on the island, off the island, or pro-rated across the two (and by which basis)? Stynes, D. J. (1999). Economic impacts of tourism. [Online]. Available: http://www.msu.edu/course/prr/840/econimpact, [August 12, 2014].” (399672)  NPS acknowledges that there may be small additional impacts associated with ORV rental and repair, NPS cabin rental and entrance and parking fees, and perhaps others in association with reduced visitation by ORV users. Supplies such as gasoline, food and beverage purchases, bait and tackle shops, etc., are included in the Stynes spending categories. Reduced expenditures on ferries are accounted for separately in NPS analysis. Other categories such as spending on charter boats and boat rentals, commercial island guided tours, etc., were not included because NPS does not expect them to be significantly affected by the rule.  238.  Explain the methods for creating regional values, as stated on page 508 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.  “Page 508, second paragraph: In this paragraph it is stated: "In some cases, regional values are created where no data previously existed, and for other categories new values are calculated to replace existing data". The methods for "creating" these values and the resulting values need to be explained and so that the analysis and results can be replicated and assessed for accuracy.” (399763)  NPS did not create regional values. The discussion on p. 508 describes the process that IMPLAN uses to adjust incomplete publicly available data so that values for all geographic areas and all sectors are internally consistent. The sentence in question explains why values in publicly available sources may not match IMPLAN values exactly.  239.  Explain how IMPLAN accounts for a sector  “Page 508, second paragraph: How does IMPLAN account for a sector with a small number of establishments such as  IMPLAN data are developed based on federal government databases: County Business  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  with a small number of  commercial ferries serving Cape Lookout? It is my  Patterns (from the U.S. Census Bureau), and  establishments.   understanding that due to privacy concerns, government data bases produced by the Bureau of Economic Analysis and other government agencies do not include economic activity data for sectors with a small number of establishments (e.g., less than 5).” (399764)  Census of Employment and Wages (CEW) data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and Regional Economic Accounts data from the Bureau of Economic Analysis. All of these may have non-disclosed elements. To develop a complete IMPLAN data characterization of a region (state or county), IMPLAN uses available information about more aggregated sectors to develop estimates of the missing data. Then, IMPLAN re-sectors the data from the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code to IMPLAN sector. Details on the procedures used are provided on the IMPLAN website at https://implan.com/index.php?option=com_cont ent&view=article&id=635:635&catid=258:KB38.  It should be noted that commercial ferry operators fall under IMPLAN Sector 334, Water Transportation.  240.  Clarify the standard for defining the economic impacts to the region of influence as “small.”  “Page 509, first paragraph, first sentence: By what standard are the economic impacts on the ROI judged to be "small"? And for the sub-region of Carteret county that depends more on Cape Lookout visitors, would these impacts be significant? Given the number of major population centers in Carteret county and the overall economy, using the whole county as the Region of Influence (ROI) serves to greatly diminish the impacts of reduced visitors to businesses dependent on Cape Lookout.” (399766) “Page 514, fourth paragraph, first sentence: By what standard are the economic impacts on the ROI judged to be "small"?” (399787)  Region of influence definitions depend on the area in which the majority of economic impacts are likely to occur, and it is a somewhat subjective determination. Selecting a smaller area reduces the total magnitude of estimated impacts because fewer of the multiplier effects are captured; however, on a percentage basis the impacts are larger when the base is smaller. Conversely, selecting a larger area increases the absolute magnitude of impacts by capturing more of the supply chain and consumer spending impacts, but the percentage change is smaller because the base is larger. Using the county or group of counties in which an event occurs as the region of influence is common. Sub-county regions of influence can be  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  constructed by combining zip codes or other small areas; however, such a region of influence would risk omitting supply chain businesses or residences of affected workers, and thus underestimating impacts.  241.  Why were social effects not detailed more?  “Page 509, first paragraph, second sentence: It is acknowledged here that negative economic impacts would be concentrated on a few businesses, particularly ferry operators. Economics is one part of the "triple bottom-line" of economic, social and environmental effects. Since the Socioeconomic Resources section deals with socioeconomic effects, why are not social effects including equity (distributional effects) and diversity given more attention and importance?” (399767)  In the section “Visitor Use and Experience” in chapter 4, distributional effects such as the impacts that ORV users and visitors seeking a pedestrian-only experience could face are detailed. This also includes the diversity of visitor experiences at the Seashore, including ORV use, swimming, sunbathing, beach walking, and shell collecting.  NPS gathered information to characterize minority and low-income populations in the region of influence, but impacts to these populations and Environmental Justice impacts were dismissed from further consideration. Refer to the section “Issues Considered but Dismissed from Further Consideration,” on pp. 18-25 of the draft ORV management plan/EIS.  242.  Please clarify where the statement regarding limited visitor spending on hotels and restaurants came from.  “Page 509, first paragraph, third sentence: The statement is made that: "It is believed that the ORV visitors typically stay on the island and their spending on hotel and restaurants may be limited". This is a very vague and subjective statement. Who in this sentence is doing the believing? What is this belief based on?” (399769)  This is based on anecdotal observations by park staff, including the fact that there are no restaurants on the Seashore itself, thus while staying on the island visits to restaurants would be limited.  243. However, the average number of visitors since 2008 is greater than the average number prior to 2001. NPS projected future visitation under alternative A based on data for ferry operations and visitation during the period 2005 through 2010. NPS determined 5,500 vehicle ferry trips per year for the draft ORV management plan/EIS, based on data from vehicle ferry operators for 2005 through 2010. With respect to equity or distributional impacts, NPS gathered information to characterize minority and low-income populations in the region of influence, but impacts to these populations and Environmental Justice impacts were dismissed from further consideration.
