For the socioeconomic analysis, what is the assumption that only a small portion of total ORV use would be impacted by the ATV/UTV ban based on?  “Page 512, second paragraph: If there are no data on the number of high performance sport model A TVs and UTVs, on what basis is the statement made that "the ban on these vehicles would only affect a small portion of total ORV use"?” (399776)  ATVs and UTVs are approximately 20 percent of vehicles transported to the island, and high-performance sport-model ATVs and UTVs are a subset of total ATVs and UTVs.  245.  Provide reference for permit holder and parking lot use data.  “Page 512, third paragraph: Provide reference for permit holder and parking lot use data.” (399778)  Data on parking lot and permits was compiled by NPS.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  246.  Clarify the source of the 10 percent to 30 percent reduction estimates.   “Page 512, fourth paragraph: What is the source of the 10% and 30% visitation reduction estimates and the basis for the statement, "If alternative B results in a decrease in overall visitation, it would likely be closer to 10 percent and probably not as large as 30% ... "? 21. Page 513, third paragraph: With respect to the claim of "minimal night driving", see comment 19.” (399780) “Page 514, third paragraph: What is the source of the 10% and 30% visitation reduction estimates and the basis for the statement, "If alternative C results in a decrease in overall visitation, it would likely be closer to 10 percent but potentially up to 30% or more ... "?” (399786)  In the absence of detailed data, NPS used the range of estimated visitation reductions (10 percent, 30 percent, and 100 percent) to examine the economic impacts associated with modest, mid-range, and severe reductions in visitation by ORV users to Cape Lookout National Seashore. These are assumed values. Ferry operators interviewed cited reductions of 25 percent to 75 percent under alternative B, 50 percent to 75 percent under alternative C, and 50 percent to 100 percent under alternative D. One survey respondent stated that alternatives B and C could increase visitation by pedestrian visitors, but alternative D would result in a 10 percent decline in overall visitation.  NPS used these estimates and examination of Cape Hatteras National Seashore visitation patterns since 2008, where ORV regulations have been enacted, plus best professional judgment, to select the values it used in modeling economic impacts.  247.  How many visitors without ORVs come to the island in the spring and fall?  “Page 513, third paragraph: How many non-ORV visitors come to the island in the Spring and Fall? 22. Page 513, fourth paragraph: With respect to the claim that high-performance ATVs and UTVs are a small portion of total ORV use, see comment 20.” (399781)  NPS has data regarding the number of visitors arriving by passenger ferry from 2014 to 2016 on the Island Express Ferry. For the purposes of the below numbers, spring was considered March, April and May; and fall was considered September, October, and November. Spring passenger ferry use has risen from approximately 16,800 in 2014 to 21,400 in 2016. Fall visitation was approximately 11,900 in 2014 and 12,900 in 2015 (data for the fall of 2016 is not yet available). NPS has not collected data on the types of ATVs and UTVs brought to the Seashore.  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  However, based on staff observations, ATVs and UTVs are approximately 20 percent of vehicles transported to the island, and high-performance sport-model ATVs and UTVs are a subset of total ATVs and UTVs.  248.  What method did NPS use for observations related to ATV and UTV use?  “Page 513, fourth paragraph, last sentence: Related to comment 19, by what method did NPS staff observe "very few visitors transporting ATVs and UTVs by private vessel"? How do we know if these observations on certain days and times of day are representative of private vessel use? If not conducted following a set protocol, individual observations of events can be highly subjective and biased from a statistical perspective.” (399782)  As noted in response #247, NPS did not formally monitor ATV and UTV delivery by private vessel. Instead, the information resulted from observing private vessel use in general, and is the best information available. During these observations, delivery of ATVs and UTVs was rarely observed.   249.  Why is it assumed that future use is necessarily constrained by parking space?  “Page 514, first paragraph: Why is it assumed that future use is necessarily constrained by parking space? As a response to increased recreation demand, both the private and public sector often respond by providing more capacity (supply).” (399784)  The amount of parking space provided at the Seashore is a policy decision. The amount of parking at the Seashore is based on resource protection, not on market demand. Currently, NPS has no plans to expand parking capacity in response to changes in demand for parking.  250.  How was the recession taken into account when determining permit caps?  “Page 514, second paragraph: When calculating the historical average number of vehicles transported to North and South Core Banks per year and the initial permit cap, how was the "Great Recession" taken into account which economic theory suggests would be reduce recreation demand and use? In particular, higher use before the "Great Recession" would be expected to lead to a higher permit cap.” (399785) “Page 515, first paragraph, line one: Related to comment 29, how did the comparison to "historical levels" account for the "Great Recession" (e.g., reduced recreation demand and use)?” (399788)  Based on NPS total visitation data, a generally increasing pattern of visitation to Cape Lookout National Seashore can be observed (with some variation) from about 1990 to 2007, and a generally decreasing pattern from 2009 to 2013. However, the average number of visitors since 2008 is greater than the average number prior to 2001. These visitor trends seem to indicate that the “Great Recession” did not cause a wide fluctuation in visitor use numbers. NPS has revised the ORV permit structure and has determined an initial limit of 6,200 vehicle ferry trips per year, based on data from vehicle ferry operators for 2005 through 2010. These  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  data include repeat trips/visitors, and therefore, allow for a higher number than represented by actual use during those years. The preferred alternative has been revised to better account for future events that may have a temporary impact on visitor use numbers. After further consideration, the adjustment period has been changed to five years of useable data. The average will be based on five full operating years (meaning five years without major storms or other major events that cause closures greater than 14 days to park operations when ORV use is permitted). The preferred alternative has also been modified to read, ‘If there is a year with a significant closure when ORV use is permitted, in excess of 14 days, that year will not be considered and an additional year will be used.”  251.  A parking lot survey should have been completed to determine impacts of eliminating long-term parking.  “Page 515, second paragraph: Why was not a short, relatively inexpensive survey (e.g., parking lot survey) conducted to query visitors on how ending long-term parking would affect their island recreation use patterns?” (399789)  Under the NPS preferred alternative C, longterm parking is not eliminated. Permitting requirements would be modified and parking lots would be reduced from 4 to 3, but parking would still be available.  252.  The analysis does not account for ORV users who do not currently visit the Seashore, but might in the future.  “Page 515, third paragraph: The adverse future economic impacts of Alternative D (and other alternatives that restrict ORV use) may be underestimated by not accounting for ORV users who do not currently visit Cape Lookout, but might in the future, especially if the current ORV use policy is continued into the future (e.g., less restrictions on ORV use as compared to Alternatives B-E).” (399790)  Visitation by ORV users at the Seashore has varied from year to year depending on weather, economic conditions, and other factors. NPS did not project increased future use because data do not clearly indicate that use is likely to increase. Note that impacts are measured from current conditions (baseline), not from an estimated future amount of visitor experience. Nonetheless, the 6,200 numerical limit under the revised preferred alternative includes repeat  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  visitors, whereas a permit system would only count such visitors once, thus the permit system will allow for some future growth.  253.  Clarify what is included in commercial ATV use. Alternative E discriminates against private ATV use.  “Page 516, first paragraph: Does commercial ATV provider use refer to both commercial rental of ATVs and guided ATV tours? Why does the ATV use policy (including Executive Order 11644) under Alternative E discriminate against private-owner A TV use on the island in favor of commercial provider A TV use?” (399791)  ATVs operated under a commercial use authorization (CUA) are regulated separately by the terms of the CUA; conversely, the definition of ORVs expressly does not include vehicles operated “under a permit, lease, license, or contract.” NPS does not discriminate against private-owner ATV use, but rather regulates it separately. Note that this section of the draft ORV management plan/EIS refers to alternative E, which would ban ORV and ATV/UTV use. Other alternatives would regulate but not ban ORV use. Further, in response to public comments, NPS plans to revise the preferred alternative to permit the use of non-sport ATVs and UTVs.  254.  In reference to page 518, what is the standard for “low” visitation?  “Page 518, third paragraph: By what standard is the number of ORVs visiting the Seashore annually considered to be "low"?” (399792)  Visitors associated with ORVs are a small share of total visitation at the park; visitors transported by private boat and passenger ferries represent the largest share of visitors to the Seashore. NPS estimated that approximately 13,000 ATV/UTV or ORV passengers would visit the park under alternative A (the no-action alternative). This compares to an average of approximately 58,000 passenger ferry visitors. In addition, there are frequently more than twice as many visitors transported by private boats than by ferry (refer to Visitor Use Statistics Special Report data for the Seashore). Thus, NPS estimates that overall, ORV, ATV, and UTV visitors constitute less than 10 percent of visitors to the Seashore (excluding the visitor’s  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  center).  255.  Clarify the conclusion that a 100 percent reduction in visitation would result in short-term, rather than longterm impacts.  “Page 518, fourth paragraph: What is the basis (e.g., labor market study) for the claim that: "In the short term, a 100 percent reduction in visitation would likely involve short-term adverse impacts as the local economy and job market absorbs the displaced workers or the workers leave the area"? It is possible, for example, that the local economy and job market may not be able to absorb displaced workers and/or displaced workers need to take lower-paying jobs (including part time or seasonal jobs) resulting in long-term adverse local income and employment impacts. It is also possible that due to a number of reasons, migration out of the local area to seek jobs elsewhere may be slow and "sticky" resulting in long-term adverse local income and employment impacts.” (39994)  Economists define the short run and long run to distinguish between solutions that are immediately feasible with some factors of production fixed in quantity, and solutions that are eventually available under conditions when all factors of production can be varied. As the length of time over which a solution is sought becomes longer, more options become feasible to address adverse impacts. (For example, refer to Parkin, M. 2010. Microeconomics. Boston: Addison-Wesley, p. 252.)  256.  The overall loss of visitation should be noted in the socioeconomic section.  “Also, the statement is made that if ORV use is restricted, then increases by visitors seeking ORV-free experiences may provide positive economic impacts. However, this Socioeconomic Resources section noted earlier that this potential increase is likely smaller than the losses created by restricting ORV users, so there would still be an overall loss. This should be stated here on page 519.” (399795)  In the final ORV management plan/EIS, NPS added text to note that positive impacts associated with increases in visitation by people without ORVs would likely not offset adverse impacts associated with reductions in visitation by ORV users, and would be incurred by different stakeholders.  257.  ORV regulations would result in a 25 – 40 percent loss of vehicles being transported to the Seashore.   “Most of the clientele, around 80% are from North and South Carolina. North Carolina ranks near the bottom, 3rd in National household income while South Carolina only ranks #40 in household incomes. A lot of these folks drive more than a thousand miles, roundtrip, already paying for astronomically high prices for gas. Keep in mind, since 1998, Morris Marina has not increased ferry rates in order to keep visitation up, if the National Park Service is allowed to implement a driving fee, I expect a 25-30% loss of vehicles being transported to the seashore.” (399848) “If the National Park Service implements Alterative C it will  NPS acknowledges that vehicle ferry operators and others who serve ORV users who visit the seashore would likely experience the most serious economic impacts as a result of the ORV rules. Based on the assessment by NPS, the commenter’s estimated magnitudes are likely high; however, some negative impacts are likely. In terms of impacts to the larger economy, however, NPS does not expect large impacts to the region of influence, even if all visitation by ORV users were lost. However,  Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  take away approximately 40% of our total income. What that means to us is that our business will not be able to continue to survive. It will cost six full time and four part time employees their jobs. Is this best for the economics of the Down East area of Carteret County? Is it best for the state of North Carolina? There are a lot of people and businesses which depend heavily on tourism throughout our state. Was it a positive thing to put the number of small ferry business out of Beaufort and Harkers Island in the un-employed lines?” (399951)  NPS does not expect visitation to decline dramatically. Examining visitation at Cape Hatteras National Seashore during periods before and after implementation of the ORV rules, data does not show an overall reduction in visitation after the ORV rules were implemented. Examining visitation patterns at Cape Hatteras National Seashore from 1990 through 2013, visitation during the periods 1990–1996, 2004– 2008, and 2009–2013 all averaged 2.2 million visitors per year. During the period 1997–2003, Cape Hatteras National Seashore averaged 2.7 million visitors per year.  ORV camping visitation shows a similar pattern: from 2000 to 2004, average ORV camping visitation was 28,005. During the period 2005– 2008, the average was 24,764. For the period 2009–2013, the average was 23,341. Visitation was down in 2008, but rose again in 2009 and 2010 to levels slightly higher than 2006 and 2007. Omitting 2011, which was the lowest year during the entire 15-year period, (probably due to Hurricane Irene), the average for 2009–2013 was 24,064—higher than the average for the period leading up to 2008. Thus, in terms of overall visitation, visitation by ORV users, and levels of economic activity, the Cape Hatteras National Seashore ORV rules do not appear to have had a severe impact, and overall business closures may be due to wider economic issues. However, it is likely that businesses that specialize in serving visitors who use ORVs may have incurred more serious impacts. This pattern corresponds to the expected pattern of economic impacts NPS has  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  projected for the ORV rules at Cape Lookout National Seashore. Furthermore, in response to public comments, including concerns about potential negative economic impacts, NPS has revised the preferred alternative which would reduce the potential adverse impacts to visitors who use ORVs and ferry operators. For example, closure dates have been made consistent. Night-driving restrictions have been revised, to allow back route driving from 5 am – 6 am and 9 pm – 10 pm. New pedestrian-only areas are now seasonal only. Non-sport ATV/UTV use would now be permitted for the entire season. Instead of 10-day and annual permits, there would be 3day, 14-day (same as the length of time you can camp on the Seashore), and annual permits. Final permit limit numbers will now be based on a five-year average, with significant closures being excluded from overall numbers to avoid skewing the long-term average. A civic engagement process would be required for any changes to the number of permits per year. Vehicle length restrictions have been removed and trailer length restrictions will be 30 feet. Taken together, all of these changes to the plan would reduce the potential economic impacts because with these revisions, the preferred alternative would be more similar to alternative A, the no-action alternative. Thus, the potential adverse socioeconomic impacts would be reduced by these revisions.  258. NPS Visitor Use Statistics program. For example, refer to this website: https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/SSRSReports/Park% 20Specific%20Reports/Park%20YTD%20Versio n%202?Park=CALO.  259.  The estimated expenses for ORV uses at Cape Lookout National Seashore is not accurate and too low. The report where these numbers are derived from states many limitations, some of which apply to the Seashore.  “The expenses listed in Table 66 are too low for the average ORV user at CALO. I calculated the average costs for my four trips per year. My trips range from 3 to 6 days (average = 5) with one to two people in my truck (average = 1.75). My cost for cabin rental is $42.00 per party of two for each day, compared to $18.92 for motel and camping fees in Table 66. My cost for food, beverage and ice is at least $45.00 per party of two for each day, compared to $30.18 for restaurants, bars and groceries in Table 66. (Ice alone costs $11.34 per party of two for each day.) My cost for bait is $10.34 per party of two for each day, compared to $9.99 for entertainment in Table 66. My cost for gasoline is $29.75 (including generator gasoline) per party of two for each day, compared to $24.59 in Table 66. The most glaring difference is the cost of the vehicle ferry boat service for ORV users. My cost for vehicle ferry service is $28.90 per party of two for each day, compared to the local transportation cost of $4.42 in Table 66. This cost is not optional, we have to pay it to get to the island. Vehicles with more passengers or longer durations will be less, but larger vehicles or shorter durations will be more. My cost for fishing tackle is at least $20.00 per party of two for each day, compared to $13.27 for miscellaneous retail in Table 66. My TOTAL cost is $175.99 compared to $101.39 in Table 66, an increase of 73.6%.T ORV Plan Socioeconomic Resource acknowledges a potential reduction of vehicle ferry service customer volume at increments of -10%, 25 ad -100% (age 508 and Table 67 on page 509). However, those three projections are not tied specifically to any of the five alternatives and there is no estimate for Alternative C, the park service's preferred alternative” (399891)  NPS recognizes that average expenditures per day for park visitors as reported in table 66 may not be representative of every visitor’s experience. However, NPS has concluded that these estimates constitute the best data available for the purpose of valuing visitation to the Seashore.  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Concept  Quote  Response  “Table 66 on page 506 comes directly from the report Economic Benefits to Local Communities from National Park Visitation and Payroll by Daniel J. Stynes, Professor Emeritus at Michigan State University. I have read this report. It is a good description of the economic benefits of national parks at a macro level. The Table 66 data is the average daily spend per user at a typical NPS campground. Stynes notes in his report that "Spending averages at individual parks vary from these system-wide averages due to differences in local prices and spending opportunities." His report includes one and a half pages about the errors and limitations of the report including the disclaimer "many Alaska parks are only accessible by air or boat, so spending profiles estimated from visitor surveys at parks in the lower 48 states do not apply well". I believe his reference to the remoteness of Alaska parks also applies to CALO due to its limited access by boat.” (399879)  POTENTIAL IMPACTS – PARK OPERATIONS  260. Why not use this money (if C is adopted) for maintenance or  As a special use permit, the ORV permit is addressed by Director’s Order 53: Special Park Uses. As a cost recovery program administered under NPS Director’s Order 53, the actual price of the ORV permit will be derived by determining the additional operational costs (staffing, supplies, equipment and other non-personnel services costs), above and beyond base funded operations4, Law enforcement is one component of these costs that is accounted for.  4 Base operating funds is the part of the annual appropriation from Congress for Operation of the National Park System (ONPS) which isallocatedby the NPS to each park to fund salaries and other expenses such as utilities to operate the park. Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  resource management.” (399936) “LAW ENFORCEMENT / RESOURCE MANAGEMENT: At the Beaufort NPS Off-Road Plan presentation I asked Superintendent Kenney what he intended to use the additional funds that would be produced from the new permits and fees. No drug deals, bank robberies, murders, rapes, high speed chases or anything of that nature. (2) Carteret County is one of the larger counties in our state. On a regular duty shift there is approximately 7 deputies on duty for the entire county. The park budget needs to account for structure maintenance and replacement.   “In addition to operating expense deficiencies the park has suffered from inadequate funding for infrastructure maintenance. The park service inherited many structures on South Core Banks that they have struggled to maintain. The Core Banks Gun Club facility was never maintained and has decayed to the point where the only remaining option now is demolition, but the park service does not have funding for that. Likewise the old Coast Guard dock is crumbling away and needs to be demolished. Beyond the need for demolition funding, both of these sites have tremendous potential and need funding to develop new structures there. Both sites are suitable for boat docks for private boats, canoes and kayaks. Both sites are suitable for handicap fishing piers and associated parking of ORVs. There are many significant structures in and near the historic village  The NPS recognizes the need to address ongoing maintenance of structures at the Seashore, something that requires additional attention given the dynamic nature of the Seashore. Planning for these structures, including maintenance, demolition, or reuse, is outside the scope of this ORV management plan/EIS and would be addressed in a separate planning process if necessary.   Cape Lookout National Seashore Appendix B: Comment Response Report Concept  Quote  Response  that are crying for maintenance. Some of those structures would be ideal for rental such as meeting and educational day use and overnight stays, but they need funding for water, sewage and electricity infrastructure. The park service needs to anticipate replacing cabins at an average rate of about 10% pr year and accumulate a cabin replacement reserve fund. Due to the harsh environment they are exposed to, the useful life of these cabins is much lower than at other park units.” (397697)  Off-road Vehicle Management Plan/EIS Cape Lookout National APPENDIX D: AGENCY CORRESPONDENCE As the nation’s principal conservation agency, the Department of the Interior has responsibility for most of our nationally owned public lands and natural resources. This includes fostering wise use of our land and water resources, protecting our fish and wildlife, preserving the environmental and cultural values of our national parks and historic places, and providing for the enjoyment of life through outdoor recreation. The department assesses our energy and mineral resources and works to ensure that their development is in the best interests of all our people. The department also promotes the goals of the Take Pride in America campaign by encouraging stewardship and citizen responsibility for the public lands and promoting citizen participation in their care. The department also has a major responsibility for American Indian reservation communities and for people who live in island territories under U.S. administration. (2016) United States Department of the Interior · National Park Service
